PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled:
The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1987-88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided Medical Benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Peace Trust Fund Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
At present all Australians, including those who conscientiously object to war and the preparation of war, are required by law for a portion of their income tax to be spent on military use.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray.

That you support the Peace Tax Trust Fund Bill 1989 which has been presented by Western Australian Independent Senator, Jo Vallentine. This Bill does not propose that anyone be permitted to withhold tax, but that the law should be changed to allow conscientious objectors to divert the military portion of their tax into more positive and socially useful programs.

PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.
Your petitioners, therefore humbly pray:

That you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by Western Australia Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Maguire (from 21 citizens) and Powell (from 192 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: End of War List
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned showeth that:
The members of the Australian Armed Forces who served in the Vietnam from 1962 to 1973 did so with distinction, valour and professionalism, upholding the traditions of the Armed Forces.
After World War 2 and the Korean War the Australian Government approved an End of War List of Gallantry Medals for individual acts of bravery that were not rewarded during wartime.
The Whitlam Government refused to approve such an End of War List at the end of the Vietnam War.
Your humble petitioners pray that:
The Federal Government reverse the decision of the Whitlam Government and thus approve an End of War List for the Australian Armed Forces personnel that served in Vietnam.
Upon the approval of the End of War List, the case of the 2nd Lieutenant John Fraser, 3RAR be considered for the award of a posthumous military honour.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

GRAPE RESEARCH LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1989
The purpose of this Bill is to increase the maximum rate of the levy that may be imposed under the Grape Research Levy Act 1986.

The Grape Research Levy Act 1986 imposes a levy on fresh and dried grapes and grape juice, delivered to wineries and other processing establishments. Dried grapes which are leviable under the Dried Fruits Levy Act 1971 are exempt. Levy is payable by grapegrowers and by winemakers who grow their own grapes.

The proceeds of the levy represent the grapegrowers contribution to the financing of research on winegrapes and other processed grapes. The Commonwealth matches industry expenditure under the program. A Grape and Wine Research Council established under the Rural Industries Research Act 1985 administers the grape research program.

Currently the maximum rate of the levy under the Grape Research Levy Act is 50c per tonne. The operative rate of the levy was increased to this level with effect from 1 January 1989. This amendment will provide flexibility for the levy to be increased in future but only if industry so requests.

In May 1988 the Government re-affirmed its commitment to matching rural industry research expenditures up to a ceiling of 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production (GVP) of the industry concerned. Subsequently the Winegrape Growers' Council of Australia requested that the maximum rate of the Grape Research Levy be increased to $2 per tonne to enable a phased increase in grape industry research funding.
This Bill implements that request which was supported by each of the nationally representative winemaker organisations.

I want to emphasise that this Bill does not increase the operative rate of levy currently paid by grapegrowers. Increases in operative rates will continue to be set by regulation under the Grape Research Levy Act. There is a specific legislative requirement for industry to be consulted before such increases are implemented.

Increasing the maximum rate of the grape research levy will not in itself have a direct impact on government expenditure. The extent to which outlays for grape research increase in the future will depend upon the level of levy increases implemented over time within the higher maximum rate.

Growers' funds provided by this levy and matching Commonwealth contributions have placed grape research on a secure long term financial basis. An initial relatively modest expenditure program of about $270,000 in 1987-88 will increase to a budgeted level of $522,000 in the current year.
This Bill will facilitate further development of the program commensurate with growers' willingness to contribute additional funds for that purpose.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
WINE GRAPES LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1989

The purpose of this Bill is to restructure the levy which funds the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation. The new levy arrangements will improve equity in levy contributions between small, medium and large winemakers and provide increased funding for the Corporation.

This Bill is part of a package of measures to promote further development of the wine industry An associated Bill amends the Grape Research Levy Act to introduce a higher maximum levy rate and a third Bill amends the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Act to implement a program to enable wine labelling claims to be verified.

The Wine Grapes Levy Act 1979 imposes a levy on fresh and dried grapes and grape juice used in the manufacture of wine. The levy has two components-a marketing amount to finance the promotional and regulatory activities of the Corporation and a research amount which provides industry funding for wine research. The levy is payable by winery proprietors using the equivalent of 20 tonnes or more of fresh grapes per year in winemaking.

The current marketing component of the levy is a flat rate of $4 per tonne of prescribed goods with a cap of $20,000 on levy payments per levy payer. This levy structure has resulted in a disproportionate burden of Corporation funding falling upon smaller and medium sized wineries and considerable potential levy income from larger wineries has been foregone. For example, a proprietor of a winery crushing 5,000 tonnes of grapes pays $4 per tonne of $20,000, but a proprietor of a winery crushing $80,000 tonnes of grapes also pays $20,000 because of the $20,000 levy ceiling. A further weakness in the present levy system is that because of the levy ceiling corporate amalgamations have the potential to significantly reduce levy revenue over time.
Amendments proposed in this Bill address these issues by abolishing the levy ceiling, introducing a tiered levy system and reducing the threshold tonnage below which levy is not payable.

Under the structure proposed, the levy to fund the Corporation will consist of a flat amount of $200 for each levy payer plus an additional amount depending on the tonnage of grapes used in winemaking. To calculate this additional amount a sliding scale of levy rates will be used. Progressively lower rates will apply as tonnage crushed increases. The maximum rates and initial operative rates of the levy are set out in clause 6 of the Bill.

At present proprietors of wineries crushing less than 20 tonnes of prescribed goods per year are exempt from both the marketing and research components of the levy. This Bill proposes to reduce that exemption threshold from 20 tonnes to 10 tonnes.

The levy will continue to be payable on fresh and dried grapes and grape juice used in winemaking. Provision will remain for the operative rates of levy to be changed by regulation. In respect of the marketing component, this will occur only after consideration of any recommendation made to the Minister by the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation. The Corporation must first submit its recommendation to an annual general meeting of the industry and advise the Minister of the voting on any relevant resolution.

The changes provided for in this Bill were requested and are strongly supported by the wine industry. A motion recommending the changes was approved by an 84 per cent majority of votes cast at the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation annual general meeting in February this year. The proposal to reduce the exemption threshold from 20 tonnes to 10 tonnes in respect of the research component of the levy has the support of each of the three national winemaker organisations. It will retain consistency in the exemption level for each component of the levy.

The levy changes proposed will also provide substantially increased funding from the Corporation. In 1990-91 estimated levy income will be about $1.16m compared with approximately $750,000 in 1989-90.

Since 1987-99 the Corporation has incurred significant deficits financed through reductions in its reserves. The Corporation has budgeted for a further deficit of about $176,000 in the current year. The increase in levy receipts expected from the changes being implemented through this Bill should arrest the erosion of Corporation reserves and be sufficient to cover increased program expenditure by 1990-91.

The Corporation was reconstituted in 1986 to improve its accountability to industry and to enable it to operate more effectively and efficiently. The strong industry support for an increase in the level of its funding for the Corporation reflects industry confidence in the Corporation and the programs it has implemented and intends to implement for the industry's benefit.

The Corporation has allocated a high proportion of its resources towards encouraging and servicing, through its export promotion and inspection arrangements, the rapid increase in exports which has occurred in recent years. The value of exports of Australian wine has increased more than fivefold from $20.5m in 1985-86 to $113m in 1988-89. Exports in the current year are expected to be worth $133m.

The wine industry, supported by the Corporation, is working hard to further increase awareness of the quality and value of our wines and to protect the reputation of the industry as a supplier of consistently reliable products. In addition to its promotional programs the Corporation has implemented a compliance monitoring program under which wine samples are analysed for non-permissible additives. Introduction of a label integrity program will further enhance consumer confidence in Australian wine.
Funding changes embodied in this Bill will enable the Corporation to maintain these and other programs from a more secure financial base.

The Bill contains appropriate transitional provisions for implementation of the new levy rates from 1 January 1990 which is midway through the normal levy year. This has been done so that the new levy system can apply to the 1990 grape harvest, thereby making additional funding available to the Corporation as soon as possible. The existing levy will apply until 31 December 1989, but a winery proprietor's maximum levy liability in 1989-90 will be limited to what he or she would have incurred had the new levy rates applied throughout 1989-90.

The proposed amendments will have no net effect on government expenditure. The levy which funds the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation is paid into the Consolidated Revenue Fund and an equal amount is appropriated from the Fund for payment to the Corporation. The revised levy has no additional cost implications for the Department of Primary Industries and Energy as levy collection costs are fully recouped from the industry.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
AUSTRALIAN WINE AND BRANDY CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

The main purpose of this Bill is to provide the legislative basis for implementation of a wine label integrity program by the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation. It also makes amendments to the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Act 1980 consequential on amendment of the Wine Grapes Levy Act provided for in an accompanying Bill. In addition this Bill amends penalties in the principal Act.

The wine label integrity program will require wine manufacturers to keep records to support labelling claims of the vintage, variety or region of origin of wine and to make those records and the stocks to which they relate available for audit upon request by the Corporation. The purpose of auditing is to help to ensure truth in labelling, thereby increasing consumer confidence in the reliability of wine label claims and enhancing the reputation for quality and value of Australian wine in domestic and export markets.

The label integrity program has been devised and developed by the Corporation at the request of the wine industry. It has the support of each of the three national winemaker organisations and was recommended for adoption by a substantial majority of votes cast at the Corporation's annual general meeting in February 1989. The Wine and Grape Industry Advisory Council comprising representatives of winemakers and grape growers, considers that the program will contribute to meeting the need for regular systematic monitoring of compliance with wine labelling requirements.

The need for legislation by the Commonwealth arises from concern within the wine industry, the Corporation and the Government to protect our reputation for producing sound, good quality wines with accurate product description on labels. Exports of Australian wine have grown from $20.5m in 1985-86 to $113m in 1988-89 and are expected to reach $133m in 1989-90. Continued export expansion is now a key to the industry's future growth and prosperity and protecting the reputation of our wines is essential to achievement of that objective.

The Australian wine industry also holds a 97 per cent share of the domestic market for wine. I believe Australian consumers will welcome the implementation of a label integrity program as a further initiative by the wine industry to enhance consumer respect for the local product.

The price which winemakers can obtain for premium wines may invite spurious labelling claims by any producer who has little respect for accuracy in product descriptions. Experience overseas has shown that, in the event of fraudulent winemaking practices and product description by the irresponsible few, export customers tend to avoid wine from all producers of the country affected. Australia's winemakers wish to pre-empt any such damage to their industry, by implementing their own program of industry self-regulation. Knowledge that a system is in place to facilitate detection of breaches should be a strong deterrent to any potential transgressors.

The Bill provides that all wine manufacturers engaged in the manufacture of wine for commercial purposes be required to keep a record of the vintage, variety, region of origin, source of supply and quantity of grape products received for use in making wine. This will enable the Corporation to trace a wine back to the point where grapes from which it was produced were first harvested or juice was first processed.

Wine manufacturers who sell or dispose of their wine without any claim as to its vintage, variety or region of origin need not maintain any further records in respect of such wine. For example wine manufacturers who sell their wine as claret, burgundy, moselle or chablis, once they have made records of their intake of grape products, can dispense with further record keeping.

Wine manufacturers who make claims about the vintage, variety or region of origin of a particular wine will need to keep records relating to the production, sales and disposal of all such wines, thereby establishing an `audit trail'. This will enable verification of claims made by wine manufacturers about the pedigree of the wine and enable the Corporation to determine whether or not more wine described as being of a particular variety-say, chardonnay-is being sold than could possibly be produced from the available grape supply.

Relevant clauses in part 3 of the Bill take account of typical transactions occurring in the wine industry-which include blending of wines, sale of wine to other wineries, transfer of wine between the producing arm and marketing arm of related companies, winemaking under contract, relabelling of wines without labels and cellar door sales. The clauses in each case impose obligations on wine manufacturers to keep records, not on grapegrowers or bottling firms.

The need for record keeping arises from a circumstance believed to be unique to the wine industry-that there is no known technical means of assessing a wine to determine its vintage, variety or region of origin. For most other primary products, it is possible to verify contents by technical means-for example by species testing or by other analysis of the physical or chemical characteristics of the product.

As a matter of normal commercial practice most winemakers already maintain the records they will be required by this Bill to keep. Where winemakers do not already maintain intake, production, sales and disposal records, the Corporation will assist them to establish simple and appropriate record keeping procedures. The Corporation will be providing a guide to wineries on the requirements of this Bill and will be visiting wineries to further explain the requirements of the label integrity program and to ensure that producers are familiar with the record-keeping requirements appropriate to their particular operations.

Labelling requirements concerning vintage, variety and region of origin are enshrined in food laws administered by State and Territory governments. This Bill does not change existing food laws or introduce new labelling requirements nor does it encroach upon the authority and responsibilities of the States and Territories for administering those laws. In consultations, these governments have indicated that they would welcome the assistance of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation in monitoring compliance with wine labelling aspects of food laws. Evidence of any apparent breaches detected by the Corporation will be brought to the attention of the States and Territories for appropriate action, or action may be brought under the consumer deception provisions of the Trade Practices Act.

The wine industry does not seek through the label integrity program to emulate the European appellation system. There are no attempts to limit the types of grapes which can be grown in a specific region, to limit the yield which can be obtained from a vineyard or to prescribe certain methods of production. All that is required is that winemakers who make labelling claims of vintage, variety or region of origin, maintain the records necessary to substantiate the claims.

The Bill contains appropriate provisions necessary for effective administration of the program. These include standard provisions relating to the powers of inspectors, access to premises and the gathering of evidence of label offences.

The consequential amendments to the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Act 1980 contained in part 2 of the Bill will maintain the existing arrangements concerning voting rights at annual general meetings of the Corporation, payment to the Corporation of levy money collected by the Commonwealth and refunds of any overpayments back to the Commonwealth.

The up-dated penalty rates specified in the schedule to the Bill relate to offences against provisions concerning the coverage of grape products, provision of information to the Corporation, export of grape products and offences against regulations made pursuant to the principal Act.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill and allied Bills and to support the amendment moved by Senator Stone. These Bills basically reduce the revenue that would have been received by this Government as a result of enormous bracket creep that is, of course, still pushing Australian taxpayers into even larger and larger tax bills, despite this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Total taxation revenues in the last year of the Fraser Government, 1982-83, totalled $41 billion. They are budgeted this year to total $91.3 billion. That is almost a 120 per cent increase. The significance of that increase is that over that time, from 1982-83 to 1989-90, the consumer price index (CPI) is estimated to have risen by 64 per cent. Tax revenues are up by almost double the rate of rise of the CPI. There can be no more dramatic instance, no more clear evidence, of the justification for the nickname `bracket creep' for this Treasurer (Mr Keating) than this evidence of bracket creep.

This Government, through its relaxed, casual approach to inflation, an inflation that is destroying Australia's competitive position in the world, is destroying our export industries and making our import replacement industries incapable of competing against the burgeoning volume of imports to this country. This Government's approach to that disastrous inflation has been so lax, its management so incompetent, that it has brought about this massive increase in government revenues. It makes one wonder whether in fact inflation suits this Government. It is what this Government wants. It is so easy for this Government, when there is a high level of inflation, to pay its bills and to come out with the respectable looking surpluses by which it seeks to ingratiate itself with the business community.

The fact is that this Government's lax, incompetent approach to the secret killer of the Australian economy-inflation-has brought this Government significant revenue benefits which these Bills purport to give back to the people of Australia, but which in fact do not give back anything like the volume that is necessary to provide any kind of fair go to taxpayers as a whole and Australian families in particular, who have been suffering unbelievably as a result of the economic and taxation policies of this Government.

I go back to this rise in total taxes of something like 120 per cent, while the cost of living, as measured by the CPI has gone up by only about 64 per cent since 1982-83. Not only have we seen that huge rise in taxes with net pay as you earn tax up something like 103 per cent, about one and a half times the rise in inflation, but also we have seen other taxes, such as those paid by unincorporated provisional taxpayers, go up by something like 115 per cent. During that time the Medicare levy has been introduced-a phoney system that theoretically pays for Medicare but of course does not and is simply a hidden tax, totalling this year something like $2.6 billion. There is also the prescribed payments system. We must add all those things on to the total tax bill. If we do that we see income tax on individuals up by 124 per cent under this Government. As I said, it is just about double the rate of inflation. Taxes on companies are up by 135 per cent over that period. The Government could well say that this is because companies are doing better, and that is true: company profits have risen. But when we add all these taxes together we find a horrendous rise.

But the most interesting, dishonest and disgraceful rise in taxes is in the sector of the tax regimen which this Government said would not be increased-consumption taxes. In fact, it said that there would be no consumption taxes. Do honourable senators remember the dishonest attack that the Australian Labor Party waged in the last two election campaigns against the coalition on the question of consumption taxes? `There will be no consumption taxes', it said. It claimed that the only people who were talking about consumption taxes were the coalition. That is totally phoney and crooked. The figures demonstrate the extent to which this Government behaved in its typical dishonourable and disgraceful way because the fastest rising taxes in Australia are consumption taxes, the very taxes the Labor Party was not going to introduce, the very tax system the Labor Party said was a disgrace when it alleged that the Opposition was going to introduce one.

So what has happened to these consumption taxes that do not exist according to the Labor Party but which are eating money out of the pockets of Australian families? Under the Fraser Government sales taxes totalled about $3.49 billion-well under 10 per cent of total taxation revenue. What are they in the current Budget? They total $10.5 billion. They have trebled. There has been a three-fold increase in sales taxes while the cost of living has gone up only 65 per cent. It is incredible that this Government can come in here and show no embarrassment, no shame, no humiliation about this deceptive increase in the one tax it said would not exist under a Labor Government. The classic Labor lie is manifested here. Sales tax totals $10.5 billion and is the biggest single consumption tax that exists.

Of course, that $10.5 billion is out of a total tax revenue of $91 billion-well over 10 per cent of total tax collections. How did the Labor Government get this increase? It was not, as the Labor Party would have us believe, just because of the indexing of excise-for example, beer excise going up automatically as the CPI goes up. That would only account for a 65 per cent rise. We have not had a 65 per cent rise; we have had a 200 per cent rise in consumption taxes. How has the Labor Party done it? Very simply. It has put a tax on orange juice, ice cream, kids' flavoured milk and snack foods. What are the sorts of things that Australian families tend to consume in fairly large quantities? Exactly those things on which the Labor Party has imposed the non-existent tax, the tax that it does not believe in and would not introduce. That is where the tax rises have taken place.

I am totally in favour of a correction, a fixing up, of the mess that has been made of the sales tax situation by successive governments. I believe it should be made fairer. I do not believe it is fair to do what this Government has done, which has been to put a tax on kids' orange juice and ice-cream but to leave pornographic magazines tax free. Thousand-dollar ball-gowns are tax free under this Government, but kids' ice-cream and orange juice are not. What sort of standards does this Government have? It says that it is totally opposed to consumption taxes. I wonder, when it avoids putting a sales tax on pornographic magazines, whether it is paying more attention to and having greater concern about the interests of the publishing houses of this country than the welfare of this country. I believe the vested interests that this Government seeks to serve consistently are evident from the nature of its laws, particularly in this area.

As I said, we have had a 200 per cent increase in sales tax revenues and a 64 per cent increase in the cost of living. On top of that there are all these additional taxes like the fringe benefits tax-you name it, and they have taxed it-and on top of all that, we have had the magnificent bracket creep that this Treasurer has specialised in and which has enabled him to produce such substantial surpluses in the Budget. As was pointed out by Mr Ian Wilson in the other place only last week, when one looks at the impact of bracket creep-this Government's subtle, sinister, underhand increase of the tax burden on Australian families-one sees a particularly distasteful sight. And this is after the so-called tax cuts that this Government is introducing in this legislation. The Treasurer claims that this new tax structure `more than offsets what is known as fiscal drag or bracket creep'. The Treasurer in his April economic statement went on to say:
In other words, personal income taxpayers will now be paying less than if we had indexed the tax scales for inflation since 1983.

That is simply deliberately misleading. It deliberately distorts the truth. The truth is that tax revenues have increased far faster, as I have demonstrated from these figures, than the cost of living and the index that would be applied. The Treasurer is getting away with basically saying that, because there is a one-year delay in applying the impact of indexation, that one-year delay may well-and I have not checked the figures-have started to offset this enormous bracket creep. The fact is that, so long as inflation increases at a far lower rate than personal income tax, bracket creep is taking more and more out of Australian taxpayers' pockets.

This can be demonstrated quite clearly. This year, taxpayers on average annual earnings who have a dependent spouse and two dependent children will pay an estimated 16 per cent of their income in tax under Keating, under the so-called lower tax rates. According to Keating, people will be doing better than if the tax scales had been indexed as his tax cuts will more than offset bracket creep. People will be paying 16 per cent this year. What did they pay in the last year of the Fraser Government? They paid only 14.1 per cent of their income. In other words, a worker on average annual earnings, with a dependent spouse and two dependent children, has had his or her tax burden increased from 14.1 per cent to 16 per cent. That means that the tax burden on such a family has been increased by Labor by almost 14 per cent. Yet the Treasurer has the gall to make claims that are clearly deceptive and misleading. He claims that the tax burden on families has been reduced under this Government. That is simply untrue.

The same applies to taxpayers without dependants. The tax payable under the new Keating tax formula for someone on average annual earnings of $28,216 would be $6,813. Such a taxpayer on average earnings will pay 24.1 per cent of his or her income in tax. Under the Fraser Government in 1982-83, when average earnings were about $17,630 that taxpayer would have paid $4,038 in income tax, or only 22.9 per cent of his or her income. This is not simply an isolated case that I have selected. It is a universal truth that under this Government, despite its highly publicised tax cuts, the average family and the average taxpayer are paying far more of their income in tax.

Total tax revenues have massively increased. They are far higher-almost double the rate of inflation. Yet we are told by the Government, or at least by one of its senior Ministers, `Don't worry, we are going to have a big $5 billion tax cut next year, too'. The comments of the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, were reported in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on Tuesday this week. The article stated:
The Government would probably repeat this year's $5.8 billion tax and family package next year, a senior Cabinet Minister revealed yesterday.

In an interview with the Herald, the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, said it was likely that Labor would deliver a similar tax and family assistance package to the $5.8 billion handout announced in this year's April statement.
One would need something like a $5.8 billion handout next year to go at least part of the way in giving back to the taxpayers what this Government has raised in taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —It won't be fully funded though, will it?
—As Senator Watson says-this is the key element that I am coming to-the package will not be fully funded.
—Will it be funded at all?

—Indeed, will it take place at all? If the Government does not provide it, then it has been telling lies to the people of Australia about their true tax status. If it does provide it, where is the money to come from? A figure of $5.8 billion is double the benefit that the Liberal and National parties have outlined in the excellent Economic Action Plan. Yet this Government has tried to smear that by asking where the money is coming from. Despite its earnest and best endeavours the Government has been unable even to dent the integrity of that plan. The only integrity that has been dented has been that of the Treasurer, in his asinine attempt to demolish this plan.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the Labor Party's most senior Ministers is saying that the Government is going to provide a huge, apparently unfunded, tax cut next year. When challenged about it he went to water, but it was not merely a figment of his imagination. When Mr Howe was challenged about it he did not deny that such a matter was in the mind of someone in the Government. All he said was:
The Government has not as yet given consideration to any package for next year, but the approach would not be dissimilar from what has already been delivered this year.

In Labor Party wordspeak, what does that mean? What is meant by that response to the question asked by the shadow Treasurer, Dr Hewson, about Mr Howe's suggested $5.8 billion cut next year? I repeat what Mr Howe said:
The Government has not as yet given consideration to any package for next year.

The Government may not have formally done so as a government, but one should not think that Mr Brian Howe dreamt this up one morning on the way to work. This is clearly being discussed within the senior Ministry. It is clearly a matter that is on the table. It is clearly a matter that deserves very close public scrutiny. If the Government is serious it will have to provide some costing. If the Government goes ahead with the crazy notion that it has had in the past, that tax cuts can be provided out of nothing, it will perpetuate this disastrous inflationary situation that is now destroying this country. Unless tax cuts are funded, those tax cuts are totally and absolutely worthless. They are ephemeral; they will disappear next year, and they will disappear largely through the very bracket creep that has already under the Hawke Government brought about a rate of rising taxes almost double the rate of inflation.

I do not believe that the Australian people are prepared to put up with the phoneyness of that kind of transaction any more. I do not believe that the Australian public is prepared to believe the Government in this area. If the Government is going to do this at the expense of reducing the surplus rather than reducing its own expenditures, that will represent a loosening of fiscal policy. As the Reserve Bank of Australia has pointed out, a loosening of fiscal policy imposes a greater reliance on monetary policy, which simply means that the pressure is kept on for higher and higher interest rates.

We have seen the consequences of the Government's total failure to approach economic policy in a rational, coherent and competent way. We have seen it having to rely on interest rates going through the roof, pushing people out of their homes, destroying the viability of Australian families. We have seen the Government using the inflation rate to push people into higher and higher tax brackets, increasing the burden on Australian families. We have seen the Government in its incompetence destroying Australian export industries.

Our balance of payments is now a total disaster and we now have $2 billion a month deficits on our current account, and we have to borrow more and more from overseas, selling off more and more of the farm because there is nothing else for us to do. This has meant the forced sales of Australian assets so that we can keep paying the bill-and that bill is a huge one because of this Government's incompetence. It has set out on a clear pattern of economic policy which has resulted in higher inflation, which brings higher government revenues. Of course, those higher taxes help undermine the stability of the Australian family and the higher interest rates they bring undermine the stability of Australian business. It has bought whatever successes it has been able to claim at an untenable and appalling cost of putting Australia perpetually in debt in a way which will present the next government-which will take office whenever this Government gets around to having an election-with enormous problems. How fortunate we are that the present Opposition has the competence, the talent and the policies to resolve those problems.

Every Budget time, over the full period of this Government's mismanagement, we have outlined exactly what it was doing wrong. There is nothing new in what we are saying now. We have consistently warned it against proceeding down this track, against continuing with excessive government spending. That excessive spending was clearly evident in its first, second and third Budgets. Then it started to pull the reins in, but it was too little and too late. We have criticised every Budget on the same grounds. Every criticism is now being substantiated by what we see in the Australian economy right now. We warned that when Government did what we wanted-freed up the money markets, freed up the foreign exchange markets-it would impose a discipline on government that Mr Hawke and Mr Keating were not prepared to respond to. That discipline has not been imposed on this Government. It has dumped every tough decision. Mr Keating says, `But we have done some things'. But, as I said, that has always been in response to pressure from this side of the chamber. It is always too little and it is always too late. As a result, we have this awful situation from which Australia will find it so hard to emerge.

It is all very well to criticise the Government, but what will the Opposition do about it? As I mentioned earlier, the Reserve Bank pointed out that we cannot just rely on monetary policy, as it simply will not work, that we cannot restructure the Australian economy in the face of excessive inflation. Clearly, the thrust of the Opposition's policy is to get inflation down. We are determined in our fiscal policy to provide for smaller government, not the excessive government and the huge spending that has been the hallmark of this Government. It is all very well for people on the Government's front bench to point to reductions in the last couple of years. Those reductions became doubly necessary after the profligate, reckless, nonsensical behaviour of the first two or three Budgets that this Government introduced. In its first one, as I recall, having with great publicity announced a $1.3 billion cut in a May mini-Budget in 1983 it came out with $2.5 billion in extra spending. It hoped that people would notice that, instead of cutting spending, as its propaganda had it, it was in fact massively increasing government spending. And so it went on.

What will we be doing? We will be offering smaller government, privatisation of major government business enterprises and a larger Budget surplus. That means a tighter fiscal policy. That means taking the heat off interest rates and taking the heat off inflation. We will have the largest Budget surplus since comparable records have been kept. We will have tax relief that is fully funded by expenditure restraint, and that will exclude the proceeds of privatisation, which will go towards reducing the debt. In these difficult economic times tax relief will have to be limited to assisting those most disadvantaged by the Hawke-Keating Government, such as Australian families with children. Expenditure, including the proceeds of privatisation, is to be reduced to 22.5 per cent of gross domestic product, the lowest since 1964-65, the lowest for 25 years. Tax revenue is to be reduced to 24.3 per cent of GDP, the lowest for six years and there is a commitment to forego the increase in revenue because of bracket creep. That represents about $2.5 billion or so a year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few words in this debate without unduly taking the time of the Senate. Many of my colleagues and I have spoken about the economic crisis facing Australia not only in the period ahead but also now as a result of the quite massive economic mismanagement of the economy and related policy issues during the almost seven years of the Hawke Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not propose to go into the details of the Bills in the way that some of my colleagues have. I fully endorse the remarks that my colleague Senator Michael Baume has just made about the massive increase in revenue collections by this Government, a Government that has somehow or other held itself out to the Australian community as a lean, efficient Government that has managed to get revenues down. When one looks at the raw figures and takes account of the massive bracket creep that has occurred under the Government, one sees that the increase in taxation take has been unprecedented in this country's history. Far from having a government which over recent years has managed to keep taxation down, we have a government under which all forms of taxation, both direct and indirect, have increased massively. Senator Michael Baume mentioned the 150 per cent increase in sales tax take in recent years. The number of wage earners who are paying the 40 per cent rate of tax has increased staggeringly. The economic crisis facing small businesses, in particular, is positively horrendous due to the effect of taxation and interest rate increases.

TALK.START.PARA: —These are the same people to whom the Government wishes to deny the benefits of the repeal of the capital gains tax.

—Absolutely. As my colleague Senator Stone says, we on our side of politics are proposing the abolition of the capital gains tax and its replacement with a very sensible, rational but reasonable speculative gains tax. We are being pilloried by the Government for doing that. The Government is really trying to pillory us for saying, `We want to do something about small business in this country. Somehow or other this Government seems to think that there is something wrong with business making a profit and keeping some of the reward of that effort.
—The Government is only looking after its own big mates. It thinks they are the only ones who exist in the community.

—Yes, as my colleague Senator Stone points out, the relationship between the Government and certain areas of the big business community-at the expense of every other section of the community-requires the closest investigation. If as much investigation were put into that as the Government puts into running around trying to protect its flanks, there would be some very interesting revelations indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not generally realised by many in the community just how serious are the problems facing Australia. Not only in the short term but, even more so, in the medium and longer terms, as a result of the cumulative policies of this Government during the past six and a half years, Australia faces the biggest economic crisis that it has ever faced, certainly since World War II. There is no doubt at all about that when one considers the basic underlying position of this economy.

For some time Australia has had the highest level of interest rates in the whole of the Western world, together with the highest inflation rate of most Western countries for a period of years. In fact, during the period of the Hawke Government, Australia has had a record for having the highest level of inflation relative to its major trading partners that it has ever had in its history. Australia is now more uncompetitive on a cost and price basis with its major trading partners than it has ever been for such a lengthy period. That is some record.

Australia's record in the interest rate game is exactly the same. It is no wonder that the major international credit rating agencies have down graded Australia's credit rating twice in the past three years. The implications of that for the future, as well as for the present, are very significant indeed. It is not just a down-grading of the credit rating of the Government as a borrower; it is a down-grading of our credit rating as a nation, and that affects every borrower in the nation.

If there were any sign that we were getting out of this malaise-this crisis-perhaps one might take some comfort from that. However, the sad, the serious and the staggering thing is that, after those years of economic mismanagement, the situation shows no sign of improving. Indeed, it shows every sign of getting worse. Australia is running a balance of payments deficit on current account of an average of $2 billion a month. When the Hawke Government came to office, if our balance of payments deficit had been $2 billion a year on a regular basis, we would have said that we had a problem. The absolute and cumulative increases in our balance of payments deficit has created for us a debt to the rest of the world which is five times higher than it was when the Hawke Government came to power. There is a huge difference between using 5 per cent and using 20 per cent of one's export income to service one's foreign debt in terms of the capacity to raise, or for that matter maintain, basic living standards. If we cannot pay our way to the rest of the world, something has to give and what has been giving progressively has been our living standards and our capacity to build for the future. Our savings rate is abysmally low. Our real level of investment is abysmally low. So not only are we having current problems but also we are storing up future enormous problems because we are not putting ourselves in a position to be able to take the next leap forward as we should be doing.

Not only is the volume of our debt to the rest of the world of major concern but so is its composition. About one-third of our foreign borrowings are supplied by short term lenders who are coming to Australia only because of our excessively high interest rates.

When we look at the totality of the Government's economic policies over the last seven years and when we look at where we are as an economy in the world today compared with where we were in 1982-83, despite the fact that that was a year of major world recession and despite the fact that we were therefore having to live in a much more difficult international environment than we do today, we see that there is no denying the fact that as a nation we have gone backwards very significantly in world stakes in both absolute terms so far as our standard of living is concerned and relative terms compared with our major trading partners.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt at all-it cannot be denied and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is making a dreadful mess of trying to deny it-that the problems and the major crisis we are now facing are due wholly and solely to the mismanagement by, and the disastrous economic and related policies of, this Government. They are due to the refusal by this Government to make the necessary decisions not only in the area of macro-economic policies, but also in the area of micro-economic reform, where the rhetoric has been huge and the performance has been nil.

Those are the reasons why we have the fundamental problems we have today. Those are the reasons why the coalition has proposed a set of taxation and related economic proposals-both macro and micro-to tackle those fundamental problems. It has been very encouraging to see the Treasurer running around with the coalition's Economic Action Plan in his hand during the last three weeks. He has been trying to shoot it down and has not got within a kilometre of the target. Hopefully, at least, he might be reading it because, if he does, he will learn something about the way that economic policies ought to be proposed and conducted if we are to tackle those fundamental problems that face our community.

Of all the sections in the Australian community that have been most bludgeoned by the policies of this Government-and every section has been-the two that stand out above all the rest are families and small businesses. The basic thrust of the proposals contained in the coalition's Economic Action Plan is directed at those two groups and, through them, the wider community and, therefore, the wider economy. If we do not specifically tackle the problems facing families and small businesses in the short term, we will not allow them virtually to survive in the longer term.

The major proposals that the coalition has put forward to assist families will cost the revenue a little over $2 billion. Those proposals comprise a system of child tax rebates designed specifically to help parents with young families, at a cost to the revenue of $1,000m. That is assisted, in turn, by a system of tax rebates for child-care at an estimated full year cost of $820m. On top of that, there will be changes to the dependent spouse rebate to give benefit to families with a dependent spouse through a rebate system, at a cost of $200m. That is the main package of proposals for assistance to families in the short term.

So far as small business is concerned, the coalition will abolish the Australian Labor Party's enormously damaging capital gains tax and replace it with a tax on certain capital gains-because we realise that a tax on certain capital gains is important and equitable. But the coalition will not be saying, as this Government has, to a small business or any other investor who has worked hard to build up an asset, `If you work hard and build up a productive asset and you want to dispose of it several years down the track, we will take most of the results of your hard labour by capital gains tax at the marginal rate of tax'. We will say that only speculative gains will be taxed, in the first year at 100 per cent of the real realised gain, phasing out by 20 per cent a year so that after five years there would be no capital gains tax on the realisation of an asset. It will cost the revenue, compared with the present situation, $450m in a full year, but it is an equitable decision. It is a proposal that is designed to encourage business to invest, save and build-particularly small businesses, and particularly small businesses that are being crippled at the moment by the high interest rate regime. That will give small businesses an incentive to get themselves up and, through doing that, get the economy growing again.

The significant thing about the coalition's Economic Action Plan package is that it is very carefully costed and is fully funded, which is a fundamental point. That should be compared with the outrageous statement made earlier this week by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) that this Government will give the taxpayers and wage earners of Australia another $6 billion deal next year without 1c of it being funded. If that were to happen, the already enormous economic problems we have would be compounded. Obviously, that cannot be done with any measure of responsibility at all. That is not to say the Government will not do it, because everything the Government has done over the last six years has been irresponsible. If the Government were to do this, it would blow this economy even further out of the water.

I bet it will not do it because what Mr Howe was doing the other day was trying to join the Treasurer in the propaganda stakes race, because they are desperate about the electoral prospects of the Government during the next few months as it faces an election. Indeed, Mr Howe's outburst was absolutely typical of the actions of this Government in its decision-making processes during recent months. The whole decision-making process of this Government seems to have gone completely off the rails in recent months. The decisions that have been made are nothing more than cynical, vote buying, populist actions. As far as Coronation Hill and the handling of the pilots dispute--

TALK.START.PARA: —You must not use that word `dispute'.

—Yes, we have not got a dispute. It is very interesting that if one rings Australian Airlines and gets the answering machine, it says, `Due to an industrial dispute we are unable to answer the phone'. But the airline has not had a word with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) because the Prime Minister is telling us, `There ain't no dispute at all'. What absolute nonsense. Who does the Prime Minister think he is fooling? It is typical of the whole process of the Government's decision-making machinery at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: This was highlighted by a speech made at a conference in Sydney yesterday by a senior Minister of the Government. Actually I happened to be there, and it was very interesting. Mr Kerin made a speech essentially related to the Government's decision making in the area of not the environment but industrial development. The title of Mr Kerin's speech was, `The Government's Role and Responsibility in Safeguarding Industry Development'. He was really saying that the environmentalists have captured the Government and have captured the debate in the area of industry development, and that the Government has gone to water in front of them and in the face of them and is taking decisions without any due and proper regard to all the factors involved. Let me quote one paragraph from this speech, which I commend to all honourable senators as a speech that we ought to read. This paragraph in particular struck me. Mr Kerin said:

To my mind, governments need most of all to have consistent policy responses to the environmental puzzles they are faced with, rather than be seen to be reacting to each and every environmental group and its demands. If they don't, they are not acting as a government, nor are they engaging in the debate in the most responsible manner. People want governments to set the agenda and take balanced decisions. Politics is not just about the art of the possible, it is also about the peaceful resolution of conflict and it is also about giving leadership.

Mr Kerin was saying, very rightly-and he could not have made it any more overt-that this Government, of which he is a senior Minister, has not given leadership; it has caved in to individual groups in the community and it has adopted a populist, soft options approach in a blatant attempt to buy votes for the next election. As we on this side of the chamber have said time and time again, that is not going to work for the Government. In the process of it not working, the Government is taking decisions which are leading Australia down the road to economic ruin.

For example, the Coronation Hill decision relates to an area in which no mining will now be allowed. It is an area whose mineral wealth is estimated at something of the order of $7,000m. This Government has bowed to pressure groups and refused to allow the mining of Coronation Hill to go ahead. Of course, this is an area in which mining took place right through the 1950s and the 1960s. We are not talking about some pristine, virgin bit of land; we are talking about something that was mined for two whole decades. I am told that it is one square kilometre of land in a non-environmentally sensitive area, anyway, of 25,000 square kilometres. I am told that the area of land in question at Coronation Hill is something like a tenth of the size of the Parliament House precinct.

TALK.START.PARA: —Both you and the Government are wrong.

—Apparently Senator Coulter has not read, or if he has he is trying deliberately to misinform the Australian people, about a fundamentally important issue. It is a fundamentally important issue in terms of the living standards of every Australian, and it is about time that the people who sit on the Democrat benches thought about the future of this country in terms of the living standards of ordinary Australian people. The Democrats' approach on these sorts of matters is just condemning Australian families, in particular, to ever-declining standards of living.

SPEECH.PARA: They are the sorts of problems that I believe we are facing. The Economic Action Plan of the coalition is designed, not just in the measures that I have outlined today but in the whole gamut of economic reform, to address those issues. The sooner the Australian people are given the chance to give us the opportunity to do that, the better.

TALK.START.PARA: —I realise that I am not on the list of speakers, but I just want to say a few words about the third Bill in this trilogy, the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1989. I do agree with the previous three speakers, Senator Michael Baume, Senator Jim Short and Senator John Stone. I know it is a mixed metaphor, but it is becoming increasingly obvious that the ship of state is running off the rails.

SPEECH.PARA: The Medicare Levy Amendment Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives on 6 October and debated, if it could be called that, on 24 October. The Bill itself is simple enough. All it does is fix the levy at 1.25 per cent of taxable income and it raises the threshold below which people will not be levied for Medicare. However, the Opposition's amendment itself was substantive. I note from Hansard of 25 October at page 1854 that when it was brought into the House the debate took up a well-spaced half of one column. The record indicates that the debate was resumed from 6 September, on motion by Mr Peter Morris that the Bill be now read a second time. Mr Shack moved:
That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
``whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1) expresses its concern that despite its increasing cost Medicare is delivering a lower level of health care, particularly to the poor and needy;
(2) condemns changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which will rob the community of high quality pharmaceutical services;

Mr McGauran seconded the amendment. The next line states, `Amendment negatived'. The original question was resolved in the affirmative and the Bill was read a second time. That is the most cavalier treatment of legislation that one could imagine. It is happening with increasing frequency in the House of Representatives. It is leading to a deluge of legislation that is being rammed through the House over there and piling up here in the Senate. It is a virtual rape of the democratic process. That is the reason why this Senate is so busy and has to sit for so long. It is also the reason why all our committees are saturated with Bills that have to be examined. A lot of the legislation is ill-prepared and is likely to have unintended consequences, as we have seen in the past. At the moment the Senate has a select committee inquiring into medical insurance. That is an enormous job. It will probably take until next March to conclude that inquiry. In the meantime, Medicare marches on.

Although this Medicare Levy Amendment Bill will be welcomed by people in the lower income brackets, it certainly will not do anything to help Medicare. In fact, it will be a hindrance to it because at the moment the levy does not cover the cost of Medicare. So the Bill will not help Medicare but it will help a few people. I am concerned about the treatment that such Bills are receiving in the House of Representatives. They are obviously not allowing any debate on amendments. All the Opposition can do is table its amendments, and then the Bill gets rammed through the House.

We are not moving that particular amendment in the Senate that the Opposition moved in the other place. The Democrats, I note, have an amendment which picks up the central point of our amendment and, as I understand it, the Opposition will support the Democrats' amendment in relation to the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I wish to move an amendment to the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1989, which has been circulated to all honourable senators. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 4, clause 4, after proposed subsection 221ec (9), add the following new sub-section:
`` `(10) This section does not apply to:
(a) a public hospital;
(b) a public benevolent institution;
(c) a public university.''.

Speaking to that amendment, I point out the rationale for the inclusion of clause 221ec in the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill. The first part of this Bill deals with group employers who have group remittances totalling $5m or more in a financial year. Applying Mr Keating's rationale that these people pay their group tax twice monthly rather than once monthly, as is currently the case, he said that it is wrong that public funds should be used by companies or other organisations for company or private purposes.

The Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, has always been very strong on adopting a consistent rationale or logic in pursuing legislation and legislative claims in this House. We wish to take up that assertion. In doing so, we acknowledge in our amendment that the organisations named in our amendment use public funds for public and community purposes. By applying that logic, it is only reasonable that the Government should agree with us and the Australian Democrats, who are joining with us in this amendment, by voting for this reasonable amendment.

A number of organisations and people, not surprisingly, have said to us that we should extend it to, say, private hospitals, which are non-profit making organisations, or maybe to local government and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, which is a public body. But to do so would be to depart from this strict rationale or criterion which we are told is the logic or purpose behind the legislation in the first place. Therefore, it is only reasonable that the Government, applying its own logic and criteria, should agree to this amendment.

If the Government fails to acknowledge this amendment to a machinery Bill that does no more than rearrange the collection of the money-and the Government is treating it as a taxing Bill-it would be quite abhorrent, because the Government would be using a backdoor approach. The Government acknowledges that, as a result of these new arrangements, there is an interest saving of $20m per annum. We acknowledge that sometimes in a rearrangement these sorts of situations can occur. But at the same time, if one applies purely strict logic, as Senator Cooney and all other people who use logic and reason would have to apply in a consistent approach to the reason for the legislation in the first place-and we do not walk away from that approach but would ask the Government to acknowledge that in these amendments-we believe that it is unreasonable, unfair, unjust and in fact preposterous not to include public hospitals. After all, there are about 70 public hospitals all around Australia. There are not many benevolent institutions, so the Government is not going to lose much money there because they will not be big enough. It is only the big institutions and universities, is it not, because they gain Commonwealth moneys for public purposes? I think it is very difficult for the Government to deny these worthy institutions-applying its logic to the reason for the Bill in the first place-and not support this amendment.

Unfortunately, I hoped that we might have had a bit more time to persuade the Government. I think the Government is likely to give a knee-jerk reaction and say, `No, we will oppose the amendment'. In opposing the amendment, the legislation will go down to the other House and will then come back again. It is not a taxing measure. We are not taking money away because, as I mentioned, it is a machinery Bill; it is just rearranging the collection of tax. It has an indirect effect. If the Government is using this measure as a taxing Bill, then it is a disgrace. It is morally wrong and outrageous to use the back-door methods that it will be attempting to apply to get extra revenue from public hospitals and public universities which, according to its logic, the Government should not be doing.

I now wish to draw the Committee's attention to a second feature. Unfortunately, this second feature does cross the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill. It concerns me that in the financial impact statement-and we have one financial impact statement for the package of Bills, although at the present time we are debating them in the committee stage separately-there is a lack of consistency in the criteria that are being applied to that financial impact statement. I seek the indulgence of the Committee, therefore, to draw comparisons between the application of financial impact criteria in this Bill and the other two Bills which were a part of a cognate debate. In this package of Bills, inconsistency and a lack of standards apply to the presentation of the financial impact statement in relation to the legislation before the Senate.

I am grateful for a briefing that I received from my friend and colleague in the other House Mr Allan Rocher, the honourable member for Curtin. He has been pursuing this matter for quite some time. In pointing out the different criteria which apply to the financial impact statement, I address first the issues in the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill. The financial impact statement, for the year 1989-90 the gain to revenue, as a result of the introduction of these twice-monthly pay as you earn remittances, is $550m. This will enable a $20m reduction in public debt. When we pursue the next part of this section, which deals with the changes to payment of provisional taxes, we are not given an estimate of how much less revenue will ensue. It will be less because we are told that the public debt interest for 1989 will as a result increase by $20m. If we express this in commercial terms, the effects of the first two changes to the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill, which is the Bill currently before us, will be in the first case an additional $500m principal, accompanied by a saving of $20m interest, and in the second case, where we are not told the amount of principal although principal there must be, interest on that unknown amount will be an additional $20m. So there is a lack of logic there.

When we come to the second Bill, we note that the financial impact statement sets out a reduction of $160m in revenue anticipated as a result of the uplift factor. One might recall that the uplift factor has been dropped to 10 per cent. In my speech during the second reading stage I said that I thought there was a better case for that uplift factor being no more than the projected or budgeted current rate of inflation. But that is not the point. In relation to this provisional tax figure for 1989-90, no public debt interest figure is given. The third measure in this package of Bills will have a notable financial impact. By reducing the amount to be added on to the assessable income of taxpayers subjected to provisional tax to 10 per cent from the present 11 per cent or 12 per cent, the explanatory memorandum stipulates only an estimated reduction in revenue to be collected of some $160m.

In summary, in the first case, the effect on public debt interest is given; in the second case the effect on revenue and public debt interest is given; and in third case only the effect on revenue is given. Therefore, even though we are dealing with a package of Bills which have a common theme, we are looking at different criteria and providing different information to the taxpayers and the Senate. This is unfortunate as it could be quite misleading. If we continue to do this, I submit that the financial impact statements are not having their intended meaning. Instead of providing useful and meaningful information, we are providing misleading information because we do not have a standard by which to present the same criteria. This is unfortunate.

I wish to draw attention to another aspect in this committee stage. The Opposition finds it is very difficult to support legislation which is drawn up in such a loose fashion; in other words, legislation is not drawn as tightly as it should be. If this legislation is passed-and it will be passed, with the amendment I have proposed, thereby excluding public hospitals, public benevolent institutions and public universities-companies will nevertheless be able to drive a chariot through the thin fabric of this legislation. Companies will pay their people, not on or before the fourteenth of the month, because under the legislation payment has to be remitted within seven days, but on the fifteenth of the month. Therefore the companies will be given 22 days in which to pay. Some companies will be caught up in the mesh but the more astute ones will rearrange their payments in such a way as to avoid much of the so-called savings that this Government intends to make.

This legislation could have been drawn much more tightly to overcome that situation. If something must be done, the Government should propose income tax legislation that is so complex that nobody can understand it, but legislation that is going to hold up. It should not allow the astute and clever boys, the people with the good accountants, to be able to get around it while others get caught. I hope that the Government will think about this further. I think that it might come back, in the not too distant future, with some amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to state again, as we did in the second reading stage of the debate, that the Australian Democrats are convinced by the arguments that Senator Watson has advanced in relation to these three specific amendments to clause 4 of the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1989. We will support those amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has listened very carefully to Senator Watson's proposal, but it is not really persuaded of the desirability to accept the amendments. In general, I think it is understood that the money deducted from the salary or wages of an employee obviously is not money belonging to the employer. I am sure that Senator Watson would agree with that. The employer could be said to be in the position of a trustee holding the employee's money in order to ensure that the Commonwealth gets its money. In a sense, it is the employee's money in transit to the Commonwealth, whose money it is, because the tax has been levied.
—We don't dispute that. That is not the point.

—I think it is the point. The real point is that the money at issue could probably be properly characterised as the Commonwealth's money. It is the employee's money being held by the employer on the way to the Commonwealth. It is the tax that is due to the Commonwealth under the laws passed by this Parliament. I understood Senator Watson to be saying that, since most of these institutions are recipients of Commonwealth funding, why do we not take advantage of the fact that they can use the moneys that they are holding on behalf of their employees and make a few dollars by way of a few short term investments or something like that? The argument is that this will help those good institutions, be they universities, hospitals or some other public institution.

SPEECH.PARA: I think Senator Stone would agree that if the Commonwealth is to make money available to public institutions such as hospitals, universities or whatever, it should be very much up front; it should be easily identified by the community. It should be well understood that the Commonwealth is making $200,000 more per year available, for instance, to the University of Tasmania, to a public hospital in Perth, or whatever it may be. There should not be this sort of indirect means of Commonwealth funding which Senator Watson seems to be suggesting should continue to be countenanced, whereby these institutions can hold funds for a period which would allow them to invest and, therefore, as I understand it, either have some extra money made available to them or, at the very least, reduce the necessity for the Commonwealth to provide direct funding to help that institution undertake a particular expenditure.

I do not think that is good public policy. I am sure that when Senator Stone puts the National Party's point of view he will make it clear that he does not think that that is good public policy. It should not be done indirectly in this way. The money should be paid to the Commonwealth. If the Commonwealth deems fit, in full public view and open to public scrutiny, it should make those moneys available to the public institutions concerned. That is why I do not find Senator Watson's argument as convincing as, apparently, the Australian Democrats have at first blush. I think that when they read the Hansard record of my remarks over the next few weeks if the legislation returns to this place, they may think that my refutation has some merit.

The other matter raised by Senator Watson was a bit more technical. I hope he will excuse me if I read a comment that has been provided by the advisers. They say: concerning the quarterly provisional tax, this change does not have an effect on the Budget revenue for the year. Provisional tax money is collected in the same year of income. Instead of being collected by four instalments, the provisional tax payable is collected in a lump sum. The collection occurs in the same income year. The public debt interest cost occurs because of the timing of the collection-a lump sum in April-June, instead of payments in August, November, February or April. I pass that to Senator Watson for his consideration. As I say, it is a technical matter which I cannot argue very convincingly, but I hope that it is of some assistance to the Committee.
