TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say something in response to Senator Tate's comments regarding what might, in normal circumstances, be thought to be an appropriate manner of structuring Commonwealth accounts. Ordinarily, I would be inclined to agree with him, when one has to choose between providing finances to, in this case, public hospitals or public universities by a specific appropriation up front-I think those were the words used by Senator Tate-in the Budget. Therefore, it is discernible when one examines the outlays side of the Budget, and, in a sense, it is accountable. I think that was the core of his point.

SPEECH.PARA: I would, in general circumstances, tend to agree with that view, as distinct from the process of providing some hidden subsidy or, in this case, what might be called a tax expenditure form of financial assistance to the bodies concerned. I think that we should note that what we are dealing with is not a generality of that kind. We are dealing here with a specific piece of gimmickry by the Federal Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the 1989-90 Budget. In order to make the Budget figuring look better, in order to make it appear that he was after all tightening fiscal policy by increasing the size of the surplus, at the last moment the Treasurer has brought into the Budget a couple of major gimmicks, one of which is the matter we are discussing in the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1989, namely, the decision to require what one might loosely call large employers-that is, employers with a pay as you earn deduction payroll amounting to more than $5m per annum-to remit to the Commissioner of Taxation payments twice-monthly rather than once-monthly. As the financial impact provisions of the explanatory memorandum spell out, and indeed as the Budget spells out, this will bring in $550m this financial year. The financial impact statement quite rightly describes it thus:
This gain is in the form of a one off bring forward of revenue.

In other words, as I said before, it is a piece of gimmickry, designed to make the Treasurer's Budget for this year look fiscally more responsible than it is. That is the situation that we are dealing with today. I hope that the Minister does not get up in this place and quote to me general statements of fiscal principle about how a government should present its accounts, when what we are dealing with is a piece of non-principled fiscal policy from the Treasurer of this country, who once again this week has demonstrated his total lack of principle with his infamous behaviour in the House of Representatives in bringing forward charges which he cannot substantiate and which indeed he knows cannot be correct.

In the instance in question concerning the charges over the manner in which the Opposition came to formulate its capital gains tax policy, the Treasurer knows, because it is a matter of public record, that the decisions in question had been not only taken but also publicly announced 12 months before the share dealings which he alleges to have been the basis for those decisions were even contemplated. Yet we have a Minister in this place standing up and asking us to affirm our views of principle about how a government should structure its accounts-when we are dealing with a government which in this area is led by a Treasurer who only this week has demonstrated his total lack of principle and who has not yet had the courage to get up in the House of Representatives and apologise, as any man would do.

I make no bones about saying to the Senate that I feel deeply about that, having served for 30 years Treasurers of this country of various political persuasions who all had their good points and their bad points; and I do not recall that any one of them, from either side of politics, would have behaved as Mr Keating has behaved this week. I can assure the Government that this is not the last it will hear of this matter.

As to the Bill, I simply want to say that, for the reasons I have stated, we are not dealing with what one might normally call a question of principle about the presentation of the Government's accounts; we are dealing with a piece of gimmickry by the Treasurer. Unfortunately, this piece of gimmickry will this year have the unfortunate result-no doubt another one of those unintended consequences for which this Government has become notorious-of impacting in a strongly adverse manner upon the finances of a number of bodies, details of which Senator Watson has quite rightly brought to our attention: in particular, public hospitals, public universities and, indeed more generally, public benevolent institutions. Perhaps not many institutions in the last category will fall within the $5m criterion but, nevertheless, the Opposition considered it wisest to include that category also on the assumption that some might.

I simply say to the Minister that, notwithstanding in the general sense the quite proper point which he made and which in other circumstances one would probably not want to contest, the Opposition believes that there is a real problem here. Since this is a one-off matter we believe that the matter should be addressed. I note the Minister's statement that the Government will not accept the amendment. However, I hope that the Government will reconsider the matter before the Bill comes back from the other place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must despair at the quality of the advice that has been given to the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), because the Minister, as a highly principled man, would on reflection know that the majority, if not all, of the public hospitals operate under what are known as deficit financing arrangements-that is, they are always in the red, with funding from government being in arrears rather than in advance, and that they are therefore faced with making interest payments on that overdraft at interest rates currently between 20.25 per cent and 24.75 per cent. I say this in all good faith because I think on reflection the Minister would realise that they operate thus-but the Minister is telling the chamber that these organisations are investing this group money for their benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole effect would be to reduce the interest payments, if they are operating under deficit financing. With respect, I ask the Minister to give some further consideration to this matter. I do not ask the Minister to withdraw the measure, but I think that as a principled man he would realise that these public hospitals, perhaps about 70 of them around Australia, actually do operate under this deficit financing arrangement, which requires overdraft accommodation. They are public institutions serving the community and they do follow that rationale.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I formally table amendments to the Privacy Amendment Bill. These amendments are the result of consultations with the credit reporting industry and consumer and privacy groups. They are also the result of peak representative groups sitting down with the Government to fine tune the Bill so that a statutory framework of regulation could be developed for the industry which protects individuals' privacy and, at the same time, permits legitimate commercial practices in relation to credit information handling. These amendments have been discussed since June and were made available to the Opposition parties and to the public formally on 5 October.

SPEECH.PARA: Before moving to some brief comments on the more significant amendments proposed, I must say that we should not forget why the Bill was originally introduced back in June. Its prime purpose was to prevent the development by the credit industry of a system of credit reporting called positive reporting. The industry had announced that it would be introducing that system this year. It was incumbent on the Government to move speedily to clarify its policy position in relation to positive reporting.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were not going to move. They said they were not going to move. You went to the conference I went to.

—The industry said that it would, and after discussion we got it to defer. It deferred until next January in fact. The Government did not want the industry making an unnecessary capital investment. The introduction of the Bill clarified that position. I consider that the term `positive reporting' is misleading. I prefer the term `personal profiling' because I consider that that really reflects the intrusion into individuals' lives which would have occurred if that system had been allowed to develop in Australia. As I stated in my second reading speech, the Government does not consider that there is any proven substantial benefit from the positive reporting proposals and that in view of the strong privacy concerns held by the community this massive expansion of the extent of information held about individuals should not be allowed to develop.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill has received considerable critical attention. The amendments which are to be moved will clarify aspects of the proposed regulatory scheme. In addition, I consider that the code of conduct to be developed by the Privacy Commissioner, in consultation with the credit industry and consumer groups, will provide a blueprint for the daily operations of industry practices for the handling of personal credit information.

A considerable number of the amendments are technical amendments which will clarify the rights of individuals and the duties imposed on credit providers and credit reporting agencies in relation to their responsibility for the proper handling of individuals' personal information. The classes of business that will be able to obtain access to a credit reporting agency under the Bill will be widened. Credit information will be able to be used to assist credit providers in combating serious credit infringements and in collecting debts. Commercial and consumer credit reports will be able to be cross-referenced by credit providers when making lending decisions. A number of other technical amendments will significantly lessen the regulatory burden placed on the central credit reporting database. I indicate that I have tabled the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are the amendments being circulated?
—They were circulated to Opposition members on 5 October and were circulated formally this morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a few words about the handling of the Privacy Amendment Bill because it has been handled as badly as any legislation in the eight years that I have been in this place. This morning the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) brought into the chamber wholesale amendments that changed the whole structure of the original Bill that he introduced. In effect, we just heard from him a second second reading speech to deal with the huge package of amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister was correct when he said that a copy of the amendments was forwarded to the Opposition last month, but the amendments were not available to individual senators who are interested in the matter until this morning. They were not available in the Table Office last night and, on inquiry, it was found that they had not yet been authorised by the Minister. I looked at them briefly this morning and they appear to be much the same as those circulated previously, with some small alterations, but obviously we need to assess them carefully.

In effect, the Minister has sought to merge two Bills into one Bill. We have had two second reading speeches, the second one having been given this morning in relation to the package of amendments. It will not therefore be surprising that the chamber is very much confused about what is occurring.

TALK.START.PARA: —As confused as the Minister.

—That is so. The original Bill was introduced without any consultation with the industry. It was believed to be politically opportune. There was a chance of winning some political points from some of the civil liberties organisations and the Government rushed in in an effort to gain what was therefore seen as a political advantage. It lodged its Bill in this place and then the industry pointed out to the Government how unworkable the whole scheme was and how it should have been given proper consideration in the first instance.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of that, the Government then went back to the industry, did what it should have done before introducing the Bill in the first instance, and then said, `Put us right'. In some instances, the industry has now put the Government right-as far as I could work out from this great package of amendments-and some of the changes are in accordance not only with the industry's wishes, but also with what we said should have been included within the original Bill. We will argue that it does not go as far as it should. It is now a mess. The proposed legislation should be withdrawn and the Government should sort out what it wants in the area of privacy and put into the chamber one Bill which covers the matters that it wishes to cover and which the chamber can then debate.

From glancing at the second explanatory memorandum, which relates to the Government's foreshadowed amendments, it seems to me that it is even longer than the first. That is not the way in which the Government should operate. It is not its function to introduce a second Bill, in effect, in the form of amendments at the committee stage. It does not allow for a proper debate by the Senate, which should be appalled at the way in which the Government has handled the matter. The Government could have expected a complex committee stage consideration of this matter; it will now be much more complicated and the new issues raised by the Government's amendments will have to be explored at that stage. The end result of poor handling such as we have seen exhibited today is that the debate will take longer. As I said, it becomes more confusing and it does no-one any good, least of all those seeking to follow the debate or who have a particular interest in the subject matter. An enormous number of people in business and industry, in particular, have an interest in what the Government is seeking to achieve by the proposed legislation.

The Bill-I refer principally to the first Bill, not the Government's amendments-deals with credit reference reporting. As I said, we find it unsatisfactory. We found it absolutely unsatisfactory in the first instance, we still believe it is unsatisfactory, and we will oppose it. As I indicated, there will be a comprehensive committee stage consideration when we will move extensive amendments to the Bill; in other words, if it gets a second reading in this place we will then do our best to put it into a satisfactory form.

To put the Bill in context, it is necessary for me to say something about the process of credit reporting with which the Bill deals. I will then explain in more specific terms our objections to the Bill as it is presently drawn. Credit reference reporting is the process of keeping information about the creditworthiness of individuals and businesses so that commercial enterprises may decide whether to give credit to them or have other commercial dealings with them. Banks and financial institutions, for example, regularly get a credit check on potential borrowers before lending the money. Firms that hire out vehicles and equipment check on potential hirers. Real estate agents, who do not seem to have been covered by the amendments foreshadowed, obtain checks on potential tenants. Sellers of goods and services make similar checks before they extend credit. Debt collectors use such services to locate missing debtors. Insurance companies use them to prevent fraud because, if an insured person is making a claim and is heavily in debt or has a long line of similar claims, the claim may be a fraudulent one and, at least, one that should be looked at closely.

Credit checking is so widespread that it is now a regular and essential ingredient in all commercial activities. I understand that about 98 per cent of credit reference reporting on individuals in Australia is done by a company known as the Credit Reference Association of Australia Ltd, CRAA. The CRAA is owned by its 4,800 members who are the major public utilities, banks, finance companies, department stores, credit unions, building societies, insurance companies, credit card companies and many manufacturing and trading companies. Credit reference reporting was originally done by manual means, keeping handwritten card indexes on customers. Over the years it has expanded to the extent that CRAA now operates a sophisticated computerised system in all States. Its database now holds records on over 10 million individuals and businesses. Its members make about seven million inquiries a year about people or businesses to whom they are thinking of extending credit or lending money. In October 1988, for example, 534,000 inquiries were made, an increase of 80 per cent since October 1984. I have demonstrated the very widespread industries and commercial undertakings in this country that are dependent upon the system, the very extensive use that is made of the system, and the fact that the use is increasing at a rapid rate.

I will say a few words about CRAA's method of operation because it becomes important when looked at in terms of the Government's Bill. The CRAA has gradually built up files on people and businesses to whom credit has been extended. The files, which are really print-outs, are based upon information sent in from CRAA members on defaults, public record information such as bankruptcy orders and judgments, company records and insurance claims. In addition, when members of the CRAA make inquiries about individual debtors, those inquiries are also recorded. From all of that information files are built up on credit customers so that, when a member comes to make an inquiry about a person to decide whether to lend money or to extend credit, that member has access to a lot of accumulated information. Access to that information enables CRAA members to make a more enlightened decision on whether or not a person is a good credit risk, which is really what the whole process is all about. The CRAA also makes the point that having access to that information enables the lender to make a decision in the best interests of the borrower. In other words, it can prevent a borrower getting too far into debt and, sometimes, into a situation in which the borrower will be unable to repay the debt. That is not only in the interests of the credit provider but also in the interests of the debtor.

Who may have access to the files is an important question that was raised in the public debate before the Bill was introduced. It was raised also in the nature of the draft legislation. Of course, members of the CRAA have access to the files. They effect that access by telephone calls to the CRAA, by computer-to-computer links and by personal computers using the telephone network. Most access these days is obtained by computer links rather than by telephone calls. The CRAA operator or the computer brings up the individual's file and provides the member with a copy of it. The member then has to make his own commercial judgment based on the information that is provided by the CRAA. Members who improperly use information on the files or who do not comply with the secrecy rules of the CRAA face expulsion.

Consumers who have been refused credit also have a right to access their own files, which is worth emphasising particularly. They have the right to access their own files free of charge to see what it is on their files that has led to credit being refused. Quite apart from that, any person on whom records are kept has access to his own file at any time. That access is given upon payment of a fee of $5 for a computer printout of one's own file.

The insurance information service that is also operated by the CRAA holds information on approximately three million insurance claims. Its function is to give insurers information about claims that have been made in the past together with other credit information, thereby reducing the possibility of fraudulent claims being made in the future. The CRAA maintains that access to that information prevents insurance premiums from rising, because fraud is a major component in the cost of insurance premiums.

The CRAA maintains that its security is good because it has strict limits on who may gain access to the database. It claims also to have good physical security over its operations and an extensive system of verification of the data that it holds. It also examines closely applicants for membership and monitors the way in which its members use the service. As I said a moment ago, the ultimate penalty for breaches is expulsion from the Association.

The issue of what information is on the files is also important. The CRAA has its own rules on the information that it keeps and the information that it will not keep. It keeps records only of financial matters that are relevant to the decision of whether to extend credit or relevant to other commercial decisions that its members have to make. It does not keep information on matters such as race; national origins; political, social or religious beliefs; lifestyle or sexual practices. It does not allow its information to be used for private investigation purposes or pre-employment checks, nor does it generate or sell direct mailing lists based on its information.

The Minister mentioned positive reporting as opposed to negative reporting as a justification for the urgency of the introduction of the Bill, which was totally misleading. It was made clear at that conference on this subject, which a number of senators attended, that this legislation would not be introduced without a thorough and widespread public debate and that it was in the interests of the industry to assess public attitude to the extension of the existing system to positive reporting.

The present system of credit reporting that is used by the CRAA is known as negative reporting because it shows bad credit records, that is, non-payment, rather than good or-in the jargon of this debate-positive payment records. As I said, some commercial organisations want to move to positive reporting, which will record all or most of a person's current financial commitments and will show the good news of regular payments. Its advocates claim that positive reporting is needed to balance a bad record payment and that it will improve the decisions of credit providers because they will be able to confirm promptly whether a credit applicant has the ability to meet his new commitments. To put it bluntly, some commercial and financial enterprises want the CRAA to keep records of all financial transactions by as many people as it can locate. Clearly, that would result in a new, vast databank on most Australians. Understandably, that gives rise to new concerns.

The debate on positive reporting in itself drew attention to the whole issue of credit reference reporting and to the privacy issues that it involves. Clearly, potential exists for personal privacy to be invaded if there is the possibility of extensive private financial information on citizens being stolen or improperly used. This concern led to a debate on privacy itself and, hence, to this Bill.

The answer to whether or not the Government will permit positive reporting is contained in the Bill, which does not allow positive reporting. The Minister made that clear as one of the objectives of the Bill. However, in the process the Government has decided to restrict even negative reporting; that is, the reporting systems that are currently in practice. Much of this debate and much of our concern has revolved around those restrictions.

At this stage it should be stated that it is common ground that some form of privacy legislation is needed. That is so partly because of increasing concerns about privacy. The credit reference industry would also welcome a clarification in the law as to what it can and cannot do. It seems that, if there is to be privacy legislation, one of two approaches can be used. The first approach is to set out a series of prohibitions to prohibit what are thought to be the undesirable aspects of credit reference reporting. That is the approach that the Government has taken. Not surprisingly, the Bill has become a hotchpotch of random prohibitions. The only consistent principle behind it is to prohibit much commercial access to credit reference reporting and to restrict very severely the reporting that is to be permitted.

As I said earlier, the Government has foreshadowed the introduction of a whole series of amendments, which will be debated in detail at a later stage. There is a vast gulf between the use of credit reports in the Bill in its original form-or what is permitted in its original form-what industry wants, and what is going to be the result after the adoption, presumably, by this chamber of the majority of the Government's foreshadowed amendments. As I said, this will be pursued. The issue of the uses of credit reference reporting to be allowed is one of the major factors of contention between the Opposition and the Government. In essence, the Opposition says that a much more liberal use of reporting should be permitted.

I said that I would discuss some of the defects in the Bill. The Bill is an attempt to provide rules on the information that a credit reference agency may keep on its files: how long the information may be kept; the accuracy and security; access to the files; alterations in incorrect information; disclosure of information in the files; the uses that may be made of the information; the penalties for including false or misleading information in files; a code of conduct for the detailed operation of the system; and enforcement via the Privacy Commissioner. However, in our view, when considered as a whole, the Bill is heavily slanted against business and commerce. It severely limits the use of credit reference reporting and prohibits, outright, some uses of the process that are clearly legitimate. The CRAA estimated, before the Government's amendments were announced, that over 90 per cent of its members would no longer be able to use its services. Even with the amendments that have been foreshadowed, many members of CRAA will not be able to use its services lawfully. Not surprisingly, therefore, many business members are still concerned about the Bill, even in its foreshadowed amended form.

The reality is, as I indicated, that the Bill was introduced with no consultation at all. The consultations that have taken place are still inadequate. The Bill, in the form in which it will be debated in the committee stage, is still inadequate. Just to give this chamber some idea of the extent to which industry is opposed to the Bill, even in its amended form, I seek leave to table a list of approximately 20 major organisations of the Credit Reporting Forum which are still expressing objections to the Bill.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the Credit Reporting Forum was established, many other organisations have joined it so that virtually the entire business community is now ranged against this proposed legislation. Their argument, supported by a financial impact report commissioned by the Business Planning Group, is that if the Bill is passed in its present form many companies will not be allowed to use credit reference reporting at all; others will be severely restricted in their use of it; the costs to business will escalate; insurance premiums and interest rates will rise; there will be overcommitment by debtors and borrowers and many socially disadvantaged people will be hurt as businesses will be forced to make subjective judgments instead of relying on reasonable, objective information supplied by credit reports. In the view of the Opposition there is considerable merit in the arguments that are being put forward by these business organisations, and our view remains firm notwithstanding the Government's foreshadowed amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not only the business community that is expressing concern. Firstly, as we have read in the press, a number of Ministers have been very concerned about the consequences of the Bill and, in particular, the cost that it will undoubtedly add to industry. Secondly, no doubt we have all read the views of the Australian Labor Party Minister for Consumer Affairs in Victoria, Mr Roper, who is opposed to the Bill. He particularly refers to the exclusion of insurance companies and real estate agents from credit information. Thirdly, we know that the Business Regulation Review Unit warned the Government about the danger and the cost of imposing more burdens and controls on business. Unfortunately, it seems those people have lost and the Labor Left has won.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are over a barrel now.

—That is the bottom line of what the Minister has put before us. I will now detail our major concerns a little more fully. The first concerns the meaning of `credit' and `credit provider'. The Bill provides that a credit reference agency may not-with exceptions which I will not deal with at the moment-disclose information on its file about a person unless it is disclosing it to a credit provider. `Credit' is defined as a loan, and then only as a loan for domestic, family or household purposes. We submit to the chamber that this is a major fault in the Bill. It follows that if the Bill is passed without amendment, CRAA would not be able to provide credit reference information to a real estate agent checking on the solvency of a tenant-I do not think that is even picked up in the amendments-to a company trying to collect a debt, because it would not be making a loan; to a creditor trying to locate a debtor; to a business selling goods on terms or credit, because it would not be making a loan but extending credit in the normal sense of the word; to an underwriter of a mortgage, because it would not be making a loan; to firms that hire out goods or equipment, because they would not be making a loan; to a credit provider to review an account because of slow payment or to advise him of the new address of a missing debtor. All of these uses of reporting are outlawed by the Bill in the first instance at least and, it seems to us, even after the amendments in a number of these cases.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the Opposition is concerned about insurance. The same limitation seriously damages the effectiveness of the large insurance service provided by CRAA. Insurance companies will be prohibited from checking on the credit default record of claimants because the insurance company, of course, will not be making a loan to the insured. This can only give rise to an increase in insurance fraud and a consequent increase in insurance premiums. It should be noted that the Government has not proposed any amendments to remove or limit the severe effect that the Bill will have on the insurance industry and the cost of insurance to the community as a whole.

Thirdly, in relation to debts, bad debts may be recorded on a file-in the Bill's initial form-only if the debt is 90 days overdue. I think that might have been reduced to 60 days in the foreshadowed amendments. Even so, the Bill severely restricts the type of default information that a credit reference agency may collect and keep, and we find that objectionable. In relation to business and personal credit, the Bill makes an unrealistic distinction between personal and domestic credit and business credit. The Bill first says that an agency may disclose information in a file only if it is to be used to assess an application for a domestic, family or household loan. Thus, access to personal credit reference files for business finance is, in effect, outlawed. The Opposition finds that very foolish.

In relation to privacy, it is ironic that, although the Government prides itself on furthering the cause of privacy, the Bill does not provide much protection for the citizen. Certainly it gives no more protection than is presently given. We will pursue that in the committee stage, particularly in relation to accuracy, security and matters of that nature. The Bill does not adequately reflect the information privacy principles as set out in the Privacy Act 1988-the Government's own legislation-and this is one of its principal defects. Concerning the use of information by credit providers, the Bill prevents credit providers from passing on news of actual defaults to other credit providers without the debtor's consent. Credit providers regard this restriction as obnoxious because it may not even be known where the debtor is in order to obtain his consent. The debtor may not give consent until after the default has occurred.

The Opposition says there is a better approach. The defects in this Bill so contaminate it that it should be withdrawn, redrafted, put to the industry and the community and looked at carefully. The Government should acknowledge that there is not the urgency it sought to imply there is to this chamber. The Government should take this Bill away and do the job properly. Instead of the approach adopted by the Government it would have done better to state clearly the principles on which any such legislation should be based, and fashion the Bill on those principles.

The two basic principles are that commercial organisations should generally have access to financial information that enables them to make sensible, commercial decisions; and that there should be a mechanism by which consumers are advised that commercial organisations have had access to this information about them, and there should be an opportunity for them to obtain redress for improper use of that information. This Bill, even in its foreshadowed amended form, does not measure up against either of those two principles.
On behalf of the Opposition I move the following amendment in relation to the motion for the second reading of the Bill:
Leave out all words after ``That'', insert ``the Senate declines to give this Bill a second reading as the Senate is of the opinion that the Bill:
(a) imposes excessive and unjustified prohibitions and restrictions on the collection and use of personal financial information;

(b) fails to provide that credit reference agencies be able to give commercial organisations reasonable access to appropriate financial information they have collected provided that the information is reasonably required by a commercial organisation to assist it in making commercial decisions;

(c) will place obstacles in the way of the detection of fraud, add to the cost of insurance, goods and services, increase interest rates and impose additional costs and inefficiencies on business, its customers and the community;

(d) falls short of the Information Privacy Principles contained in the Privacy Act 1988, particularly those principles designed to ensure that individuals are made aware that information concerning them has been disclosed;
(e) will have many unintended consequences to the detriment of consumers, credit providers, credit reference agencies and the community as a whole; and
(f) has been introduced without adequate consultation''.

The Opposition will seek to have that amendment carried, in which case the Bill will not be given a second reading in its current form, and the Government will have to take it away and draft a proper Bill. If we are unsuccessful in that, as I have indicated we will do our best in the committee stage to put the Bill in a form which we regard as satisfactory, consistent with the basic principles that I have outlined in this speech.

Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I thank the Senate for the leave to continue this process which I believe is vitally important.

SPEECH.PARA: The question arises, of course, of what avenues are open to ordinary Australians if they believe that they have been treated unjustly by their bank. The banks say, of course, that their doors are open and all that one needs to do is to present oneself to the officer who is responsible for disputes resolution within the branch, the State branch or even to the national headquarters of the bank. Of course, that begs the question. Inevitably there is bias because the referee represents one of the disputed parties. It is very seldom that matters of serious dispute are resolved in that way.

It has been argued in debates in this chamber that there is access to the courts and that if one is in serious dispute with banks one simply takes the matter to the court and it will be resolved in due course. The due course could be a decade, assuming that the person who is in dispute-the victim so to speak-is in a position to proceed to the courts anyway.

Most of these people are in dispute because they are financially destitute. They have been broken by the process that is in question. Not only have they have broken financially, but often they have been broken maritally, emotionally and domestically. They are confronted with the challenge of taking banks to courts. Banks, of course, have unlimited access to the best legal minds and unlimited resources and usually settle out of court if there is anything of conjecture. But they do this right at the last minute; often years after the process of disputation began.

If one loses in the courts, of course one has the right of appeal. Some very courageous people have over a period of five or six years actually carried their appeals right to the highest court of the country. But it takes a very special person to do that. It needs very special and very costly advice to do that successfully. One could take the matter to a senator or to a member of parliament who may in fact pursue it on one's behalf. In fact, many of the people whose affidavits I have tabled in the last 12 months have come to me after having approached other senators or members. I may have been the fourth, fifth or sixth person they had spoken to. However, these members of parliament, because of the position taken by their parties in relation to a bank's dispute, have not been able to represent them. I have brought these disputes into this chamber only to find that there is not sufficient moral courage here to challenge the banks, the most powerful institutions in the land. Of course, these attempts to have these matters dealt with in the Parliament of the land have failed also. But, of course, one can continue with those attempts.

The banks are putting in place a new procedure whereby, theoretically, people can take their disputes to a bank ombudsman. On first appearances, it would seem that this process is a sound one. I believe that Australians should take it at face value, subject it to a very hard test and challenge its efficiency, viability and credibility. Already, quite serious reservations have been expressed concerning the role and terms of reference of the bank ombudsman and I have conveyed them in this place on behalf of those who hold them. The first and obvious reservation is whether this is a case of banks looking at banks. Certainly, the ombudsman will be in the employ of the Australian Bank Council, which is funded by the major banks and, therefore, he is employed by the banking industry in this country.

There is an old adage that he who pays the piper calls the tune. I suppose the wisdom of that adage has been acknowledged over the centuries and it may well be that that observation could possibly be valid in the case of this process. A valid observation has been made that under his terms of reference the bank ombudsman will focus on petty cash issues and that the sums in dispute that can be resolved or compensated will be relatively small. The upper limit is $100,000. That sounds a lot of money but of the now almost 60 cases that I have tabled in the Senate-and they are only 60 out of hundreds-very few involve disputed sums of less than $100,000. So a disputant who goes to the ombudsman, obtains a successful ruling and attains compensation of $100,000 will perhaps have to pursue the excess of the disputed sum in the court context once again. So, really all that happens is that there is a partial resolution of dispute and the person has to go before the courts again, with all of the limitations that that involves.

It is interesting that there have already been indications that the bank ombudsman, when he or she takes up that position, will not consider any cases that are retrospective. In other words, it is now being hinted that anybody who is now in dispute with the banks will not be able to take his case before the bank ombudsman. As a result, the assurances that I have given to people that I will immediately put before the bank ombudsman cases that I have already tabled in this Senate may be truncated. These people, who are in genuine dispute-they are just as seriously in dispute as anybody who is in this position with the banks on day one of the ombudsman being positioned-may, in fact, be denied access. In other words, those who have contributed to the build-up of evidence which partially has created this process will be denied access to the referee.

There are those cynics-and I must admit that I am fast becoming one of them-who see this exercise as being essentially a public relations one by the banks. After all, it is costing them $2m a year to put this process in place. Of course, that is absolute chicken feed alongside the billions of dollars of profit that are enjoyed annually by the four major banks. So it remains to be seen how credible and how viable the bank ombudsman procedure proves to be.

I have asked to be the first to appear before the bank ombudsman. It is my intention to table all of the affidavits that I have tabled in the Senate, place them before the bank ombudsman and say, `There is your first year's work, perhaps'. I am now beginning to feel that perhaps they will be pushed back across the table at me and that I will be told, `We are not interested in those because we are starting with a clean sheet as from today'. So, perhaps the credibility of the so-called procedure to obtain justice from greedy banks in this country may virtually, on day one, be legitimately challenged. This remains to be seen.

I suppose that raises in the minds of Australians, who quite clearly see the whole issue of banking in this country as being one of grave concern, the question of `Where do we go to now?'. If people have been unsuccessful before the court and in their approaches to the Parliament, the Government and the newly appointed bank ombudsman, I think this quite legitimately raises in the minds of Australians affected by greedy banks-and that is all of us-the question as to how do we really, in fact, challenge the almighty power of these extraordinary institutions.

My concerns have been recently described as obsessive. I do not think they are obsessive at all; they are just a commitment to a task which I am prepared to carry through. If people wish to say that in some way that is obsessive, there is no way in fact that I can do anything about that. But I am fairly convinced that most Australians are certain that at least one person in this place is committed to this task. I reserve the right, perhaps week after week, to continue this process of tabling affidavits and continuing to present what I consider to be credible evidence, provided to me by concerned Australians, that there is a real need to bring the banks of this nation to heel.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak about a matter that was addressed by Senator Cooney in this chamber on 5 September last. In a fairly measured presentation, Senator Cooney nonetheless managed to misstate several matters which need to be corrected. I have no doubt that he was encouraged to make his remarks by some mischievous and misleading statements by Wally Curran of the Meat Industry Employees Union, Mr Curran having worked himself into a lather about certain employment practices relating to the Thomas Borthwick and Sons (Australasia) Ltd meat abattoirs at Portland. The matter for principal concern has been that Borthwicks are in the business of seeking to re-engage workers who will not apply the same outrageous restrictive work practices that have been in place for many years. In so doing, it has been the practice of this firm to require applicants to undergo medical examinations in order to test their physical capacity for work.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the complaints that have been made by Senator Cooney and others is that it is somehow outrageous for the employer to be able to determine the doctor of choice and that, in any event, it is even more grievous because these examinations are paid for by the public purse via Medicare. The first factual inaccuracy I think is the following proposition stated by Senator Cooney:
The candidates were told to use their Medicare entitlements. This caused concern because the Medicare scheme is not intended for the purpose to which it was put.

The first matter that needs to be corrected is this: that somehow all applicants for new employment positions are entitled to Medicare cover. That is simply not correct. The provisions of the Health Insurance Act make it clear that a ministerial direction has been issued in respect of certain categories of health screening services to enable Medicare benefits to be payable for in this case, a medical examination provided to an unemployed person at the request of a person to whom the unemployed person has applied for employment.

If Senator Cooney has any criticism, it ought to be directed at the Government for issuing those ministerial directions. The fact, of course, is that it is highly desirable that the Government, via Medicare, should subsidise the employer's cost of conducting examinations for unemployed persons. If a person is in another job and applies for a position, the cost of that is not borne by Medicare and quite properly so. But I do not think that point was appreciated by Senator Cooney or, indeed, Wally Curran, if he ever understood what the issue was. But, in relation to unemployed persons, I do not have any doubt that the policy rationale for Medicare picking up the tab is the Government's concern to help the unemployed get jobs by defraying the costs to employers of pre-employment medical examinations. That, I think, is not only reasonable but also highly desirable because otherwise employers would be inclined to give preference to others or would not be inclined perhaps to give unemployed persons quite the same consideration that is available under this scheme.

The suggestion that somehow people are forced to use Medicare entitlement is simply not so. It is clear from what I have detailed to the Senate that this is all according to the Act and the practice as provided for by ministerial directions. On that basis, there is no element of compulsion. I find it passing strange that there can be complaints that somehow it is wrong for employers not to disclose the contents of medical reports. That is, as we would all know, a time honoured practice. There is a privilege that attaches to such examinations. Quite clearly, the purpose of the exercise is to enable the employer to make a sensible and proper judgment on the basis of expert medical advice.

Senator Cooney managed to give an example of one investigation which he says showed that the original diagnosis had been wrong. I suppose no doctor is infallible and, to the extent that there are errors, they do need to be corrected. But it is overwhelmingly not the case and I would have thought it is certainly not sufficient justification for questioning the system. Therefore, I wanted to take issue with Senator Cooney's assessment of the situation, particularly in relation to the Borthwick plant which has been controlled by Elders IXL Ltd for quite some time.
Senator Cooney's final remarks were:

A situation has been created where people looking for work must use Medicare to pay for a report from the single doctor to whom the company sends them. This fits awkwardly with the concept of a caring employer.

I think that is a fairly cheap and nasty parting shot because it does not do justice to the situation. Clearly, this employer is like any other employer seeking to have a medical examination of an applicant conducted. Therefore, I think the sting in Senator Cooney's remarks was misguided. Certainly, I commend his restraint in not indulging in the sort of vitriolic abuse that Mr Curran used about those that he believes are in control of the plant. Nonetheless, I do think that, to the extent that Senator Cooney was under a misapprehension about the reason why employers' costs are Medicare funded, he was also in error. I trust that the matter will be suitably rectified at local level. I note that one of the leading orthopaedic specialists in Portland attempted to have the matter corrected by the Warrnambool Standard but as at 8 September the letter had not been published. DEBATE.TITLE: CRIMES (SUPERANNUATION BENEFITS) BILL 1989AUSTRALIAN FEDERAL POLICE AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 October, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal first with the Crimes (Superannuation Benefits) Bill 1989. In recent times, it has become all too obvious that it is possible to be too complacent about the possibility of corruption in the public sector, whether it be government officials, the judiciary, politicians and police alike. This Bill is proposed as a weapon in the fight against corruption. Its purpose is to prevent the payment of Commonwealth funded superannuation benefits to any Commonwealth employee who is convicted of a corruption offence. Not only will payment of such benefits be prevented but benefits which have already been paid may be recovered in the event of subsequent conviction of a corruption offence committed during the term of Commonwealth employment. The employee contribution and the interest accrued on it would not be affected.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation will come into operation where a Commonwealth employee is convicted of a corruption offence punishable by imprisonment for at least 12 months. `Conviction' is broadly defined to include circumstances where a person has been summarily convicted, convicted on indictment or has absconded. A `corruption offence' is defined as one involving abuse of office committed for a purpose involving corruption, or to pervert the course of justice. The proposed legislation will apply to all employees of the Commonwealth and its authorities as well as members of parliament, judges and Defence Force personnel. Therefore, this is an important Bill, which might not necessarily be evident by the interest in the debate today.

The court will have power to make superannuation orders preventing the payment of the Commonwealth contribution, recovery orders where the contribution has already been paid and restraining orders to prevent the disposal of property which may be needed to ensure the recovery of an amount owing to the Commonwealth. So we recognise that the powers are significant. For the purposes of recovery of property, the Bill includes a provision similar to that of section 120 of the Bankruptcy Act 1966. The definition of property in the Act we note to be extremely broad and covers property in which the person has a beneficial interest and any gifts made within the two years preceding the date of the charge or the restraining order.

The Bill also, we have observed, contains provisions similar to sections 9 and 9a of the Proceeds of Crime Act to prevent people trying to escape the effects of the legislation by taking property out of the country, giving it to another person or dealing with it in such a way as to diminish its value. Pursuant to these provisions, the court will also be able to pierce the corporate veil to get at property subject to the effective control of a person. The legislation will only apply to convictions recorded after it comes into force.

We note that the Act will work as follows: the police will notify the Minister when they charge an employee with what they think may be a corruption offence. They then notify the Minister as to the outcome of the charge. If the Minister thinks it is a corruption offence, he or she may tell the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) to apply to a court for a superannuation order. If the person absconds, or is sentenced to a period of imprisonment of more than 12 months, the DPP must make an application for a superannuation order. If the court is satisfied that the person was convicted of a corruption offence or has absconded, the court must then make a superannuation order. Employee contributions that have been paid into a fund are returned to the employee. As in the case of recovery orders, the court calculates the amount to be paid. As of the day the order is made, the amount payable by a person is a debt to the Commonwealth.

The DPP may apply for a restraining order against specific property of the defendant or another person where a person who has received superannuation benefits from the Commonwealth may be the subject of a recovery order. The purpose of a restraining order is to ensure recovery of the amount payable. Property which is under the effective control of the defendant can be the subject of a restraining order. Pursuant to clause 35, it will be an offence knowingly to deal with property in contravention of a restraining order. The provisions relating to the restraining orders generally mirror those, again, of the Proceeds of Crime Act. Under clause 40, the court may treat any property under the effective control of the defendant as his or her property.

When sentencing a person for a corruption offence, the court must not take into account any possible superannuation order. It cannot take that into account in determining the quantum of the penalty. It is in our view important to note that the forfeiture of superannuation rights and benefits under this proposed legislation is a separate question from that of any other penalties under the criminal law, or other legislation such as the Proceeds of Crime Act, that a corruption offence may attract.

The Australian Federal Police Amendment Bill 1989 is the companion Bill to the Crimes (Superannuation Benefits) Bill 1989. I remind the Senate that in the last session the Australian Federal Police Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 was passed. It provided for the recovery of superannuation benefits paid to officers of the Australian Federal Police. At the time, we in the Opposition pointed out that there was a large loophole in the legislation of which corrupt officers may have been able to take advantage. In essence, a corrupt officer could have resigned, collected the superannuation owing to him or her and then disposed of it, for example, by giving it to a relative. This Bill closes the loophole that we brought to the attention of the Government by introducing the concept of effective control so that when a recovery order is made it is not only applied to property in the officer's physical possession. Similarly, when a court makes a restraining order it may be made against the defendant or another person.

Mr Deputy President, we support this legislation. We think it will be a useful tool in the fight against corruption which, as I said, we have become only all too much aware of in recent times and we commend the Government on its introduction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Crimes (Superannuation Benefits) Bill 1989 and the Australian Federal Police Amendment Bill 1989 deal with an essential item from the Government's viewpoint in terms of the fight against crime. The Australian Democrats do not cavil with the Government over the increased penalties, as it were, for corrupt public officers. There are not only penalties for whatever crime is committed and penalties relating to the proceeds of crime but also it is now proposed to take away from corrupt officials their superannuation benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to point to one problem that I think is emerging in this move. As honourable senators well know, many judgments that have been given over recent years in the Family Court of Australia actually are based on the claim of a spouse of a superannuant to part, and sometimes all, of a superannuation benefit. The moral right of a spouse to part of that superannuation benefit is strengthened, particularly in light of the productivity trade-off exercise in the last 12 months whereby 4 per cent of salary is now paid to many workers by way of a productivity superannuation bonus arrangement. In other words, quite directly the Government has recognised in its own industrial relations and wage policy area a direct link between salary and superannuation.

As the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), who is at the table, well knows, it is a standing rule now in terms of the Family Court that where only one wage earner in a family unit has paid for an asset such as a home, that asset is part of the package for distribution between the spouses. In other words, assets are not considered by the Family Court as being owned wholly and solely by the person who earned that salary that paid for them. That is perfectly correct. It is a recognition that in a partnership of marriage each spouse is entitled, in terms of whatever the agreement is between the couple, to a fair share of the accumulated assets of which superannuation is morally a part and of which court judgments in the Family Court have declared it to be a part.

I admit that at the moment there is not an overall legal entitlement to that. I believe that in terms of development in this area of the distribution of assets and who actually owns assets within a marriage contract, in a very short time indeed superannuation will be seen as an accepted part of that whole arrangement-not as peripheral to it but as an essential part of it. The difficulty then that I see with these two pieces of legislation is that we are assuming totally the opposite viewpoint, that the superannuation is totally and completely owned by the person who has the superannuation arrangement. As I say, the Government in its own industrial relations and wages policy has espoused the opposite view. It has espoused the opposite view in the Family Court. Yet this legislation is really in contradistinction to that movement.

I am afraid that I am not able to offer many constructive views on how one might resolve that dilemma. How we might disentangle the various entitlements is a difficult problem. But it seems to me that if the spouse of a corrupt police officer-and I use that example in terms of one of the Bills before us-has not committed a crime, if it is not able to be proven in court that there was collusion between the couple and if the partner who was not the serving officer was not an accessory either before or after a crime and, in other words, is innocent, I think what we are doing is visiting a direct penalty on the spouse. That does not seem to me to be a good principle to enshrine in law.

The children also have to be considered. When one thinks of the other types of penalties that will be visited upon a corrupt officer in those circumstances, it could very well be that the family structure itself will almost be reduced to penury. On top of that, we will be depriving the spouse and children of their moral right to part of that superannuation. I do not press this matter any further in terms of a legal right, because there is not any at the moment. I think the family could be said to have already suffered a vast penalty because of the actions of the corrupt officer. To visit upon them yet another penalty is a very harsh exercise indeed.

I acknowledge that it could be a very effective penalty. But, then again, I think most exercises where one visits a penalty on a spouse or children tend to be fairly effective in the eyes of the other spouse. This sort of thing was used during the Second World War with regard to torture. I accept the point that effectiveness in terms of the fight against crime will certainly be enhanced because it will affect an officer's family. However, I do not accept that the effectiveness of this area is an argument in its favour.

I think the Government really ought to review the situation. I can express on behalf of my party support for the current legislation because, as I say, that legal entitlement is not enshrined elsewhere in legislation. But I would hope that the Government in terms of developing an overall policy position with regard to the ownership of superannuation benefits will bear this element in mind. I hope that it will not simply put it to one side on the basis that this is an effective way of fighting crime and ignore the moral and legitimate rights to those benefits of the spouses and children involved in these cases.

I would like to make one further point. I am not seeking to draw any analogy, and neither do I believe is there any analogy, between this operation and the proceeds of crime. The proceeds of crime is a totally different principle which depends upon the receipt of ill-gotten gains. Since the person who commits a crime has no right and no legal entitlement to those ill-gotten gains, fairly obviously a spouse could not assume a right to them. Even the most recent amendments that have been made to legislation which put the onus of proof on the criminals themselves to show that the assets they have were derived from activity other than crime, do not in any way invalidate the point that I have made that the Proceeds of Crime Act is based on the notion that the criminal does not have any legal entitlement to those assets, income, money or whatever and, hence, the assets cannot be passed to his spouse or children. This, however, is a different matter. This is an earning, a salary, in as much as we have not sought, for example, to take all of the salary that a corrupt officer earned. It seems to me that, in keeping with that principle, we also ought not seek to take in total that part of the salary which the Government has set aside as a superannuation benefit.

I would ask the Government to consider seriously the point that I have raised. It is a policy point. It is something that needs to be taken into consideration in the further developments that will be undoubtedly undertaken in this area. These developments probably can best be handled not in this area but in the superannuation policy area in general as it develops with regard to families and other people who may seek to be the owners-at least morally and soon, I hope, legally-of the benefits that flow from superannuation cover.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I thank the Opposition and the Australian Democrats for their support for the Crimes (Superannuation Benefits) Bill and the Australian Federal Police Amendment Bill. It is not surprising support because indeed the Bills continue to embody the intention of the Parliament that those persons who are employed to serve the public should not benefit from Commonwealth funded pension entitlements or superannuation entitlements if it is discovered that during that period of public service they were in fact corrupted and obviously acted in a way detrimental to the general interest of the public. The Commonwealth takes the view that the pension entitlement, in so far as it is Commonwealth funded, should be made available only to those who have served the public in a non-corrupt fashion; that is, those who have truly fulfilled their contract in that sense. It is only when that is the case, that is when they have fulfilled their contract in a non-corrupt fashion, that the entitlement really arises.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased that the chamber is indicating its support for these Bills but I do think the matters raised by Senator Macklin deserve very serious consideration and I can assure him that the Government will give it to them. I suppose it is worth just making the point that we are not talking about the whole of the superannuation available to the former corrupt Commonwealth employee; the lump sum payment that might be obtained, which is a refund of employee contributions, will be available and unaffected by this particular legislation.

Nevertheless, in relation to the Commonwealth funded portion of the benefit Senator Macklin raises a very interesting point that indeed there might be a legitimate expectation on the part of the spouse that the benefit which had been accruing over the period of the employment of the corrupted official might be available in some proportion for that spouse in the event, for example, of the dissolution of the marriage. There is some analogy, I believe, with the continual accrual of income over the period of employment of a public official, which of course can be transmuted into capital, such as the matrimonial home. It is quite clear that the Family Court regards the matter in the light that Senator Macklin put forward.

I believe that there is a matter there for consideration. I am advised that the Family Law Council is indeed looking at this area and I understand that the Family Court is edging towards and trying to develop some principles in relation to the matter in general, indicating that perhaps where divorce occurs prior to confiscation and the employee is close to retirement, the likelihood of superannuation is taken into account as a financial resource available to the person and the property settlement is adjusted accordingly. For example, in the knowledge that the superannuation benefit might be available in two or three years time to one of the parties to the marriage the other party, the non-earning party, may in fact have, let us say, her proportion of the matrimonial home or entitlement to the general property shared by the partners up to the divorce increased in view of the likelihood of the superannuation accruing to the employed party. In that situation, as I am advised, the spouse who takes a greater share for example in the matrimonial home or in property would be unaffected by any subsequent confiscation. Senator Macklin has raised some very important and interesting matters.

It is a difficult area. There is no doubt about the deterrent effect of being able to say, for example, to an Australian Federal Police officer that he will not be able to hedge his bets, that he will not be able to say, `I will try to get away with this corrupt practice and if I do not, well, at the end of the day my wife and kids will be looked after because they will have the super'. To take away that particular possibility will, I think, be a very real deterrent to the police officer and, in the light of these Bills, other public servants concerned. Whether it is given too much weight in the sort of argument that Senator Macklin has raised today is, I think, a matter for consideration and I undertake that I will certainly try to find out what the Family Law Council is doing in this regard, and he suggests other forums to deal with a review of superannuation more generally. I think that that is a good prop- osition. So, Mr Deputy President, I thank the Senate for its support for these Bills and commend them.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) left Australia today on official Government business overseas. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Button as Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and in his capacity as Minister representing the Prime Minister. I preface my question by referring to a speech given in Sydney yesterday by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, entitled `The Government's role and responsibility in safeguarding industry development', in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: To my mind, governments need most of all to have consistent policy responses to the environmental puzzles they are faced with, rather than be seen to be reacting to each and every environmental group and its demands. If they don't, they are not acting as a government, nor are they engaging in the debate in the most responsible manner. People want governments to set the agenda and take balanced decisions.

No matter how adept any government is at doing ad hoc deals or how clever in taking short term fixes or how courageous in taking a stand on environmental questions, political and economic reality demand a balance to be struck and for more comprehensive policies to be put in place.

First, does the Minister agree with these views of Mr Kerin? Second, if so, why did the Government not follow these views when reaching its decision on Coronation Hill? Third, will Mr Kerin be sacked for once again, for the second time in two weeks, criticising the Government's decision on Coronation Hill? If not, why not? Fourth, when will the next meeting be held of the group of senior Ministers, which is reported in the Sunday Herald of 22 October to include Senators Button, Cook, Evans and Walsh plus Mr Kerin, established to counter what they see as a growing anti-development bias in Government decision making fostered for cynical, opportunistic, vote-buying reasons by their colleague Senator Richardson at great cost to the living standards of all Australians?

TALK.START.PARA: —I read newspaper reports of Mr Kerin's speech and, if I might offer a commentary on it, I found some of the illustrative material that he used in the speech flamboyant and very graphic. But in so far as he is making a point about governments-`governments' in the plural because this issue concerns both State and Federal governments and if one asks people in industry about it, their concern is largely with inconsistent decisions, sometimes made between various governments and so on-I agree that consistent policy responses are desirable, and consistent policy responses which reflect the concept of sustainable development. This was developed and enlarged on in the Prime Minister's speech on the environment.
—What about within government? That is the question you are being asked.

—I am referring to Mr Kerin's speech; I am not taking supplementaries from Senator Alston. Senator Short implied in his question that Mr Kerin had again criticised the Coronation Hill decision in his speech.
—You are not suggesting he did not?

—I am sorry, I have not read the full text of the speech but I saw no specific reference to Coronation Hill. Senator Short then went on to ask whether the Minister should be sacked for criticising the Government's decision on Coronation Hill. I will try to obtain a full text of the speech. If I find any reference of that kind in it I will answer that part of the question. I do not believe it to be there. Finally, Senator Short asked about a group of senior Ministers which was referred to in an article in the Sunday Herald. He asked when that group was going to meet. I saw that reference in the Sunday Herald, or somebody drew it to my attention. I saw that I was mentioned as one of the senior Ministers concerned and I thought to myself that it must be a very secret meeting because I have never been told about it and I do not think any of the other Ministers have either. —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his non-answer. If he does, why did the Government not follow those views when reaching its decision on Coronation Hill? In relation to Mr Kerin's criticism of the Government's decisions on Coronation Hill, I think it is correct to say that his speech yesterday ranged much more widely. He was talking about the Government's environmental decisions as a whole. In that case, will he be sacked for again criticising the decisions that the Government has made on Coronation Hill and other environmental matters?

—I said in my answer to the first part of the question that I did not apprehend, on my reading of Mr Kerin's speech, that there had been any specific reference at all to Coronation Hill. —I refer the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to the Prime Minister's recent statement which acknowledged the outstanding success of the Year of Citizenship. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —To some extent I think my Department has been a victim of the success of this particular campaign. ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

They would like to mine Kakadu. In criticising extremists, it is this mad rush opposite for development at any cost that is more open to criticism than any action of this Government.

It has spent a long time evaluating each project, whereas the herd instinct of those on the other side of the chamber, led by Senator Boswell and company-they have a shadow Minister for the environment who has never had one win inside their party room, who is only up there as a front man--

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President, I would appreciate it if the Minister could just answer the question that was asked, which I thought was rather simple-whether he agreed with Senator Richardson or Minister Kerin.
—Order! There is no point of order, but there have been too many interjections.

—Why does Senator Brownhill not write out the answer for me if that is the sort of answer that he wants? He just cannot cop the criticism. TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications seen the reports on the latest outrageous attack by the Opposition spokesman on communications, Senator Alston, on the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, particularly in the area of the ABT's efforts to get a greater degree of Australian content on Australian television and on the question of violence on television? Is there any factual basis for Senator Alston's attacks?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen Senator Alston's press release of 29 October and his reported comments the following day in which he accused the ABT of attempting, as he said, to jack up local content transmission requirements, at a time when the television industry was financially troubled. He further charged that the Tribunal was preoccupied with wringing its hands over violence on television.

ANSWER.PARA: Not only are Senator Alston's comments, quite characteristically, inaccurate but they also reflect on the integrity of members of an organisation set up by this Parliament to perform important regulatory functions in the interests of Australian viewers. That is the job they are doing. They are doing it very well, and they do not deserve the kind of attack that Senator Alston has made here and elsewhere. He argued that networks should be required to maintain their current levels of Australian content transmission. He ignored the fact that the level of Australian drama, which is the expensive area that most concerns them, required to be broadcast under the new standard, which represents just 4.7 per cent of total programming time, is based on the average actual performance of the three Sydney stations during 1987-88.

TALK.START.PARA: —And that is what is wrong with it.

—Senator Alston cannot have it both ways. He cannot, on the one hand, complain that the requirement is being increased while at the same time acknowledging that the requirement does not represent an increase over what the stations have in fact been doing in the way that I have just described. That inability to recognise that one cannot have it two ways at once is one of the things that have characterised Senator Alston's hopefully short-lived tenure in the job that he is presently occupying on the front bench.

ANSWER.PARA: The standard does require an increase in Australian transmission of children's drama, reflecting the very strong community interest in this matter contained in the representations received during the ABT's inquiry process. But the networks are given substantial flexibility on how they meet the rest of their total point score against that background. The Tribunal has signalled that it intends to take into account network submissions, on the phasing-in of the proposed 50 per cent Australian content transmission rule. This will be reflected in a revised draft of the standard to be released next week.

Senator Alston's claims that the network will have to spend at least $20m more a year on programs to `satisfy someone's social prejudice' is both false and offensive. He may be a hero of the American film and television industry, but he is certainly no friend of the Australian industry, nor of those in the community who want to see as much Australian content as is reasonably possible and, in particular, those who want to see an increase in Australian content in children's drama.

TALK.START.PARA: —You only watch LA Law, and we know it.

—On the subject of violence, of which Senator Ray just reminded me, Senator Alston's suggestion that the ABT is pre-occupied with hand wringing over violence is a comment which ignores, among other things, that it is not a self-initiated ABT concern. It was the product of a specific reference to it by the Government-by me when I was Minister-and a reference last August which generated a very wide degree of community support at the time and not, as I recall, any expression of opposition from the Opposition benches. In fact, it was widely applauded. That inquiry has made substantial progress. It has been characterised by full cooperation and bipartisanship between the Tribunal and the networks. The networks are now working on a draft joint self-regulatory code on the portrayal and presentation of violence. For Senator Alston to assault the ABT for the work it is doing in trying to come to grips with this obvious and manifest problem shows how out of touch with community sentiment the Opposition is.

ANSWER.PARA: I take this opportunity once again to express the Government's full confidence in the members of the Broadcasting Tribunal. Nobody is compelled to agree with everything the ABT proposes. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —If one needed an illustration of what Mr Kerin was referring to in his speech, a spooky example has now been provided by Senator Sanders. When the CSIRO mission travelled overseas to look at the pulp and paper industry following the Wesley Vale decision, the mission was specifically instructed to look at the market for unbleached paper products and technology in respect of producing unbleached paper. ANSWER.PARA: I do not have the information in front of me at the moment, but the market assessment world wide in respect of unbleached paper states that it is not a very viable market. TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you taking this bilge seriously?
