QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DRAFT CONVENTION ON THE RIGHTS OF THE CHILD

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Justice aware of claims that the draft Convention on the Rights of the Child will enable the Government to interfere in relationships between parents and children over a wide range of matters? In particular, is the Minister aware of an assertion that the Convention gives the Federal Government power to remove children from their parents if the parents deny their child any of the rights as defined in the Convention'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of a letter recently published in a regional newspaper which makes a number of quite outrageous and totally incorrect claims about the draft Convention on the Rights of the Child. I am particularly concerned that misgivings or apprehensions that people may have about this draft Convention be put to rest as soon as possible. For that reason I need to emphasise that at this stage the Convention is only in draft form. It will be put before the United Nations General Assembly for adoption in December. At least until that process occurs, there can be no question of ratification by Australia. The letter I have in mind makes the following statement:

ANSWER.PARA: This treasonous document is now due to become law in Australia-yes Australia in December this year.
That is an incorrect statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —What paper was that in?

—It appeared in the Port Lincoln Times of 31 October 1989. That statement is so incorrect that it raises a question as to the motive of the person who wrote that letter. The ratification, if it does occur, can only be done by the Government after the terms of the Convention are settled and further consultation with State and Territory governments takes place.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the substance of the correspondent's complaints, it appears that a central element of the scaremongering approach is to suggest that the Convention will somehow permit the Federal Government to crash through the doors of the family home and tear a child from the arms of his or her parents. It is also suggested that the Convention removes the entitlement of any parent to make some contribution to the moral and spiritual development of the child. Those fears are entirely ludicrous and mischievous. Nevertheless, for the edification of the Senate I will refer to a number of provisions in the Convention. For example, article 5 expressly acknowledges the critical role of the parent in the raising of a child. It states:

States Parties shall respect the responsibilities, rights and duties of parents . . . to provide, in a manner consistent with the evolving capacities of the child appropriate direction and guidance in the exercise by the child of the rights (recognised in the Convention).

I have paraphrased some of that article. As to the question of religious and moral matters, article 14 properly acknowledges the right of a child to freedom of thought, conscience and religion. In so doing, however, the Convention expressly provides that:

States Parties shall respect the rights and duties of the parents . . . to provide direction to the child in the exercise of his or her right in a manner consistent with the evolving capacities of the child.
On the issue of the state intervening to separate a child from his or her parents, article 9 provides:

That a child shall not be separated from his or her parent against their will, except when competent authorities subject to judicial review determine, in accordance with applicable law and procedures, that such separation is necessary for the best interests of the child.
I have taken the Senate to three of the provisions in a very comprehensive document. I urge honourable senators to read it, as should many other community and voluntary groups around Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you considering signing an international agreement of this kind?

—I understand that at the recent Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, all 49 heads of government-and that is a very wide range of persons-called for its early entry into force. They cannot all be wrong on that issue. They cannot all have misread it in the way that has been suggested. In fact, it is probably the one point of unanimity between Mr Hawke and Mrs Thatcher. I have put those matters on the record because I fear that many misgivings may be generated in the community concerning this Convention. —Does the Minister for Resources believe that we have reached the point in Australia where it is necessary to decide what lands can be farmed and then stop people from farming outside them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —No doubt this question has arisen from a reading that Senator Lewis has undertaken of a speech made by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy yesterday, because reference was made to this in that speech. One of the quotes attributed to Senator Richardson by Senator Brownhill a moment ago contained similar words. If the honourable senator wishes to trivialise some of the points that were made in Mr Kerin's speech, so be it, and let the issue rest on the honourable senator's head. —Exactly, but the essential theme of what Mr Kerin said was to support the concept of sustainable development. I have been espousing that concept for some time; it is a concept supported by the Prime Minister in the environment statement that he presented in July. It is the underlying thesis of the United Nations Brundtland report, Our Common Future-World Commission on Environment and Development, a report popularised under the shelf title for a book Our Common Future. It deals with the fundamental problem of resolving the issues involving legitimate environmental concerns and legitimate development concerns and how one arrives at a resolution between the two.

ANSWER.PARA: In the case of agriculture, the most important environmental question in this country relates to the fact that we have lost production on agricultural lands of $600m a year through land degradation. That is not just my view. It is a common view across the chamber and in the community. This is the issue on which we have mounted a bipartisan and cooperative effort with the non-government organisations in this country in order to combat the problem.

The view that we all have on this is that we should move to combat land degradation by changing the attitudes of landholders to the care and management of their land and by undertaking work on catchment models, planning and cooperation. The fact that it is a major problem does not mean that some people do not have a view which differs from the cooperative model. Some people do and they express it, and they are entitled to do so. We still have democracy in this country. The Government is committed to working through the concept in the Brundtland report, on which we now have a working model in Australia in relation to agriculture, and that is the appropriate model.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The question was addressed to the Minister as the Minister for Resources for Australia. It was a simple question. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator might call it a simple question, because indeed he is actually described as a simple man. ANSWER.PARA: Senator Lewis interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought there was bipartisanship on this issue, because we are committed to a program of national soil conservation, and as a centrepiece of that program-which, by the way, was the centrepiece of the Prime Minister's environment statement-we are working through land care groups. We are getting farmers in their own communities, regions and catchments to look at a total plan for a region and catchment and to work through peer group pressure in the farming and conservation organisations. —My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs and relates to the recent launch of the banking ombudsman scheme. Will the Minister inform the Senate of the ways in which the banking ombudsman will be able to assist consumers who seek redress from a bank?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has been concerned for some time about a number of bank related issues, particularly when it comes to disputes with the banking institutions. The Government has been concerned about the number of them, the way the disputes have been handled and, generally, the problem of consumers not being able to enforce their rights in this area. In terms of the number of disputes, I am sure that honourable senators will realise that we are talking about quite a number. In relation to the electronic funds transfer area-a matter in which Senator Vanstone showed some interest some time ago-it has been estimated that some 30,000 disputes a year arise in that area of banking.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of handling disputes, concern has been expressed about tardiness. As is often the case with large bureaucracies, there can be a tardiness and consequent frustration to consumers because of the way disputes have been handled. In the area of enforcement of rights there has been concern that because of the small amount that is in dispute quite often in these sorts of cases, combined with the costs of access to law, people's rights have not been all that readily enforceable.

The Government has recognised that the small claims tribunal access offers little avenue of redress, in that quite often the jurisdictions in this area are too small to be of any meaningful use to consumers. Accordingly, over the past 18 months or so we have developed in cooperation with the Australian Bankers Association (ABA)-a very productive cooperation-a model very much along the lines of the model of the British banking ombudsman.

This matter has been worked on and in the development of the process we have been keen to ensure that consumers in this country are protected in having an avenue available to them which can be of some major use to them. We have been keen to ensure the independence of the body and, accordingly, the council which will be running the banking ombudsman scheme is very finely balanced with community, consumer and industry representatives, and chaired, as has already been publicised, by Sir Ninian Stephen.

In terms of the actual power of the ombudsman, we have been keen to ensure that the structure has enough resources, and the banking sector has indicated that it is prepared to put up some $2m to ensure that the scheme will work. That is only one part of the problem. We have also been keen to ensure that the body has determinative powers and that it can work productively in making sure that all the necessary information can be called before it. Accordingly, it will have the power to call for documents.

We had to address the cost problem, and we have been able to get agreement from the Australian Bankers Association to make the scheme accessible to consumers free. I heard during the lunch break that Senator McLean was worried about people who have complaints at the moment. Since the scheme was first mooted in May this year it has been agreed that disputes arising as from 10 May or thereabouts would also be subject to the jurisdiction of the ombudsman scheme when it is set up. There has also been a concern that this sort of avenue might supplant or overtake existing rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to make a statement, Nick?

—This is not a statement. I am setting out the details of the scheme. I might say that some honourable senators opposite have shown more interest than Senator Hill has over recent days; they also have been inquiring about it. A very important avenue of redress will be to ensure that consumers, once they have had their disputes handled, do not lose their rights at law and can, in fact, once the case has been determined, pursue the matter at law and through the courts if they so desire. Also, if there is a case that needs to go to court on appeal or will be referred to courts by, say, a banking institution, the banks have agreed to pay for the cost of that court process and any appeal thereafter.

ANSWER.PARA: The coverage has also been important and, to that extent, members of the ABA will be covered. Other retail banks will be approached, but we anticipate that other institutions-not banking institutions-that handle electronic funds transfers will be joining the scheme very soon. It is a very extensive and important scheme. In terms of the ultimate decision-making function of the ombudsman, the basic consideration will be what is fair in all the circumstances. In that respect he will take into account the law on banking practices. The final criterion is fundamentally very important. As has been indicated before, it is an important initiative, one which should be able to make available access to the law to a whole range of consumers who in the past have not had this provision available to them.

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the failure to tax capital gains will usually favour those who are more well-to-do rather than those who are less, since the former own more capital per head than the latter and are more likely to make investments that realise capital gains.
In the White Paper of 1985, the point was also made that the absence of a capital gains tax opens up the taxation system to massive tax avoidance. It said:

The lack of a general capital gains tax represents a structural defect in the income tax system which lies at the core of many avoidance arrangements: if income can be converted into or dressed up as capital gains, income tax can be avoided completely. The imposition of a capital gains tax would, therefore, strike at one of the foundations of tax avoidance in Australia. TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, Senator Powell asked a series of questions about the circumstances of a defence exercise being conducted in the Beecroft range at Jervis Bay. TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this week I was asked a question by Senator McGauran about canned fruit from Canada. I am now in a position to supply an answer.

ANSWER.PARA: Under the Canada-Australia Trade Agreement (CANATA), Canada is obliged to grant Australian goods listed in schedule A of the agreement rates of duty no higher than those accorded to similar Canadian imports from any other country. The Canada-United States Free Trade Agreement (FTA) introduced on 1 January 1989 provides for reductions in rates of duty on many US products. The product likely to be most affected by the Free Trade Agreement is canned fruit, for which Canada is our largest export market-worth around $A30m in 1988-and the US has the potential to become our major competitor. Under the Free Trade Agreement, US rates of duty will be phased out by 1998, whereas Australian product will continue to face tariffs of 10 to 15 per cent if Canada fails to honour its obligations under CANATA.

Canada has continually disputed Australia's legal entitlements under CANATA and argued that, under customary international law, it has no obligation to extend the phasing out of US tariffs to Australian products. It further argues that canned fruit was removed from schedule A by Canadian domestic legislation in 1979 and is therefore not covered by the relevant CANATA provision.

Australia has continued to reject the Canadian arguments, and the Prime Minister wrote to his Canadian counterpart in an effort to resolve the issue. At the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Kuala Lumpur in October 1989, the Australian Prime Minister reached agreement with his Canadian counterpart on the issue.

The Prime Minister issued a press release on 24 October 1989 that the agreement means the Canadian tariff on Australian canned fruit will be phased down, in the context of the Uruguay Round, to a level which leaves the Australian industry competitive with other exporters. The actual rate of reductions in the Canadian tariff will be settled through negotiations in the Uruguay Round. Negotiations will commence without delay and will be completed within a year.

This is the first annual report of the Australian Film Finance Corporation Pty Ltd. The Corporation was incorporated on 12 July last year. That incorporation was part of the major restructuring of the film industry and the backing of that industry which took place in accordance with the Australian Film Commission Amendment Act 1988, which was the last piece of legislation to be dealt with in the old House of Parliament. This is a report of the year's activities of the financial arm of the Australian film industry. The principal functions of the Corporation are as follows:

to invest in feature films, mini-series, telemovies and documentaries . . . to make loans, provide guarantees and underwriting in respect of Australian programs; to lead or participate in loan syndicates . . . to form or participate in the formation of trusts and companies formed to produce Australian programs.
In other words, as I said before, its function is to provide the financial backing for our Australian film industry.

It is noted in the report that the 10ba incentives are no longer able to maintain productions at a high level. Therefore, the Australian Film Commission published a set of options for reforms which included the proposal to establish this film financing body as one of the Government's principal assistance mechanisms to replace the former 10ba tax shelter provisions. Indeed, the Government will be providing financial support for four years. In this report we learn that the film industry has been given a $50m grant by the Government for its first year, and that further grants will be available for the other three years. The whole point of this step is that the assistance provided by the private sector should be increased as the years go by.

The Corporation operates primarily from Sydney and Melbourne. Of the 19 full time and one part time staff members, five are located in the Melbourne offices and the others in the Sydney offices. As far as keeping in touch with film producers in South Australia and Western Australia is concerned, representatives of the Corporation regularly visit Adelaide and Perth. Brisbane is not so advantaged; it states in the report that that city receives occasional visits.

During the financial year covered by this report 72 film projects were evaluated and 51 were approved for investment. A breakdown by percentage shows that features comprise 61.95 per cent, television dramas provide 31.08 per cent and documentaries provide 6.97 per cent of the productions which were approved for investment last year. During its first year in operation the Corporation was required to secure 30 per cent private sector participation as far as its supported production slate is concerned. For individual projects the minimum level of private sector investment is 15 per cent, which can be reduced in the case of children's dramas, certain other documentaries and exceptional cases. The Corporation is not permitted to fully fund projects. In future years the Corporation will, at the request of the Government, raise the aggregate level of private sector participation. The level is to be 35 per cent for the year 1989-90 and to increase in future years so that there is less reliance on Corporation funds. During this last year 105 funding applications were received. Of those, 72 were considered, seven withdrawn, 26 deferred to 1989-90 for consideration and, as I said before, 51 were approved. I commend this report. It shows us that the Australian film industry is in good shape and that, in the years ahead, it will have suitable financial backing.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration entitled Government Companies and their Reporting Requirements, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This inquiry was a further step in the Committee's continuing scrutiny of the non-departmental area of public administration. Several previous reports have dealt with statutory authorities and non-statutory bodies but this is the first occasion on which government involvement in companies has come under review by the Committee. The Committee took as its starting point a firm conviction that Ministers are no less responsible for the companies within their portfolios than for their departments and statutory authorities. It follows that the device of creating a company should not be taken as a pretext for sidestepping the principle of accountability to Parliament.

The Committee's interest in the Commonwealth's involvement in companies was prompted by the rapid growth in the number of subsidiary companies formed by government business enterprises (GBEs)-for example, the Commonwealth Bank and Australian Airlines; the steady growth in minority holdings in companies by bodies such as the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust and the Australian Industry Development Corporation in the course of their normal activities; the conversion of several major GBEs from statutory authority to company status-for example, Australian Airlines, Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation (SMEC), Australian National Line (ANL) and Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC); the formation of Aerospace Technologies of Australia and Australian Defence Industries out of the Department of Defence by executive action without any reference to Parliament.

These developments raised four questions which the Committee saw as important. What is the extent of the Government's involvement in companies? What approvals are required for such involvement? What Government activities, if any, are suited for companies rather than statutory authorities? Are the arrangements for accountability to Parliament adequate? The first of these questions-the extent of Commonwealth involvement in companies-proved to be by far the most difficult. The simple answer is that no-one knows exactly. The Auditor-General maintains a list but does not claim it to be complete. The Committee has compiled a list itself, but even during the printing of the report we were made aware of three omissions.

In all, we were able to locate almost 400 companies in which the Commonwealth has a major involvement. Just over half were majority-owned companies. The remainder were divided between companies in which the Government held 20 to 50 per cent of the capital, companies limited by guarantee and incorporated associations. We had no difficulty in concluding that, without a readily accessible and reliable register, the accountability of these companies was flawed. The Committee strongly recommends the establishment and continuous maintenance of a register of companies in which the Commonwealth has a substantial interest. This is a parallel recommendation to our previous recommendation on the establishment of a register of non-statutory bodies.

On the question of approvals for the formation of companies, we again found a confusing situation. Subsidiary companies may be formed by GBEs-whether statutory authorities or companies-as they choose, but they should notify the Minister of all such formations or acquisitions. An earlier requirement for the tabling of this information seems to have been quietly dropped, at least in one area. We can find no evidence that it was ever carried out.

Parliamentary approval was necessary for the conversion of Australian Airlines, SMEC, ANL and OTC from statutory authorities to companies. But there is a gaping hole in the approval process: Ministers, acting through their departments, can apparently form, participate in and even dispose of companies in the ordinary exercise of their executive powers. They need not inform Parliament or table annual reports.

Thus, the Minister for Defence established two companies-Aerospace Technologies of Australia and Australian Defence Industries-and transferred assets worth hundreds of millions of dollars and over 8,000 employees from the Department to the new companies. In the same way, the Department of Employment, Education and Training sponsors, joins, appoints directors to and finances more than 100 companies limited by guarantee and incorporated associations. Their existence as committees is mentioned but their legal status is not disclosed in the Department's annual report and, to the best of our knowledge, Parliament has never been informed of their existence as incorporated bodies.

The Committee has made a series of recommendations to ensure that the government cannot become involved in companies without general or specific parliamentary approval. One can question whether there are advantages in company status as against the statutory authority form, and whether company status is necessary to obtain the greater efficiency and flexibility that everyone is seeking. It is possible to give as much, or as little, operating freedom as the government chooses to either statutory authorities or companies, as the Minister for Finance has pointed out in the past.

The Committee agreed that, in the event of company status being considered in the future, a criterion should be set requiring that a company be established only when clear efficiencies or other benefits arise which cannot be obtained without the use of the company structure. The Committee was also unanimous in its view that the reporting and auditing arrangements for government companies were wholly inadequate. We were astonished to learn that the two defence companies, for example, are `exempt proprietary companies', which means that there need be no public reporting, though the Minister has promised that annual reports will be tabled.

The Committee recommends that no government companies be incorporated as exempt proprietary companies and that the existing ones be converted to public company status. Furthermore, all government companies should be required to conform to the reporting requirements of statutory authorities as well as meeting those of the Companies Code and that all such reports should be tabled in Parliament.

The Committee strongly rejects the view that government companies should be free to choose their own private auditors. Audit is not an instrument of control; it is an instrument of accountability. The greater the degree of management freedom, the greater is the requirement for adequate accountability. The auditing standards under the Audit Act are wider than those provided by the Companies Code and the Committee recommends that all government companies be audited by the Auditor-General to Audit Act standards. This would not prevent the delegation of work to private auditors under contract, but under the control of the Auditor-General.

The Committee believes that the problems surrounding this subject are sufficiently important to justify the introduction of legislation to cover the whole area of government companies. Such legislation would regulate the formation of, acquisition of, participation in and disposal of government companies. It would also cover reporting, auditing and tabling requirements and the maintenance of the register which the Committee recommends be established.

This Committee is unanimous in its view that the increased use of the company structure has opened up serious gaps in the ability of Parliament to carry out its functions. It fully endorses the recommendation of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts that the Auditor-General be reinstated as the auditor of all government companies. I was pleased to hear the Minister for Finance announce yesterday that the Government was disposed to accept this recommendation.

I thank everyone connected with the preparation of this report, especially Michael Game, the Committee's research officer. I should also mention, for those who continually criticise the Australian Government Publishing Service (AGPS), that the printed copies were delivered to us less than 48 hours after the camera-ready copy was provided to the AGPS. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have been a member of the finance and public administration company--

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I mean the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration-in its deliberation of this matter dealing with government companies. The whole issue of government companies is very much tied up with the question of privatisation. Perhaps that was a Freudian slip on my part. But I want to refer to that aspect of the matter in the course of my remarks. In its inquiry the Committee discovered a most extraordinary situation that has developed in Commonwealth Government administration in recent years. We are all familiar with Qantas Airways Ltd, which is, as we all know, a company formed under what I think was the Queensland Companies Act. Qantas was acquired by the Commonwealth by purchasing shares. However, that was a fairly unique and exceptional way in which government had gone about carrying out its business.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from the departmental form of government administration, of course, the other method favoured by government with the approval of Parliament has been the creation of statutory corporations under special Acts of Parliament. The whole range of requirements of corporate form are dealt with in such legislation, in particular the accountability of the entity to the Parliament. The ordinary accountability of administration of the Commonwealth Government to Parliament is provided under our principle of ministerial responsibility, dealt with in section 64 of the Constitution, which enables the appointment of officers-that is the constitutional word; we refer to `Ministers'-to administer departments of state as the Governor-General may establish. Those officers are known as Ministers of State.

What seems to have been occurring in recent years is that, without actually deciding that an existing or new function of government will be hived off from a department and placed in a statutory body known as a statutory corporation, the Commonwealth administration-presumably with the knowledge and consent of Ministers, although that is not always entirely clear-has been forming companies under the ordinary companies codes of the State in which they are formed, or in the Australian Capital Territory in many cases. That function, which was previously a departmental function, is being carried on by the company which, in many cases, is wholly owned by the Commonwealth and the shareholders in that company are usually the Minister and/or senior officers of the department concerned.

In the view of the Committee, there is no doubt that these companies are accountable through the ordinary company structure to the Minister, and thereby the Minister is accountable to the Parliament under the ordinary principles of responsible government enshrined, of course, in the Constitution. Nevertheless, there are very obvious problems in giving effect to that accountability if the functions of a department are in fact carried on in that way. The report explains those difficulties. Senator Coates has already given some examples of the problem in his tabling statement.

One major problem is that the reason that these departmental functions have been hived off into company form is precisely because the departments are dealing with activities with which it is inconvenient in many ways for those who are carrying on that particular function to be hobbled. They do not want to be hobbled in any way with the ordinary rules dealing with departmental administration and, in particular, the accountability ultimately to the Parliament, even to the extent that the executives of these companies, despite that legal and constitutional responsibility that they ultimately have, are seeking to avoid the attention of and auditing by the Auditor-General.

That matter has also been considered by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. I think it should be of great note to the Government and to the Parliament that two committees now-the Public Accounts Committee and the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration-have come to the same view that certainly the Auditor-General must be responsible for the audit of these companies, even though private auditors may be subcontracted in arrangements to be made between the Auditor-General and the executives of the company. It is really quite a remarkable development that not only have these companies been formed but also, in a large number of cases, are not even known to exist. The experience that we had in the Committee was that we found difficulties in identifying them, and we do not know whether we have identified all of them by any means.

TALK.START.PARA: —We certainly haven't.

—Senator Tambling, in an Estimates committee, found some company structures operating in the Aboriginal Development Commission which we had not been aware of. They are not referred to or accounted for in this particular report. Shortly after settling this report, I got an invitation to a function in Parliament House from Senator Cook to celebrate the opening of some important environmental initiative. The actual invitation indicated that the Government had formed a company called Land Care to perform a particular function. That company should be added to this list. Presumably the Minister knew all about that company, but in some cases I suspect that some of these companies are formed without Ministers knowing about them. It would be very valuable if the Government, in response to this Committee, could indicate clearly whether there is firm ministerial involvement in the formation and, indeed, the administration of these companies.

SPEECH.PARA: One other matter I mention is the recommendation of a government companies Act. That is not intended to be an Act under which these companies would be formed. In other words, it is not as though we are suggesting that there should be a separate Act under which these entities achieve legal status as independent entities known as companies. This is simply a government companies Act, the purpose of which is set out in great detail in paragraph 3.4.3 of chapter 3 of the report. It is really designed to ensure that the Parliament is informed about the intention to form such companies, that adequate reporting is made to Parliament, that adequate auditing is undertaken and so on. The precedent for that has come from a recent Act passed in the New South Wales Parliament known as the State Owned Corporations Act. I hope that the Government will agree that that Act could be an important step to be taken by this Parliament in solving the problems that clearly arise in the proper accountability of government companies.

A further matter I mention is the question of the proper status of government companies at all in the political arena. Although the members of this Committee were clearly divided on party lines in their attitude to privatisation of government functions, it is interesting that the Committee has been able to put down a unanimous report. There is no dissenting report. We accepted our differences and sought to achieve a positive result about which we could agree. That has, I think, been a significant achievement of this report. Nevertheless, hanging behind this report there is the fundamental political question of whether it is appropriate to hive off what is a growing area of government functions to companies and whether it would not be more appropriate for those activities to be within the jurisdiction of the private sector and therefore be privatised.

I do not want to go into the debate for or against privatisation, but clearly one can look at the criteria that it is suggested should be adopted by both the Government in its statements on government business enterprises and by the Committee in chapter 4 of this report. In paragraph 4.4 of the Committee's report, under the heading, `Criteria for Company Formation', and in the following paragraphs, it is notable that the sorts of criteria that it is agreed should be satisfied before any government structure is considered-apart from the ultimate destination of the shareholding in these companies-are very much the sorts of criteria which would, in my view, be appropriate for the private sector to be performing rather than government.

We have a rather odd situation whereby the present Government, which is officially largely opposed to privatisation, has moved very rapidly in the direction of what is called in many cases corporatising; although it is really a setting up in corporate form-that is, a company-of the administration of these activities. That development is occurring by leaps and bounds under a government which is officially opposed to privatisation.

The very dangerous aspect of this course, which I think is understood by Government members of the Committee, is that bodies will be set up which are accountable to no-one. If these bodies were privatised, they would not only be accountable to their shareholders but also be examined closely by the financial press and by the financial community generally. There would be all sorts of methods of accountability and pressures upon them to perform efficiently and properly. If they are to remain as government functions, they will be subject to the accountability processes that have been so well developed, in this Senate particularly, over the years. Although ministerial responsibility these days does not extend to the point where a Minister must know everything that is going on in his department, nevertheless a Minister knows that if something goes wrong, he must put it right. He must do the best he can to ensure that things do not go wrong.

With the hiving off of many of these functions into a company which is not subject to the ordinary pressures of the private sector and can escape much more easily the scrutiny of the Parliament and public control-I refer not merely to the Parliament but to the whole mechanism of financial controls, such as those of the Auditor-General, the Department of Finance, the Treasury, and so on-one is letting loose beings that are totally unguided and uncontrolled. I am very happy that the Committee has been unanimous in its recognition of that point and in its proposals to do something about it.

The absence of any comprehensible and readily accessible index of Commonwealth bodies is something that defies understanding. One would have thought that, if the Government was in the business of proper scrutiny of its own activities and indeed wanted to project an image of competence to the community at large, it would know precisely how many government business enterprises there were, how many statutory authorities there were and what their lines of responsibility were. Despite the fact that pressure has been brought to bear by a number of parliamentary committees-this being only the latest-the Government has shown no interest at all in recommendations for the establishment of a central register of companies and incorporated associations which the Government controls or in which it has a substantial interest.

I would have thought that the Department of Finance would be particularly well suited to carrying out such an exercise, compiling an index and making it publicly available. I am sure that those who are seriously interested in concepts of accountability would see this as axiomatic. Many statutory authorities are required by Government policy guidelines to table information in the Parliament. It is not at all easy to identify those that have complied with these requirements. Again, I think the Committee is at one in expressing its concern that there are not adequate safeguards for companies directly owned by the Government. We certainly believe that, whilst they do remain in the public domain, Parliament should have the ability to scrutinise all their activities and that full and informed reporting should be made to Parliament on a regular basis.

One of the recommendations that has much to commend it is that no direct government interest in a company be established without legislative authority. That does not necessarily mean that it will be a condition precedent to the establishment of a government-owned corporation that legislation be in place specifically related to that company. What it does mean is that there should be prescribed in legislation a regime which sets out the accounting and other requirements, and reportability obligations, so that once that company has been established by government, even if the public is not immediately aware of it, it will automatically become aware of it in due course because of those reporting requirements. That is a very timely and overdue recommendation and it is very difficult to understand why the Government has not embraced this to date. For each department to be required to list in its annual report those GBEs and other incorporated bodies within the purview of the department would seem to be an obvious and desirable safeguard.

The recommendation that government enterprises not be corporatised or incorporated unless there is `competition with the private sector, no explicit social objectives and a strong commercial culture' might be overstating the case, because there are internal mechanisms for funding community service obligations. That means that there can be competition with the rest of the private sector while still maintaining a specific non-commercial burden. There are means of funding that and I think there are a number of prime candidates for that type of arrangement. The drawing up of reporting guidelines for all companies, I think, is long overdue. I have no doubt at all that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) would heartily concur with that recommendation. Again, it is disappointing that the Government needs to be dragged into this arena, if it professes an interest in efficiency and accountability in the public sector.

The role of the Auditor-General has already been dealt with by my colleagues. The establishment of audit committees by all GBEs is again another imitation of private sector practice which does have something to recommend it. It normally applies in the private sector to enable a proper scrutiny to be undertaken of companies where it would otherwise be left to executive officers. Therefore, I think the role of non-executive directors on boards of GBEs is particularly important. Although there is no substitute for the real thing, certainly I think the notion of an audit committee makes considerable sense, rather than simply taking the word of those intimately involved in the day to day activities that all is well.

I think this has been a valuable report. I hope it will contribute not only to an informed debate in the wider community but also to the Government getting its own house in order. It has gone halfway in its determination to duck the privatisation issue and to pretend that somehow there is a brave new world of competitive government business enterprises. It has forgotten to put in place the right structures to ensure that there is full accountability and that indeed we can have as much confidence about the so-called bottom lines for public enterprises as we should have for any listed public company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend to the Senate the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. I also commend the hard work of Senators Coates, Alston, Black, Burns, Calvert and Durack as members of the Committee. This subject has interested me ever since I came into this Parliament. I am very supportive of the conclusions of the Committee. In particular, I commend the Committee's recommendation for the establishment of a central register of companies and incorporated associations which the Commonwealth controls or in which it has a substantial interest. Apparently, as the Committee points out, it has been very difficult to establish what companies the Government owns or controls, one way or the other. It is certain that there is very little evidence available on what some of these companies actually do.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that Australian Airlines has a whole heap of subsidiaries which are registered in the Cook Islands with no revelation here of the extent to which ownership is held by it except that the shares are in the name of a trustee company but Australian Airlines controls the voting rights. The companies listed in the Cook Islands are Antacus Investments Ltd, Fenwick Finance Ltd, Hurdman Finance Ltd, Keynell Finance Ltd, Lanmartin Investments Ltd, Laroy Finance Ltd, Markby Finance Ltd, Quendon Investments Ltd, Redmond Ltd, Romeyn Investments Ltd, Safan Finance Ltd, Semkow Finance Ltd, Vandor Finance Ltd, Venton Finance Ltd, Wain Investments Ltd, Whittaker Finance Ltd, Yarnworth Securities Ltd and Zea Securities Ltd. What on earth is Australian Airlines doing having these subsidiaries registered in the Cook Islands? Presumably it is a tax dodge. I see the look of shock and horror on the face of a distinguished legal senator opposite. I can assure him that unless there was some advantage in having these subsidiaries registered in the Cook Islands that would not have taken place.

I believe that the Parliament has the right to scrutinise such investments, so long as Australian Airlines remains owned by the public. There was great public distress and concern when the Four Corners program on the ABC pointed out the extent to which the Cook Islands appeared to be the home of many companies in the Bond Group, where remarkable profits appeared to be earned. The point about Australian Airlines underlines how absurd it is for the Government to continue to own an organisation which is in the private sector, for which there is no sound reason for government ownership and which, in fact, will be privatised by the coalition when it returns to government next year.

There are many other matters that concern me in this report. I want to express my support for the Committee's concerns that there are not adequate safeguards for companies directly owned by the Government. The report points out:

This is a significant gap in the accountability system. There is no requirement for parliamentary approval of the initial government involvement or even for the Parliament to be advised of it. There are no legal requirements for advice to Parliament of changes in the government involvement or for the tabling of annual reports.

This is of particular concern in dealing with very substantial government business enterprises. On page 15 of the report the Committee does the Parliament a great service by pointing out the way in which this Government has sought to diminish the level of parliamentary scrutiny of these governmental bodies. The Committee reveals that the 1987 policy guidelines require prior ministerial approval of initial involvement in subsidiaries formed or acquired by statutory authorities. The 1987 guidelines also require a Minister to table in Parliament information on the formation or acquisition of subsidiaries within 15 sitting days of the formation or acquisition. The Committee states:

A 1988 revision of the policy guidelines in respect of eight GBEs within the Transport and Communication portfolio replaced the requirement for ministerial approval with a provision for the minister to be notified. At the same time, and apparently without public announcement, the requirement for tabling of information in Parliament was dropped in respect of the eight transport and communication GBEs. Although the tabling requirement remains for all other statutory authorities, the Committee can find no evidence that information on the formation or acquisition of any subsidiary company has been tabled since the policy guidelines were announced.
The Committee goes on to state:

The committee is disappointed at the unannounced withdrawal of the tabling requirement in the case of the transport and communication GBEs and the apparent failure of other entities to comply with the Government's policy guidelines.

This is a matter of serious concern which has been raised in the Senate Estimates committee hearings on frequent occasions. It has certainly exercised the minds of Opposition senators. I commend the Government members of this Committee for standing up on this matter of very substantial principle. The Committee points out:
ASTA and ADI-
that is, Australian Defence Industries Pty Ltd-
are examples of major enterprises taken out of the sphere of direct parliamentary scrutiny without any reference to Parliament. Further, as exempt proprietary companies-
Senator Coates also pointed this out-
their formal reporting requirements under the Companies Code are negligible.

It is true that the Minister has said that he would ensure that full annual reports will be tabled in Parliament, even though there is no legal requirement for that to happen. However, the report states:

Transfer of the activities undertaken by ASTA and ADI out of the departmental structure has reduced the scrutiny of these activities by Senate estimates committees. Moreover, companies, unless specifically included by regulation, are exempt from the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act.
The report also states:
. . . the Government's involvement in 37 companies limited by guarantee and 67 incorporated associations through DEET has occurred without specific parliamentary approval . . .

This is a matter of significance as well as the defence companies that I mentioned a little earlier. I admit that the defence ones are more significant because, in the case of defence companies, the transfer of assets worth tens of millions of dollars and thousands of employees were involved. The Committee states:

To regard the removal of such undertakings from direct governmental, and therefore parliamentary, control as a mere matter of administration is to demean the institution which is the custodian of those assets. Parliament might well have approved the changes; it should at least have been given the option.
On the question of the Department of Employment, Education and Training, the report says:

The DEET companies raise similar issues of principle as well as potential dangers. In each company, although the Commonwealth nominates one director, it does not control either the composition of the board or the decisions made.

The Committee then deals with matters of insolvency. It is worth pointing out to the Senate that a risk clearly exists in respect of the failure of such companies. Massive liabilities, implied liabilities, may well rest on the Commonwealth's shoulders, on the taxpayers' shoulders. The report very sensibly points out:
It should be noted that the structure of these companies is similar to that of the now insolvent National Safety Council (Victoria).

The Government is proceeding with a system which has been shown to have the potential for absolute disaster for so many people and certainly for the public purse. It is the sort of disaster that took place with the failure of the National Safety Council in Victoria.

I request adoption of the Committee's recommendations that the annual reports of directly held government companies should conform to the guidelines set down for annual reports of statutory authorities; that a statutory requirement should be introduced for the annual reports of all directly owned government companies to be tabled in the Parliament as well as be provided to the relevant corporate affairs commissions; and that the same time limits as apply to provision of reports to the corporate affairs commissions should apply to tabling and that this should be included in the general government companies Act. In addition to that, I make the request that these reports be made available to senators before the sittings of the Senate Estimates committees dealing with the specific overview departments to which these government companies report, because the people of Australia own these companies. That is another reason for the Auditor-General to examine them. For proper scrutiny at the proper time, detailed information should be made available by the time of Senate Estimates committees.

I support Senator Coates's statement that the Auditor-General's Office should be the body authorised to audit these bodies. This underlines the urgent need, as outlined in the Auditor-General's report earlier this year which we dealt with quite recently, for the Auditor-General to have the resources, the structure and the flexibility to be able to undertake these audits. The Senate will note that the Auditor-General's Office appeared to be in a degree of crisis-I think the Auditor-General used the word-over its capacity to fulfil all the functions that the Auditor-General is basically required to fulfil and that many of these functions were not being attended to adequately simply because of a lack of staff, facilities, flexibility in employing staff, and a huge wastage rate of trained people, people trained at enormous cost on the job in the Audit Office. That drain of talent is a major problem which will have to be overcome if the very sensible recommendations of the report are to be implemented. I hope that this matter will be attended to.

As I said earlier, the Government has sought to hide some activities not simply behind the corporate veil of the corporations that it owns, but also through the trust funds that seem to operate in many other bodies. I hope that the Government reverses the clear trend to which the Committee has pointed. Rather than limit the amount of information available, the Government should go in the direction of making more available to the public information about the activities of the Government, as recommended by the Committee. I restate what the Committee said: these bodies are owned by the people of Australia. I commend the Committee for its report, which encourages the view that the people of Australia should have greater rights of supervision of and access to information from these bodies through their elected representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: — Telecom's annual report discloses a profit figure of $973m; in other words, Telecom has made a profit and the rest of Australia has made a loss. The essential proposition that flows from this is that it is not hard for the only player on the ground to kick goals, and that is what happened in this instance. I regard Telecom as being capable of being a very efficient fighting force. It has a very good quality board, people who would thrive in a competitive environment but who, because of the actions of the Government, are forced to operate in a range of monopoly areas. That is a trend that is going in the opposite direction around the world. For some reason best known to themselves, the anti-privateers and the Telecom monopoly preservation society in Caucus we will not see any competition under this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to look at some of the statistics that emerge from the annual report to explain why the profit figure is not a great deal higher. Telecom is acutely conscious of the political downside in returning a figure in excess of $1 billion. It has gone for gold plating rather than risk taking. It could have done a lot better. It was only because of a depreciation figure of about $187m that the figure was kept below that magic mark. There are other matters of particular concern. Apart altogether from the insensitivity of announcing increases in connection charges on the very day that massive profit figure was released, the most critical matter is the wilful and deliberate refusal by Mr Willis to release the Bureau of Transport Economics study on Telecom's community service obligations, in other words, the real cost of cross-subsidies. If we knew that we would know the justification for needing massive profits in order to subsidise those services in rural and remote areas. The industry accepts that it is a figure much less than $100m, which is chickenfeed compared to revenues in excess of $8 billion.

I do not want to say much more about Telecom's behaviour in deliberately trying to sabotage the release of that report and to come up with another set of figures to overturn it, or, indeed, to try to persuade Government members that somehow there is some skerrick of justification for a continued monopoly on the cellular mobile system. However, I want to tell the Senate of an interesting letter that I received today from Hidden Valley Lodge which is a holiday lodge some 40 kilometres from the nearest town and hospital in the Maitland region. It is addressed to Ros Kelly, the responsible Minister. It reads:

Over the last 12 months . . . On no less than 14 occasions the phone has been inoperative. At some times for as long as 4 days . . . Should we have a bad accident and cannot reach the Hospital the resulting legal actions against Telecom could be quite embarrassing and expensive.

I have bad news for Hidden Valley Lodge because Telecom's Act provides it with total immunity from suit. Even in the event of obvious negligence, Telecom cannot be sued. That is an outrageous state of affairs in this day and age. The letter goes on to say:
Since Telecom has been `fixing' our system we have-
Lost all phone services
Cannot dial out
Cannot receive incoming calls
Our Phones now won't ring
Our answering service (Telecom approved) will not pick up calls
The line drops out during a conversation
The only thing Telecom has succeeded in doing regularly is to send out the bill.
Apart from the lost business . . . we are isolated without this `basic' utility.
If your experts can't fix this problem please forward two tin cans and a large roll of string as the situation has become just ridiculous.

I have a great deal of sympathy for the Hidden Valley Lodge and, I think, so have the consumers of Australia. They do not understand why a profit of about $1 billion cannot be applied towards halving subscriber trunk dialling rates, getting our local call charges, which are about the highest in the world, down to reasonable levels--

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not. That is a lot of rubbish.

—I invite Senator Collins to read the management study that was released by NUS International Pty Ltd in March of this year. If he does, without doubt he will learn that local call charge figures that have been extracted from 12 countries around the world indicate that Australia's charges are dead level with those in the United Kingdom. The worst feature of all is that there is very poor quality of service. Telecom will not even publish quantitative data to let people know how long they have to stay in the queue. The Government will not even let Telecom charge for directory assistance, so Telecom is forgoing revenue of the order of $30m a year. Again, that is an example of political intervention by a government that claims to stand back and let the managers manage. All in all, I wish that Telecom would give us back some of our money.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the issues in the report which I would like to raise is mentioned on page 59, namely, the categories of documents that are held by the Commission. Any family in Australia could be identified on the basis of Medicare records. Any family that has thalassemia, any family with PKU-phenylketonuria-or any family with fibro-cystic disease or any other genetic disorder could be easily identified by the type of medical treatment that members of that family had received or the type of medication that they had received.

Australians and this Parliament should be concerned about how that information is stored, for how long it is stored and what access is available to that information. The Health Insurance Commission has given an assurance that that information is not open to public access, but it is highly sensitive data. I believe the Parliament should be informed in the report of the Health Insurance Commission as to how that data is dealt with and for how long it is kept.
