PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 September, on motion by Senator McGauran:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this Bill, which was introduced by Senator McGauran. At the outset I indicate that this issue requires a very sensitive analysis and a sensitive understanding of a very difficult situation that relates to Australian society, which, in the 1960s and 1970s, was split down the middle in terms of its approach to a particularly nasty and dirty war. Many issues possibly need reviving. However, other issues in relation to that war are best consigned to history so that we can learn from them and not raise them as divisive issues in today's society.

SPEECH.PARA: On 25 March 1968, a young Australian was killed on patrol and died soon afterwards in a helicopter during evacuation. He was one of the 496 Australians who were killed in the Vietnam war, in which 2,398 Australians were wounded. Forty-seven thousand American soldiers died in that war and 306,000 were wounded. For many of them, their lives were ruined completely. Approximately 400,000 South Vietnamese soldiers died and 783,000 were wounded. Close to one million North Vietnamese and Vietcong died in that conflict. I believe that indicates that the Vietnam war was a tragedy all round for this region as a whole: Australia, Vietnam and Asia. I believe that many of us can learn a lesson from the politics that surrounded that issue.

That young soldier was one of many who were killed during that conflict, which was a nasty and disgusting war that needs to be remembered for only three things: first of all, we remember those who helped to end it; secondly, we remember those who had to fight in it-either those who were conscripted on either side or those who chose to fight in it; thirdly, we remember those civilians who were maimed and killed in that conflict-remembering that more bombs were dropped on North Vietnam, for example, than were dropped during the entire World War II.

Second Lieutenant Fraser was one of the second group who had to fight in that war. As I indicated, whilst on patrol in 1968 he trod on an M16 jumping jack mine and was mortally wounded. He died later while being evacuated in a helicopter.

I turn now to the background of why Senator McGauran introduced this Bill. Some people such as Senator McGauran say that the subsequent actions of Second Lieutenant John Fraser should have justified his receiving a posthumous award for bravery. There are conflicting reports about this. Senator McGauran puts it in his particular way. He says that John Fraser was either a war hero who is worthy of a posthumous bravery award or another Australian soldier killed.

I put it to the Senate that every soldier who died in Vietnam and who fought in that dirty war is entitled to recognition. This Government has recognised them. For example, the Agent Orange royal commission was an attempt to examine a major issue that concerned Vietnam veterans. The recommendations and the final judgment of that commission are a matter for this Parliament to record. I believe that each of us individually has his own view about what is in fact the real issue and whether or not the truth about that could ever be discovered. Probably the major issue, apart from normal rehabilitation which faced the Vietnam veterans, was that problem with Agent Orange and the fears that we installed in them as a result of finding out more at a much later date about the effects of the pesticides that were used during the conflict.
Senator McGauran is right about one thing: he mentioned in his second reading speech that he was too young to fight in that war. He said:

. . . I am one such person who was not even born when the atrocities occurred in the Second World War. So it is significant for me to add that my generation has never been asked to go to war. We have been privileged with an era that has not challenged our beliefs to a point where we must take up arms and defend them in war.

In indicating that he was too young for the Second World War, Senator McGauran also indicated that he was too young to fight in the Vietnam War. I was one of those people whose name went into the second ballot during the Vietnam War. Two of my friends were killed in that conflict. One of them was totally opposed to the war in terms of its aims and the way in which we were fighting it. In fact, he had views about the strategic politics of what it was all about. He did not come back. As I said, he was one of those 496 young Australians killed. I would like to think that any young politician who is too young to have been chosen for or conscripted into any conflict would try not to make political capital out of this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not called for.

—I am not saying anything about Senator McGauran. Senator Boswell may have written his speech, but should try not to be so touchy about it. In other words, I would like to think that none of us here will try to make political capital out of this issue and will not lift the expectations of those families who, as a result of reading about this Bill, may be thinking that their dead sons or other young people who died in that war may, in some way, be recognised through a posthumous award. The passage of this Bill would not necessarily make that occur, and I think they ought to understand that very clearly. Turning the death of young men into a political issue would be an extremely dangerous thing for this chamber to involve itself in.

SPEECH.PARA: My one criticism of Senator McGauran on that issue goes to a comment he made during his second reading speech in which he referred to an `unfinished chapter'. He says this whole thing is part of an unfinished chapter. He refers to the failure of the Whitlam Government to bring in an end of war list. I must set the record straight on that point. I presume that Senator McGauran has made a mistake or has been carried away with some enthusiasm. It is a justifiable enthusiasm, but not one which is a vote getting or vote seeking exercise. He neglected to indicate that the proposition that there should be an end of war list was put to the Liberal Minister for Defence, Mr Fairbairn, who approved and endorsed the proposition that there should not be an end of war list. In fact, two successive Ministers of Defence-the Liberal Minister for Defence, Mr Fairbairn, and the Labor Minister for Defence, the Deputy Prime Minister, Lance Barnard-both took the advice of their Chiefs of Staff at the time, who recommended that there should not be an end of war list. That is the situation as I see it.

The recognition of young men who went to war should be an established principle. I do not necessarily believe in the Victoria Cross, particularly when VCs and other awards are awarded on a monthly quota, which, I understand, is the current system in most countries. Who is to say that, for example, in one month 30 should be awarded and, in another, 30 again, despite the fact that two totally separate battlefields could have been in operation at the time? Most of my interest in this Bill revolves around the way in which Senator McGauran is able to explain to me some of the issues that flow from it. I will certainly be asking some questions in relation to that.

I finish on a point that has moved me particularly. On a recent visit to Europe with a parliamentary delegation, I went to a very small cemetery in Louvain in Belgium. It is not one of the massive cemeteries like Ypres or Passchendaele, which by their sheer vastness bring home the tragedy of wars that have passed backwards and forwards across the Flanders region. It was a very small, neat and tidy cemetery. There were about 40 young Australians buried there. I use the term `young Australians' deliberately, because as one walks down the rows of crosses in that cemetery-this little cemetery stuck away in a very ancient town somewhere in the backblocks of Belgium, if I can put it that way-one cannot help but be appalled by two things. The first is the age of the young people, and the physical proximity of those people who died. Obviously, a Lancaster bomber, or something, was shot down and there are five or six Australian graves in a row. They were all aged 18 to about 31, and there was one man of about 46. I thought that these young people would probably never have gone overseas. They would not have known where Louvain was, yet here they are, buried 12,000 miles from their homes and relatives. That was hard enough-the thought of those young people ending their lives at those ages miles away from home.

Then I had a look at the visitors book, and the comments in that visitors book were probably the most moving things I have ever read. A lot of the comments had been put in during the last 30 years. They were from the parents and relatives of those young men. In some cases they were expressing gratitude for the way in which the cemetery was kept and the memories of their nephews or sons were maintained. Others were dealing with war itself. If ever one looked for an anti-war document, that particular book was it.

Today, with that and the memory of those people I knew who went to Vietnam in my mind, I would like to look very closely at this Bill brought forward by Senator McGauran. I hope that in a spirit of cooperation this House will examine it and make it a better Bill. I look forward to Senator McGauran's presentation during the committee stage of particular issues that will come out of it. As I said, I hope that at this stage there will be no politics made out of the deaths of young men in conflicts, not only in Vietnam but wherever those conflicts occurred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an honour for me to be able to support Senator McGauran's End of War List Bill 1989. I know this is a sensitive issue and one that worries a great many people. Let me reject out of hand the suggestion that there is anything political in this Bill. I will not accept that. I know the debate will flow and ebb, but I want it to flow and ebb in the right spirit.

SPEECH.PARA: In technical terms, Senator McGauran's private member's Bill seeks to set up a tribunal which would consist of three members, one from each of the three arms of the Australian Defence Force. These appointments would be made by the Minister for Defence. The purpose of the tribunal would be to investigate acts of valour performed by the people who did not receive awards during the conflict. I believe the tribunal would go on for any further conflicts. The Senate is indebted to Senator McGauran for having the initiative and foresight to bring forth this private member's Bill to honour the 49,211 men and women who served in the Vietnam conflict. My figure is slightly higher than the 511 put forward by Senator Aulich as being the number of men who paid the supreme sacrifice with their lives. Whether it is the 500-odd that I mentioned or the 400-odd that Senator Aulich mentioned, it is certainly a very high price to pay, as it would be even if it was only one.

That conflict lasted from 1962 to 1973. That decade shaped many people's lives, particularly the lives of people who would be in the age group of those who are in this Senate now. It challenged many young Australians, particularly those in universities. I know many members of my own Party were so challenged that they marched in protest against the conscription and our involvement in the Vietnam war. The people who would have traditionally supported our side, or the conservative side, of politics changed their political alliance and have probably carried that right through to now. That is the effect that that war has had on many people.

The events of that decade had a changing effect on the formative years of countless thousands of Australians. Whether senators and members of Parliament believe that Australians should have been involved in that conflict or the question of conscription really has nothing to do with this private member's Bill. The Bill seeks only to honour the men and women who served either in a voluntary or a conscriptive capacity in Vietnam. It does not seek to condone the conflict or honour war in any way, but simply to acknowledge the hardships and sacrifices that many people made. That is where Senator McGauran and I differ from Senator Aulich. We want to say to these people, `You did a job, you did it well, and we thank you'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what Senator Aulich said.

—That is the difference. I believe that the Government is not supporting the Bill. I may be wrong. Australia has always had a long and a proud tradition of honouring its returned servicemen. Because of the hardships they endured, including the social sacrifices of leaving home to serve and the economic sacrifices made-two years out of the game, business advancement and income halted for two years-we believe this Bill should be carried.

SPEECH.PARA: Each year, a public holiday is declared on 25 April, Anzac Day-not to glorify war but to acknowledge the debt we owe to the men and women who served Australia in all wars. There would be very few members of this chamber and the other chamber who do not go and stand shoulder to shoulder at the Anzac Day wreath-laying ceremonies and the parades each year. What we are doing there is paying tribute to the people who went before. In my area the Australian Labor Party Federal member for Bowman and I, the ALP member for the local seat and the ALP alderman all stand up in these ceremonies and pay tribute to those people.

Senator McGauran's private member's legislation to establish an end of war list is merely a continuation and an extension of the way in which we honour, acknowledge, thank and respect our returned veterans. Over the past three months there has been a continuous flow of petitions signed by Australians supporting the end of war list. Everyday over the last three months, 100 or so signatures have been placed on such petitions.

Australians have served in two major conflicts and many small ones, including the Vietnam War. That war was not won. It divided Australians like no other issue ever has. When our men and women returned from the war they received no accolades, no welcome, no parade and no appreciation for their efforts. In some cases, these men and women were shunned and humiliated. It was a traumatic experience from which some never recovered.

Fourteen years after the end of the war, the olive branch was extended by way of a coming home parade. Our veterans were welcomed home in a manner befitting the effort they made for Australia. It was a belated welcome and I believe it does Australia no credit that it took us 14 years to come to terms with our responsibilities and give these people a traditional welcome home.

At that time, a resolution was supported by all major parties, including the Australian Democrats, who joined together in a united motion of the Senate supporting the veterans and the coming home parade. I believe that the motion was also unanimously carried in the lower House. Senator Tate said:

The fact is that both the United States and Australia suffered terrible traumas during the conduct of that war and could not find the psychological resources to greet these soldiers as they returned, although we certainly should have . . .
I agree with Senator Tate. We should have given them the support that they required. He said:
. . . I certainly support the Welcome Home Parade concept.
He said he hoped it would be successful and helpful. Senator Reynolds moved the following motion:
. . . that the Australian Armed Forces served with great distinction in Vietnam between 1962 and 1972, earning great credit for themselves and for this nation;

express its appreciation and the appreciation of the Australian people for the individual and collective commitment, effort and sacrifice of its sailors, soldiers, airmen, men and women alike, who took part in the Vietnam conflict.
On the same day, Senator McLean rose and spoke for the Democrats in support of the motion, noting:
What we are now doing is joining together as a united chamber to express our good wishes to those great veterans and to hope that 3 October-
the day of the coming home parade-
and what it signifies for this country was an adequate belated expression of our appreciation for what they did for our nation and the sacrifices that they made.

There was a unanimous vote of support in this chamber. Those statements, made in the Senate and repeated in the House, illustrated clearly that the Vietnam veterans' efforts had been acknowledged by the parliamentary representatives of all parties in this Parliament. But if these veterans are to have the same place in history as veterans who served in other conflicts, then Senator McGauran's private member's Bill must be given the same support as the unanimously carried resolution carried by both Houses of Parliament for the coming home parade. To deny this Bill passage would be to take a step backwards and would be a hypocritical move by the members of this chamber.

During the Whitlam regime the Labor Government rejected the establishment of an end of war list on the grounds that it would be seen to be celebrating war. At that time, the Labor Party-and I say this with a great deal of sensitivity-had campaigned against the involvement in the war and there would have been a great deal of feeling against the raising of an end of war list-and I can understand that. I lived in those times. I saw what the war did to people. But after 16 years, at the end of a divisive period, it is time we put this matter to rest and gave the Vietnam veterans the same rights and privileges as all other Australian veterans enjoy. It is time we acknowledged them once and for all and put them on the same plane, the same level, giving them the same benefits, the same acknowledgment and the same honour as every other serviceman who has served this nation has received.

Today I saw in the newspapers a memorial to the Australian Army with two larger than life bronze statues of the Vietnam war diggers. They are massive statues, and beneath them is Mr Hawke. The ceremony marked the seventy-fifth anniversary of the departure of the last Australian Imperial Force for World War I.

I believe that if we are to honour our veterans, dedicate statues to them and do all the things that a government is responsible for in relation to our veterans it is up to us as a chamber to combine behind this legislation and pass it for all those people who served in Vietnam. Senator Aulich raised a question that the Liberal Minister-who I think was Mr Fairbairn at that time-rejected an end of war list. I have done some research on that which shows that Mr Fairbairn left the end of war list open because people were still serving in Vietnam at that time but that he did not rule an end of war list out. I just qualify that for Senator Aulich.

TALK.START.PARA: —How could he?

—At that time he was the Minister. When the troops had returned, that particular Government had been defeated and Mr Barnard was the responsible Minister. Then he made the ultimate decision. I do not think it does this chamber any glory to rehash who did what and why. It was 16 years ago.
—Senator McGauran has done that.

—Senator McGauran has not done that. Senator Collins has not been listening to my speech. Senator McGauran has brought forward to this Parliament a Bill that puts Vietnam veterans on the same footing as all other veterans that served in other theatres of war. For that he should be commended and congratulated by this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —If indeed that was all Senator McGauran had done in his speech, I would not even bother to canvass the history of the establishment of this list. But as Senator McGauran has chosen to use the words `political considerations' in respect of why this list was not established, it is essential that I do so. I completely agree with Senator Boswell that, in relation to whether this end of war list should be established, it really is not relevant as to who did not establish it originally. But the sponsor of this Bill, the End of War List Bill 1989, placed it on the record in the Senate in the second reading speech, and so it has to be responded to. I refer honourable senators to two paragraphs of Senator McGauran's second reading speech. They have to be read together. In the second paragraph of his speech on page 1 he says:

SPEECH.PARA: The chapter relates to the failure of the Whitlam Government to establish an End of War List on the return home of the Australian troops from Vietnam.
He concludes his speech by saying:
This aspect of the Bill would ensure that political considerations could never again prevent the creation of End of War Lists.

That implication cannot be allowed to stand without correction. Senator Aulich has said quite accurately that it was indeed Mr Fairbairn who made a decision not to establish an end of war list. Shortly after, that decision was again endorsed by the then Minister Barnard. Both Mr Fairbairn and later Mr Barnard simply endorsed in their decisions not to establish the list the decision that had been taken not to do so by the chairman of the chiefs of staff and the Department of Defence, which agreed with that decision.

Senator McGauran is shaking his head, and I look forward to him straightening me out in the committee stage and telling me that Mr Fairbairn in fact made a decision against the advice of the chairman of the chiefs of staff. Like Senator McGauran, in debating these matters in the chamber I can rely only on the information that I receive. If I have been misled in the brief that I have been given on this I would be delighted for that mistake to be pointed out to me. But I have been informed authoritatively that the original recommendation to the Minister by the chairman of the chiefs of staff of the Australian military forces and the Department of Defence was that such a list should not be established.

Senator Aulich and, I guess, a lot of us in here come from the same generation. At the time the Vietnam conflict broke out an infamous ballot system-that was my view then and now-was established to conscript 20-year-olds like myself to go to Vietnam. I was a country boy working on a farm in north- western New South Wales. I remember clearly today the rhetoric of the politicians of the day about that conflict. I feel as bitter now as I did then and as close to the feelings of serving soldiers, then and now, in the contempt that they generally feel for politicians, who generally, with some exceptions, stay safely at home during a war whilst making decisions in Parliament to send people half their age and, in many cases, a third of their age off to be killed. Philosophers over the years have sought the answer to the eternal question of the meaning of life. One of the great unanswered questions always must remain, without waxing too philosophical this afternoon, how a species of creation, if you like, on God's earth as capable of creating the brilliant things that humankind can create can still, in 1989-and, I regret to say, probably for the next 50 years-sees no other way of resolving difficulties and conflicts than by slaughtering each other in the most appalling ways possible.

The Vietnam war was no different, no worse in that sense, than any other war that has ever been fought in recent history. The horror of napalm being used against civilians and the enduring memories we have of small children in particular fleeing in terror with their skin hanging off them in shreds after napalm attacks from American fighter aircraft in Vietnam is in a sense no worse than the appalling way in which, for example, chemical warfare was used in the First World War.

One of my memories-young as I am-from my youth was working at weekends for a number of ex-servicemen by doing their gardens, mowing grass and so on. They were disabled by gas attacks in the First World War and had spent 30 years basically in the most appalling pain and misery dying of those attacks. The big difference, of course, between all of those conflicts, and the horror of them, and Vietnam was that for the first time we had scenes from that horrible conflict in Vietnam projected directly into our living rooms on a daily basis on television.

TALK.START.PARA: —You weren't alive in the earlier wars.

—That was remark- able. The fact that I was not alive during those earlier wars does not render me unable to recognise the fact that there were no colour television sets in people's living rooms at the time of the First World War and, in Australia, certainly not at the time of the Second World War. Nor was the ability of camera crews to accompany patrols into battle and to take, while they were in action, graphic pictures that were literally beamed by satellite from the front into homes on the same night that the conflicts occurred a technical possibility. One does not have to have been alive at the time to be able to draw that distinction. In those days, news from the front was read in the London Times and various other print media, sometimes months after the conflict. The news was penned by, amongst others, such eminent people as Sir Winston Churchill, who was at the time a war correspondent. Indeed, along with many others, he gained a great reputation over the years for the reporting of conflicts.

SPEECH.PARA: But Vietnam was unique. How many wars were there before Vietnam in which the civilian population at home were treated to the sight of daily body counts being recorded almost like a telethon on television, accompanied by graphic television pictures of helicopters lifting cargo nets full of bodies away from the front? If one has not experienced that sight on a daily basis from Vietnam, one must have led a very sheltered life indeed. I am far and away from being the first person that has ever made that distinction between the Vietnam conflict and all other conflicts. This caused a considerable difference in the way in which it was able to weld public opinion. Indeed, it has been graphically illustrated since the Vietnam War, and is in writing in many places, that many television crews were personally distraught and broken by having to record those appalling sights of little children who had been burnt to pieces by napalm when fleeing down roads, but they did record them, in their own sense of bravery and out of commitment to the serving soldiers in the field, because they honestly thought that getting those pictures and images back home would increase the political pressure to stop that useless war. The sad reality is that it was a useless and dreadful war.

I was lucky-and I have thanked God ever since-that my birthday was not pulled out of the barrel. Had it been pulled out of the barrel-and I remember my feelings now as strongly as I did then-I would have gone off to Vietnam filled with a desire to serve in that conflict and rid Vietnam of the communist menace, because I was silly enough to believe then, as a country boy in northern New South Wales, the nonsense that was peddled by the Government of the day that we had to kill the communists in Vietnam before they came to Australia. That was the enduring and consistent message that was delivered to us as 20-year-olds by the then political leaders of this country. Of course, it was a terrible and dreadful nonsense then as it still is. But I believed it. I was convinced that the next move after Saigon was going to be on Australia. That was the rhetoric that was peddled; and tragic it is.

What I objected to at the time was not that we should not be fighting in Vietnam, but that the choice of who went off to be slaughtered should not have been made by a lottery and that, if 20-year-olds had to go and die in Vietnam, then all of us should have gone and died-or at least exposed ourselves to the risk of dying-in Vietnam. That is what I objected to. Twenty years on, having read and seen a lot and having read quite extensively of the thousand-year history of conflict in Vietnam and the peculiar local, cultural and racial reasons for that conflict, I recognise that it was a nonsensical and stupid proposition to be fed to 20-year-olds in Australia that the next stop after Saigon was going to be this country and that we were under threat from a so-called communist menace. Nevertheless, that does not detract from the fact that those poor Australians who were sent to Vietnam, along with the thousands of poor Americans that were sent into that area of the world far removed from their own regions to suffer and die in that conflict, should not be given all the recognition that they deserve.
I put to Senator McGauran a number of points to which he could respond during this debate. In his second reading speech Senator McGauran said:

Nobody should doubt that because of the decision not to establish an End of War List, that there are now many unsung heroes of the Vietnam war. Two cases of young Australians who died in heroic service have been brought to my attention.

I do not disagree with that, but the difficulty and tragedy-and I am sure Senator McGauran knows it-is that the establishment of an end of war list is not going to resolve, and never has resolved, that particular problem. Literally thousands of deeds of extraordinary heroism, self-sacrifice and bravery in all conflicts in recent history-the Second World War, the First World War and the Korean conflict-have never been recognised and never will be recognised. All the end of war lists in the world are not going to repair that situation, particularly an end of war list that has got a quota of 30 fixed upon it, as this Bill determines. It can be varied by the Minister for Defence, but the quota is there.

We all know in this chamber-and, indeed, Senator McGauran knows it because it is in his second reading speech-that in awarding medals for bravery quotas are set by the military in order, to use the expression, not to degrade the currency. The difficulty, as Senator Aulich pointed out quite succinctly, is this: if one is in a terrible conflict and a terrible theatre of war where one is experiencing the most extraordinary events and the most extraordinary displays of valour and self-sacrifice are occurring every day, how can a monthly quota set by the military of how many medals are to be issued that month-and that is indeed how it is done-properly recognise the bravery and the self-sacrifice of the soldiers being slaughtered? It cannot; and neither can the establishment of an end of war list with a quota of 30 set on it ever recognise the self-sacrifice and valour of all the servicemen who served in Vietnam. It is silly of Senator McGauran to even assert in his speech that it can.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at the War Crimes Bill.

—Frankly, I do not know what the validity of that comparison is. I note that Senator McGauran made it in his second reading speech, but it is lost on me. Senator McGauran said in his second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: It should be noted that the future establishment of such a list was not ruled out by Mr Fairbairn.

Again, I do not know why Senator McGauran made that point, because how could such a list be ruled out by Mr Fairbairn, Mr Barnard or anyone else? It is a fact of Australian political life that Ministers have an average life in a ministry of only about 12 months. They do not have a permanent hold on a portfolio once they relinquish it. So Mr Fairbairn was not capable of declaring in 1972 that there would never be an end of war list, and nor was Mr Barnard. So I am not sure of the relevance of that particular statement. It would have been nonsensical had Mr Fairbairn even presumed to have declared that there never would be an end of war list.

A number of other matters raised in Senator McGauran's second reading speech are reflected in the Bill, so I will wait until the appropriate time during the committee stage to ask a relatively small number of questions of Senator McGauran about the detail of the Bill. Senator McGauran and other senators were perfectly correct when they said that the Vietnam war was a tragedy which has scarred this country, as it has the United States. One does not need to see movies, either good or bad, such as Gardens of Stone or other such movies to be reminded of the horror of the Vietnam war-horror in the true sense, because of the realisation of most of the troops who fought in Vietnam, very shortly after they arrived there as scared 20-year-olds, that it was a conflict that they should not have been part of and which they could never win, in the traditional concept of winning a war. Their political masters had sent them to Vietnam to be terrorised, injured or killed without declaring it as a war, so they were fighting a war that was not a war.

One of my memories of the conflict as a 20-year-old is of a political cartoon which highlighted the last days of that war when conferences were being held in Paris between the two sides involved in the war. One can imagine the desperate hope that must have been held by the soldiers that were engaged in that horrible conflict, in listening to the news on a daily basis, as to the success or otherwise of the peace talks so that the war could end and they could go home. I remember that one of the major conferences designed to end the conflict was held up for weeks while the politicians argued about the shape of the table around which they would sit. The table that was provided for them, when they arrived at the conference centre, was a standard rectangular table. Many of the delegates did not want to sit in direct proximity to people with whom they did not want to talk.

After weeks of delay in starting the conference, it was determined that a round table would have to be provided so that the delegates could be seated at the conference. An Australian cartoonist penned a cartoon showing a small group of soldiers sitting on top of a hill, being shot to pieces by the enemy, listening to the news on their radios of the arguments about the shape of the table, and discussing at the same time the remarkably consistent shape of the bullets that were killing their comrades who were falling around them.

For all sorts of reasons the Vietnam war was a terrible war, particularly, as I said before, from the point of view of the overwhelming knowledge of the people who were most directly connected with it of the absolute hopelessness and pointlessness of what they had been sent to do. I close by saying that the specific questions that Senator Aulich and I have about some of the content of the Bill will be reserved for the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be relatively brief in my comments today. It is interesting, and perhaps appropriate, that the End of War List Bill 1989 should be debated one day after the seventy-fifth anniversary of the departure of the last of the troops of the first Australian Imperial Force during World War I and on the last sitting day before Armistice Day. The Australian Democrats support this Bill. We congratulate Senator McGauran on introducing it. Australia has been involved in seven overseas conflicts, at the end of each of which, with one exception, an end of war list has been drawn up. The Vietnam war is the glaring omission from this list.

SPEECH.PARA: What are the reasons for establishing an end of war list? An end of war list is part of the healing process after a war. It is a sign that a war, which devastates all nations, is finally over. The list contains acknowledgments of the many instances of courage, inventiveness and self-sacrifice of which Australians are capable, both in and outside war. It is the view of the Australian Democrats that such a list has in the past played a very important part in the healing of the dreadful emotional wounds that are inflicted by war, on both veterans and civilians of our nation. The contents of the end of war list, and its very existence, demonstrate to us that a war is finally over. Even under the appalling circumstances of war, and sometimes because of those appalling circumstances, collectively and individually we are capable of outstanding acts.

It seems reasonable to ask why the Vietnam war was the exception. Why was there no end of war list at the end of the Vietnam conflict? I think that the answer probably lies in the special psyche of that time and of that particular conflict, and the reaction of the nation to it. I do not think we should be bound by the psyche of that period. I think we have an obligation to focus on the reactions of Australia now. Time brings objectivity and it brings seasoned judgment. We regard it as appropriate that that objective, seasoned judgment should now be what prevails. The justifications for the psyche and the judgments of those of the day should not prevail in this debate.

We all remember the atmosphere surrounding the Vietnam War. In our view, we were dragged into it under very dubious circumstances. We stayed in it in the face of massive and ever mounting opposition from ordinary Australians. We pulled out of the conflict in a rather haphazard, rushed fashion, which probably was an expression of the confused and ghastly nature of that conflict.

Successive governments wanted nothing more than to forget that the Vietnam War had ever happened, or that Australia had ever been involved in it. Under these circumstances, it is probably not surprising that Ministers, public servants, chiefs of staff, those in the Department of Defence and, indeed, many other Australians would have been caught up in the psyche of that era. It is not surprising that those who had to take those decisions and who were approached soon after we pulled out of Vietnam declined to agree to the setting up an end of war list for that conflict. Essentially, they just wanted it behind them. I think that it is only now, in hindsight, that we can take, are taking and have taken recently some of the more important objective judgments.

This private member's Bill brought to us by Senator McGauran sets up a tribunal consisting of one member of each of the three Services to consider all applications for inclusion on an end of war list for the Vietnam War and later conflicts. This seems to us to be an eminently reasonable and overdue action. As Senator McGauran has said, the welcome home march for Vietnam veterans in 1987, to which Senator Boswell referred, received the unanimous support of both Houses of this Parliament. It has been said that this was the first step towards the healing of the emotional wounds inflicted upon so many Australians and, indeed, upon the nation at large, by the Vietnam War.

The establishment of an end of war list is a fitting conclusion to the Vietnam war. It is long overdue, and it is small acknowledgment of the massive contribution of many Australians to an unpopular and hideous conflict. The Australian Democrats have no hesitation in supporting this Bill and wishing it a speedy and successful passage through both Houses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In closing the debate, I want to extend my appreciation to my colleague Senator Boswell for addressing this issue. His was a fine contribution; he spoke from the heart. I also extend my appreciation to Senator McLean of the Australian Democrats, who also showed great wisdom. He indicated his support for the End of War List Bill, his understanding of its thrust and what it all means. At a time when we are commemorating the Second World War 50 years on and are preparing to commemorate Gallipoli 75 years hence, I believe it is time to remember that Australia is nearing the twenty-fifth anniversary of its involvement in the Vietnam war.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not asking the Senate to debate the arguments for or against the war, but rather to put aside that argument and to pay a tribute to those Australians who served their country in that war. I am mindful of the fact that many senators were deeply involved in the great Vietnam war debate. It was a time of demonstrations and bitter divisions. Indeed, after hearing some of the debate today, it is evident that many of those emotions remain. I ask Government senators not to take a view that this is a political issue. This private member's Bill comes in another era, the 1980s, and they should not lock themselves into a 1960s mentality. Whatever feelings one might have about that time they should not affect one's outlook on this Bill. The Bill does no more than recognise those service men and women who served in Vietnam. That aim should be supported by and encompass the views of all senators in this chamber.

It has been said and it is significant to note that my generation has never been called to war, that we have never been asked to defend our beliefs to the point of taking up arms. Nevertheless, I vividly recall those times, probably because the war was covered on the news service every night and also because I had older brothers and sisters. I recall as far back as the visit of President Johnson, the Tet offensive, the Kent University shootings and the moratorium marches up Bourke Street led by Dr Jim Cairns-and so much more, up until the desperate fall of Saigon in 1975.

They were difficult times and they left a sad legacy and exposed many truths. But the real hangover and shame of this lost war comes from the fact that society and Parliament have for so long failed to recognise and pay proper tribute to those who fought and died in Vietnam in the same way as we have paid tribute to those who fought and died in past campaigns. Regardless of the horror and evil of war, it is important that a certain spirit of Australia is maintained, that we never forget those who served and died on the battlefields. That is what every shrine of remembrance asks of us-`lest we forget'.

An end of war list has been established following every other war that Australians have served in. The Vietnam war is the exception. To not establish an end of war list would surely make the Vietnam veterans lesser veterans than any of those who served in other campaigns. They would never be on a par with the veterans of past campaigns. I seek the support of the Senate in not leaving the Vietnam war an unfinished chapter in Australia's history.

It was not until 1987, some 16 years after the Vietnam war, that, with a coming home parade organised by the soldiers themselves, the first step was taken towards bridging the gap between the veterans and Australian society. Until that day the marchers had had no victory parade, no glory and no pride in having done their duty. One could not help but believe on the day of the coming home parade that all the bitter divisions had been healed. Certainly, from my travels around Australia it is evident that the coming home parade has had a lasting effect. Veterans now wish to talk openly about their experiences of war and their feelings about that war, and Australian citizens are now warmly listening. Sadly, that was once not the case.

While this change has occurred in society, Parliament has lagged behind. This Bill is a step towards bringing Parliament into line with the mood of society. The passage of this Bill will send out the strongest message yet that we are finally bringing our troops home. Nobody should doubt that that is what the Australian people are asking of us. The Bill has the support of the Returned Services League and the Vietnam Veterans Association. More important than that, it has the support of the Australian people, as indicated by the thousands of petitions that have been presented to this Parliament on a daily basis over the past several months. Those petitions have come from every corner of Australia, from Mount Tom Price in Western Australia to Nagambie in Victoria. No-one should doubt that the Bill has grassroots support.

I want to clarify a point in relation to my interjection on Senator Collins when I mentioned the War Crimes Amendment Bill. The principle I seek to reinstate is the same principle given by the Government when it introduced the War Crimes Amendment Bill. That Bill was introduced some 50 years after the Second World War. It sought justice in seeking out war criminals and bringing them to trial. I am now seeking out, some 16 years after the Vietnam war, justice in relation to war heroes. Even though it may seem that no war crime trials will go ahead, to many people the principle of that Bill was stronger than the practice. Equally, that must be the case with the End of War List Bill, in establishing an end of war list for the Vietnam war.

It is also worth noting that the armed forces held the same belief, that there were unsung heroes of this war. They believe that there could have been as many as 30. Documents released under the freedom of information requests showed that the defence forces-the Army, the Royal Australian Navy and the Royal Australian Air Force-made two requests for the establishment of an end of war list. I will go into more detail if required in the committee stage. In conclusion, I point out that the Bill has much to do with a certain spirit of Australia, a spirit borne out of the Gallipoli campaign, a spirit of pride for and appreciation of Australians who have served in a time of war. As with the Gallipoli campaign, which was a political and military disaster, even in defeat we must recognise and indeed uplift those people who served this country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I last spoke on the Privacy Amendment Bill, I made the point that the Bill was badly drafted and badly handled. The fact that it comes to this place with 41 Government amendments brings shame to the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) and the Government. Some Bills have required in excess of 100 amendments. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill was a conglomeration of amendments, many of which were Government amendments. The explanatory memorandum to the Bill deals with the amendments and covers some 18 foolscap pages, quite a number. I made the point that it was rather peculiar that the amendments were not available in the chamber or from the Table Office until this morning and I complained about that. I also said that this was a sign of the Hawke Labor Government being in complete disarray and disintegration.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hill made the point that we would be moving some amendments. The Bill has a great many defects. We have not yet been able to consider the amendments closely. Nevertheless, the Bill should be rejected in its present form, and with its amendments, and be drafted again. Senator Hill made these points very clearly. It is a commercially impractical Bill. It imposes unacceptable restrictions on the proper use of credit reference reporting, which now is a universal and essential part of modern commercial practice. A better approach than that taken by the Government would have been to state clearly the principles on which any such legislation should be based and then to fashion a Bill based on those principles.

The two basic principles are easily stated because they are common sense. Senator Hill made this point in his speech. First, commercial organisations should generally have access to financial information that enables them to make sensible commercial decisions. The second point is that there should be a mechanism by which consumers are advised that commercial organisations have had access to this information about them and an opportunity for them to obtain redress for improper use of that information.

The Bill does not measure up to either of those principles. Therefore, it should be rejected and presented again when it has been completely redrafted consistent with those principles. When that is done, the Bill should no longer contain the embargoes and restrictions on the proper use of credit reference reporting that it presently contains. It should provide that the consumer should be informed that access has been made to his file. As I have already mentioned, Senator Hill proposed some of those principles in his amendment.

If the Opposition's proposed amendment is defeated and the Bill passes the second reading, the Opposition will be moving a series of amendments in committee. One of the foreshadowed amendments is to change the definition of `credit' from `loan' to `credit' as it is normally understood. Some changes have been made in the amendments to do that. Other foreshadowed amendments allow credit reference reports to be supplied to: real estate agents and property owners to assist them in deciding whether or not to accept a tenant or to make other decisions about tenancies; debt collectors or creditors who are actually engaged in collecting a debt, but not private investigators; firms selling goods or services on hire purchase, credit or terms; underwriters of mortgages; firms engaged in leasing, renting, hire purchase or similar activities; firms needing to review an account; creditors, advising them of the new address of a debtor; and insurance companies-which have already been canvassed. As well, the foreshadowed amendments will allow cross-referencing between personal and business credit.

The Opposition foreshadows other amendments. However, our basic point is that this Bill should be withdrawn so that the Government can once again consult with the industry. The Minister said earlier that there had been consultation, but I say it is too little, too late. The Government should formulate a sensible Bill that recognises the important role played by credit reference reporting, which the present Bill does not do. The Real Estate Institute has made some points about this particular Bill:

While privacy is a fundamental right in our society, the Privacy Amendment Bill fails to strike a balance between the need for privacy on the one hand and the legitimate need for property owners to establish the credit worthiness of people who will occupy their property on the other. The right to privacy must also be balanced against the need for business and society to guard against fraud and reckless indifference to others' property.

I have already stated many of the points in this Bill about which I am concerned. I am aware that two speakers, namely, Senator Calvert and Senator Panizza, want to speak in this debate. Therefore, I close my remarks by saying that this is a sloppily drafted Bill, not so much by the drafters as by the Government of this country, which is on the way out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add my congratulations to Senator McGauran on the passage of his private member's Bill and on the way in which he brought it forward. As has been said by previous speakers, this Privacy Amendment Bill, which has been rushed into the Senate today at short notice-it is an on-again, off-again Bill with many amendments-is just another attack on small business in this country. It is another problem that will face those small businesses which, for some time, have been on the receiving end of a non-caring Labor government.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Acting Deputy President, you would remember that, in recent debates about small business, it has been said that small businesses-of which there are approximately 750,000 in this country-employ 65 per cent of all Australians in the private sector. Today, it is interesting to reflect on the effect of recent Government decisions on small businesses. For instance, the airline pilots dispute is sending small businesses to the wall. Today I received some letters from tourist operators in Tasmania who are absolutely at the end of their tether. Some of those who are in that position because of the airlines dispute are going to be affected by this privacy Bill, which will be another nail in their coffin. I refer to small businesses such as the real estate industry, to which Senator Brownhill referred; the used car and hire industries, particularly the hire car industry, which have been affected by the airlines dispute; and sellers of goods and services-just to name a few.

The attack on those sections of small business follows the Government's confrontationist attitude to the pharmacists, another small business in our community. The Senate does not need reminding of the results that this attack on pharmacists will have and is having on the ordinary Australian. Up to 30 per cent of those important small businesses will be forced to close. As a result, the sick and the needy in our community will pay the penalty because of the belligerent attitude of this so-called caring Government.

I remind the Senate-if it needs reminding-of the crippling results that unprecedented high interest rates are having on small business, particularly the real estate industry and the housing and rental markets, which will be affected by this Privacy Amendment Bill. If this Bill is passed-and I hope that it is not-it will only heighten the catastrophic effect that high interest rates are having on small businesses and families in Australia.

From time to time in this place we hear hollow statements from the Government benches about this Government's support for and the importance of small business. Therefore, it is of great concern to me that this Bill seeks to threaten the viability of so many small businesses that this Government purports to support. It is a charade. All one has to do is look at the Government's record.

I have mentioned previously some of the businesses that have already been affected by the decisions that this Government has made and has put in place. I should like to comment also on the modus operandi that has been used in the presentation of this legislation. It is the same old system that we have come to expect from this uncaring Government-legislation by press release. The first that small business heard about this ill- researched Bill was when a press release was issued on 31 May 1989. The Bill was then introduced to the Senate on 16 June by a motion that was moved by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, on behalf of the Minister for Consumer Affairs, Senator Bolkus. In the opening two paragraphs of his second reading speech, the Minister proudly espoused the previously introduced Privacy Act. He said:

Late last year, this Parliament passed the Privacy Act 1988. That Act provided for the establishment of the office of the Federal Privacy Commissioner and for privacy protection for individuals, both in relation to information about them held by Commonwealth agencies and in relation to their tax file numbers.

The Privacy Amendment Bill 1989 is the next step in the Government's program to introduce comprehensive privacy protection for the Australian community. The principal purpose of this Bill is to provide privacy protection for individuals in relation to their consumer credit records.

That sounds all very well. However, if honourable senators cast their minds back to the Privacy Act of 1988, they will remember that the same problem was experienced with that. This Senate had to make many amendments to make it a rational Bill that had some effect. It was the same old story, as I said earlier. It was the same modus operandi, legislated by press release. It was up to the coalition to set it straight so that it had some effect. We have the same situation with this particular piece of legislation. It purports to protect the rights of individuals when all it will do, in the form in which it has been presented, is make things worse for small business in this country. People talk about protecting the rights of individuals, but there will be very few individuals left who will have any money to be protected if we press forward with this matter.

As Senator Brownhill said a while ago, the Opposition is again in the position where it has to move significant amendments to try to improve a faulty Bill. This is being done in an attempt to save the jobs of Australians in the many small businesses in which so many Australians are involved. There is no doubt in my mind that the main purpose of this Bill and the reason it is being rushed through is that the Government once again is over-reacting, while it is in election mode, to the minority interest groups in our community that Mr Kerin has been referring to in recent times.

We really have to ask ourselves: What is the need to impose more red tape and regulations when we have one body in Australia, namely, the Credit Reference Association of Australia (CRAA), which is responsible for about 98 per cent of credit reference reporting in Australia? The CRAA is owned by its 4,800 members-the major public utilities, banks, finance companies, department stores, credit unions, building societies, insurance companies, credit card companies and many manufacturing and trading companies which are very reputable organisations. As Senator Hill said this morning, the CRAA has a database that now holds records on over 10 million individuals and businesses. Its members make about seven million inquiries a year about people or businesses to whom they are thinking of extending credit or lending money. For example, in October 1988 alone 534,000 inquiries were made, an increase of 80 per cent since October 1984. It is quite obvious that this reputable credit reporting association is not only successful but is being used to a great extent.

What is all this concern about privacy and the collection of data? Would it not be more prudent for the Government, without inflicting all this red tape and necessitating amendments, et cetera, to set up an inquiry, have discussions with this particular organisation that runs 98 per cent of the credit reference reporting around Australia, and have a look at its perceived shortcomings, if they exist? It seems easy to me, rather than inflicting this cumbersome legislation on small business.

This whole matter is of very serious concern to all small business. I, like many others on this side of the Parliament and probably on the other side too, have received dozens of letters in my electorate office from concerned businesses. I will briefly mention some of these because I think they sum up the major concerns these people have. The first is a letter from the Tasmanian Chamber of Commerce. Naturally, being a Tasmanian, I want to be rather parochial about this. The letter states:
On behalf of the Council and members of the Tasmanian Chamber of Commerce, I am writing to urge your rejection of the Privacy Amendment Bill 1989.

The proposed legislation threatens the viability of thousands of credit providing businesses by severely restricting access to credit information. As a result, the practical measures which have been developed to control the cost of fraud, dishonesty and consumer over-commitment will be curtailed or outlawed . . . In our State the overwhelming majority of businesses are small.
I would go along with that. The letter continues:
If their costs are allowed to increase in this manner, there can be no doubt that some will fail.
In fact, some are already failing because of the pilots business. The letter continues:

In addition, under this legislation, defaulting debtors cannot be reported until the account is at least 90 days overdue. This gives the debtor at least 120 days to ensure he cannot be traced-a particular problem in Tasmania where each year, a number of visitors equal to the resident population enters and leaves the State.
That was before the airline dispute, of course. It goes on to state:

In a carefully regulated system as presently exists, the means to check a customer's credit worthiness is not an invasion of individual privacy. It is a legitimate protection for business from fraud and dishonesty.

I know of many cases where visitors from this big island have visited Tasmania and incurred debts. No doubt those visitors were not checked out and skipped the country very quickly. What the Tasmanian Chamber of Commerce is saying is very valid. To change the tone somewhat, I quote from a letter from the Association of Tasmanian Credit Unions Ltd, which stated:

Credit Unions believe in the privacy of the individual but we are quite sure that credit providers in the future will seek to offset the reduced credit file integrity of files held by the credit reporting bureaux by seeking increased personal details of credit applicants thus increasing intrusion into the individual's financial privacy.
In other words, the Association is saying that this legislation will force credit unions into asking more questions and being more inquisitive about people's privacy. It went on as follows:

Also it is certain that both business and consumers will face increased costs in the form of higher interest rates, insurance premiums prices, public utility charges and rents. It is equally certain that the Commonwealth too will face a double cost, first through reduced tax revenues, as a result of increased bad debt write offs and second, through higher Social Security outlays to relieve increased indebtedness. Similarly, State Government public utilities will be denied information vital to the collection of bad debts and may, therefore, expect their losses to increase.
That is a little different from the concerns which have been raised in this debate so far, so I thought I would mention it.
Typical of letters from small businesses was one I received from Frosto Distributors. Frosto Distributors was incorporated in Tasmania and distributes frozen food. The Manager wrote as follows:
As Manager of this Company we require this information-
that is, credit information-
from recognised credit services because in the Food Service Industry we have a high rate of business failure.

There is no doubt about that, particularly at the moment. I am aware that the Leader of the Opposition in Tasmania, Mr Gray, was in Canberra this week seeking relief for Tasmania because of the airlines debacle. Honourable senators will notice I am not using the word `dispute'. There is no dispute! Two members of that delegation from private industry were engaged in the food service industry. I know from talking to them that they are very concerned about this privacy legislation.

Finally, perhaps the most interesting submission that I wish to speak about is that from the Real Estate Institute of Australia Ltd, which will probably suffer the most under this proposal. Without going into a lot of detail it is interesting to note that its President, Bill Woolcock, is also a Tasmanian, from Launceston. So I am being very parochial but at least it covers a cross-section of opinion from Tasmania's point of view. His covering letter stated:

REIA's primary concern is that the Bill does not strike the necessary balance between the need for protection of individuals' privacy and the requirements of business for information to allow it to function in an efficient and equitable manner. The legislation also has unintended consequences for both the owners of rental property and tenants. REIA believes that industry input would help quantify the significant economic and social costs of the legislation in its present form.

To this end we urge that it be referred to a parliamentary standing committee or a Senate select committee for review. If all else fails, that is what should happen. In fact, that is what should have happened in the first place. It is quite obvious from these hastily prepared amendments that I did not receive until late this morning-and I certainly did not receive them in my electorate office as Senator Bolkus suggested I should have-just how rushed this whole business has been.

As was mentioned by previous speakers, there is no doubt that there has been a terrible lack of consultation in this whole exercise. In the accompanying submission from the Real Estate Institute, from which I just read a covering letter, some of the major concerns in this whole mess are highlighted. They are matters which will affect the large majority of Australians. One of the most important concerns is the effects of the legislation on tenants in Australia. In these days, there is an ever-increasing number of tenants because, under the policies of this Government with its high interest rates, very, very few people can afford to buy their own home. I will quote some of the consequences for tenants that Bill Woolcock describes as resulting from the effect of the legislation. He stated:

As real estate agents do not conform to the narrow definition of providers of credit, they are excluded under the legislation from access to credit reporting files. Hence there can be no credit checks performed on prospective tenants.

One such consequence will be an inevitable discrimination against underprivileged categories of tenants. Such categories, which include single parents and low income households, have been successful in the past in seeking accommodation in the private rental market when they have been able to demonstrate a history of meeting credit commitments. If such information were no longer available, it is inevitable that discrimination would intensify and more would find difficulty in finding rental accommodation. In times of tight vacancy rates, accommodation in the private rental market would become increasingly the preserve of the more obviously affluent and conforming members of society.

A further consequence of the legislation is that it would lead to delays in applications for tenancy. In the absence of a report from a reliable credit report agency, further time would be expended checking other information relating to a tenant's suitability. This would disadvantage tenants who clearly need to know as quickly as possible whether or not their application has been successful.
Once again, whilst trying to protect the privacy and the rights of individuals, all this legislation is doing is making it more difficult.

I put it to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that if you were a prospective landlord and you were confronted by two individuals, one who looked as though he had just walked off a job somewhere and another dressed in a nice blue suit with a good tie and a clean shirt, without any benefit of credit reference I suspect that you could be talked into accepting that the gentleman who was better presented would be the one who would get the property. In actual fact, you would probably find, if you checked their credit, that the guy wearing the working cloths had a very good credit record and probably had a good background of paying his debts, whereas the guy in the suit with a tie and who looked like a politician was probably a crook.

Another significant problem that I do not believe has been looked at and that will be forced on real estate agents relates to their responsibilities to owners of rental properties. I will quote again from the submission of the Real Estate Institute of Australia. It states:

The removal of access to credit reporting facilities would severely diminish the ability of real estate agents to fulfil their responsibilities to owners of rental properties. Credit reference checks are an important process in the letting of properties when little or not information on prospective tenants is available.
This is the most important part:

In the case of professional managers of commercial, retail and industrial property, access would be denied to personal credit reference data on company directors and business principals. Such information is of critical importance as there is a proven high correlation between failure of businesses to meet credit obligations and the failure of principals of such businesses to meet their own personal obligations.

I can say from my own experience in Tasmania that, over recent years, there have been quite a few shonky companies. Unless someone had the access to credit references from these particular companies, as I said earlier, they would be well and truly long gone by the time the proper checks were done under this new, jazzed-up version that the Government wants us to be involved in.

Finally, I want to make brief reference to another small industry or business that exists in every part of Australia. I notice Senator Panizza sitting in the chamber. I know that he is pretty good at this sort of thing. I am referring to used-car salesmen. They rely very heavily on credit checks. As honourable senators would realise, the most important thing to a used-car salesman is for him to turn his cars over very quickly. Most of the vehicles he is selling are usually under hire purchase or on some sort of lease agreement. It would not be very effective for him to be in his yard when a prospective client came in, after having spent some time trying to talk him into buying a car, whether it be a Torana or whatever, to find that he had to go through some other organisation and make arrangements to do a credit check. In the meantime, I suggest, the prospective buyer may have found some defects in the car and probably may not accept the purchase.

If this continues and this legislation is carried, in car businesses particularly there will be all kinds of fraud. Owners of these car yards who are in the business of reselling cars and who have enough to worry about will have all the extra concern of not knowing the bona fides of their prospective clients. Of course, the end result will be fewer car sales, more bad debts and, in the end result, a more expensive mark-up on cars to offset the large amount of fraud and the bad debts that will probably be incurred.

As far as this Bill is concerned, the Government has already responded to industry pressure by making a number of changes. We have seen the result of these today in this huge number of amendments that we have not had a chance to look at yet. Those changes show that the Bill was not put together properly in the first place; it was created in an ad hoc fashion. As a result of that, these changes which have been introduced on the spur of the moment certainly do not reflect what could be considered to be sound thought and responsible planning but rather an attempt to put the Bill together in such a manner that it would get through the Senate.

In conclusion, as I said earlier, I strongly urge the Senate to reject this Bill, as Senator Brownhill, the previous speaker, has said. If the Senate does not reject this Bill, it should at least adopt the Opposition amendments, and, failing that, at least adopt the suggestion that the Real Estate Institute has made and refer this matter to a Senate standing committee or a select committee for further review.
