DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Parliamentary Information Systems Office: Auditor-General's Report-Thomas Borthwick and Sons (Australasia) Ltd

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It being almost 6.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I stood in this chamber and spoke about the importance of the role of the Auditor-General's Office and of the Auditor-General himself. I did that in the context of commenting upon the Government's response to the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts entitled, The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: It therefore accords me no pleasure tonight to rise to speak to a report of the Auditor-General which in a way fills me with great sadness. I refer specifically to a report by the Auditor-General concerning the investigation of an unofficial account operated by the Parliamentary Information Systems Office (PISO). This report was sought on 13 September when the Auditor-General, after a lapse of some time, was reluctantly asked by the Parliamentary Librarian, Mr MacLean, to investigate a secret account which was established by officers within PISO. The account operated secretly over a period of months and evidence has shown Mr MacLean was well aware of it. He was certainly aware of it by mid-July. The Auditor-General was not involved until 13 September. In the interim the Auditor-General's report was made available to the president of the Senate and passed on to Estimates Committee A and it is therefore a public document. It says:

On 6 September 1989 the Parliamentary Librarian signed a certificate on the Department's financial statements for the year ended 30 June 1989 in the capacity as Departmental Secretary and Principal Accounting Officer. That certificate stated, inter alia, that `the statements were in agreement with the department's accounts and records'.
The report goes on to say in paragraph 8.3 on page 16:

The statements contained no record of the transactions of the `unofficial account' which could be construed to be an account of the Department of the Parliamentary Library, albeit a highly irregular account. Since the Parliamentary Librarian was aware of the account's existence at the time of signing the certificate, it is a matter of conjecture whether he should have required the transactions of the account to be reflected in the statements or worded the certificate to disclose the account's existence. Further, the AAO provided an unqualified report on the Department's financial statements dated 6 September 1989, not being aware of the account's existence until 13 September 1989. It is also a matter of conjecture whether an unqualified report could have been issued had the account been brought to the AAO's attention earlier.

The body of the report of the Auditor-General sets out many issues which raise further concerns. The reason I am speaking to this report tonight prior to the tabling of the report of Estimates Committee A is that I am concerned that the Auditor-General's summary and recommendations do not tally with his own report. In the summary of his findings he says:
. . . there is no evidence to suggest that the persons involved acted other than in good faith, nor is there any evidence of fraud. . .

I suggest that that is about as valid as saying, `I didn't know murder was illegal'. In the hearings of the Estimates Committee on 3 October, one Mr Mullane gave evidence of a payment from this secret account of $1,629 for accommodation at the Sydney Hilton Hotel for three nights plus the provision of a dining room in which a workshop was allegedly conducted. Four officers from PISO who normally reside in Canberra found it necessary to travel to the Sydney Hilton Hotel for the purposes of this meeting. They were allegedly supposed to discuss matters relating to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). However, the Auditor-General finds in his report that they adjudged it was not necessary to talk to anybody from the ABC because they were apparently doing quite well themselves. The report says that it was an organisation review workshop which was `Sydney based primarily because of ABC input required on sound and vision portion'. The report says:
The ABC had installed the sound and vision systems in the new Parliament House. The then manager of PISO-
one Mr Goodall-
has informed the AAO that, as the Workshop progressed, it was found that there was no need to call upon the ABC for any input.

The people who attended that so-called workshop were the then manager of PISO, Mr Goodall; the Director, Planning and Administration (PISO); the Director, Special Projects (PISO); and the assistant project manager employed by Computer Power Pty Ltd, under prime contract between PISO and Computer Power for the work with PISO. The report continues:

The Movement Requisition for the then Manager of PISO's travel was approved by the Parliamentary Librarian while the then manager of PISO approved the movement requisitions for the other two PISO officers.

As I said yesterday, the concern is that the Auditor-General is the essential link between public accountability-that is, the accountability for the expenditure of government's and taxpayers' funds-and the Parliament. If that link is broken down in any way, then true accountability is just not possible. It would have been appropriate had the jurisdiction been available, I believe, to have referred the Auditor-General in this instance to the Ombudsman, who, I said yesterday, has already himself written a report that he would like to be considered as part of the scrutiny process. Unfortunately, the Auditor-General is the head of one of those bodies which are precluded from investigation by the Ombudsman.

As I said, the report does not justify the summary and conclusions that the Auditor-General, under his own hand, has reported upon. There are many questions which are not answered. Who actually opened the account? Whose signature appeared on the account? Why did the PISO officers involved in establishing the illegal account claim that there was apparently a general belief among officers of the parliamentary departments that the provisions of the Commonwealth finance directions and purchasing manual, the Audit Act and the Constitution-all of which the Auditor-General found were breached-did not apply to the parliamentary departments? Can anyone explain to me how people could work in the parliamentary departments and somehow believe that they are not covered by the Constitution, the Audit Act or the finance regulations and how the Auditor-General, who is charged with the responsibility of ensuring the proper expenditure of public funds, could also somehow believe that they did it all in good faith? It is just not credible.

I heard early in the piece, by way of gossip, that this report was to be a whitewash. I was so concerned about that that I rang the Auditor-General and said, `I think the person I should tell that I have heard these rumours is indeed the Auditor-General himself'. I asked Mr Taylor what stage the report had reached. He said that he had not involved himself with this report early in the piece and was not aware of the situation. I suggested to him that he properly ought to involve himself forthwith and be involved in the preparation and furnishing of the report. The Auditor-General then assured me that he would do that. I can only believe that he was quite approving of the way in which this report has finally been presented. As I said, it gives me no joy at all to have to stand in this place and say that I find a report of the Auditor-General-whose office I have defended at great length, whose independence I have striven to maintain and, indeed, enhance-of such a poor standard.

At some stage in the future people will have the opportunity to debate the report of Estimates Committee A, which I am not able to do at this stage, nor will I. I think it is important that people avail themselves of this report. For instance, we read that moneys from this secret account were used to buy such things as a microwave oven, the framing of nine prints, two credenzas with side tables with refrigerators and other such items, quite in breach of all the regulations, and indeed, as I said, to pay those accounts for the so-called workshop conducted in the Sydney Hilton Hotel. I add that the Auditor-General recommends that reimbursement be made for those amounts of money which exceed normal travelling allowance.

If it is the case that other departments outside the parliamentary departments are to see that people who have clearly breached, according to the Auditor-General, the Constitution, the Audit Act, the finance regulations, at least six finance directives and the Commonwealth purchasing manual are to go uncriticised in a real sense and be told that it is all to be whitewashed because the Auditor-General says `that there is no evidence to suggest that the persons involved acted other than in good faith', then I think we have a grave concern for our accountability process, because there is abroad a feeling that somehow there is no area in the Federal public sector for misappropriation or improper behaviour. There is a feeling that that goes on only in State governments or local government. But anyone who has heard the recent evidence given before the Independent Commission on Corruption in New South Wales concerning one Mr Ross, an employee of the Department of Administrative Services, can only know that there is great opportunity for temptation in the Federal sector, where the amount of money spent on procurement is in the vicinity of $8 billion a year.

If this report is to be allowed simply to be a whitewash of what occurred in PISO, in the Department of the Parliamentary Library, then I think the signals that are sent out to the public sector generally are totally misleading. That standard of behaviour is clearly not acceptable either by the departmental head, the Parliamentary Librarian, or operatives within that Department. As I have said, that is why I stand in this place tonight and, with great sadness, feel it is necessary to say that a report of the Auditor-General, whose office I have steadfastly believed in and which I still believe is an integral part of the question of accountability, has simply let the side down.

As I said, I commend the report to others to read, as I commend the Hansard of the Estimates Committee hearing of 3 October and the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts entitled The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and Parliament. If the Auditor-General is to fulfil that function, then I am afraid that he has to lift his game.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the matters of public interest debate at lunchtime, Senator Alston raised issues dealing with the Thomas Borthwick and Sons (Australasia) Ltd meatworks at Portland. He took me to task-although gently perhaps-over a speech I made about two months ago on 5 September 1989. Senator Alston kindly told me that he was going to make this speech today, but unfortunately I did not hear it. I am relying on a summary of the speech obtained by Marcia O'Hara, a member of my staff, and perhaps one of the most outstanding staffers in this building. Senator Alston, for about five minutes, referred to a misstatement I had made about the employment of labour by Borthwick's at Portland.

SPEECH.PARA: According to the note I have, Senator Alston mentioned that ministerial directions under the health Act enable unemployed to claim medical examinations for employment applications and he generally defended Borthwicks. The note says that Senator Alston said that I had more or less sinned, which had me concerned. Today is All Souls Day, which makes one very apprehensive about one's future when it is put that I have said something wrong in a speech made two months ago which must now be corrected.

My speech of 5 September 1989 has roused some furore in south-west Victoria and comments have been made about me by a Mr Hughes from Queensland, who said that in the Federal Parliament I raised issues about prospective employees at the plant being forced to claim on their Medicare entitlements and that I was not really worthy of being a senator. As a result of this criticism, I thought I had better look at this speech that was so full of venom. As I had been chosen to be the person to be criticised, I thought that this speech might compare with-and I say this with great respect, Mr Acting Deputy President-one of your brilliant efforts. I thought: Is this speech of the standard of Senator Crichton-Browne's? Does it lash those it opposes so that they crawl away?

I looked at my speech of 5 September for the evil words where I had accused Borthwicks and Elders IXL Ltd of all sorts of wrong. The very vicious sentences-and the Minister at the table, Senator Reynolds, will appreciate the viciousness of this attack-contained in the speech say:

Elders IXL advertised for employees under the new award. People applied. The company sent them to a particular doctor in Portland. He reported to Elders on their physical ability to carry out the work required. Elders did not pay for the certificates. The candidates were told to use their Medicare entitlements. This caused concern because the Medicare scheme is not intended for the purpose to which it was put.

My understanding-at least until the time it was pointed out to me-was that Medicare was developed to help people pay for the medical care that they might need. I was pointing out here that that was not the purpose to which it was put. I did not accuse Elders IXL or Borthwicks of any criminal activity or wrongdoing. I simply said that the Medicare scheme was not intended for the purpose to which it was put.

This statement has produced items and caused letters to be sent to the local newspaper, a denunciation made of me from Queensland and during the matters of public interest discussion a contribution from Senator Alston. I really am at a loss to know what I can do about it. Do I withdraw the statement that it is a matter of concern when an employer sends people, including people with whom he has been in dispute, to a specific doctor where they have got to use their Medicare card for a certificate, which is then sent to the employer who keeps it to himself? Is that statement so outrageous as to call forth denunciations in the Senate, letters in the newspaper and the disturbance that this has apparently caused? It seems to me to be a reasonable statement of fact that medical examinations may be made through Medicare for people who are unemployed so that they can get certificates to obtain work, if they are allowed to go to their own doctor. But it can be a matter of concern to the people who have to have a medical examination that they have to go to a particular doctor nominated by their prospective employer.

I have not read the debate on the introduction of the Medicare scheme, but I would be surprised if the debate said that one of the intentions of introducing the Medicare scheme was to allow prospective employees of Elders IXL to get a medical report on their ability to carry out the work. I also mentioned Medicare. I stated:

But for the unions, conditions provided by Elders IXL at Portland would be poorer. A situation has been created where people looking for work must use Medicare to pay for a report from the single doctor to whom the company sends them.

One matter of concern is the fact that doctors in Portland, other than the doctor who conducts the examinations, feel troubled about the situation. They wrote a letter to the Portland Observer of 29 September in which they stated:

The following Doctors, Mr J. Das, Dr S. Jones, Dr G. Hitchman, Dr M. Martin, Dr B. Myles, Dr P. Reid and Dr T. Tierney categorically deny that at any time did they receive a `circular' from Thomas Borthwicks and Sons regarding Pre Employment Medicals or any other matter.
At no time had these Doctors charged Medicare for medicals performed on behalf of Borthwicks.
Indeed none of these Doctors have recently performed medicals for this company.
Dr Peter M. Reid.

That part of my speech of 5 September 1989 dealing with Medicare aroused all this concern. The interesting point is that apparently it did not disturb the company that I also alleged that it had failed to comply with an award, that is, the award obtained at the end of the case in the Industrial Relations Commission between the union, the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, and Borthwicks. In that speech I said:
However, in clause 35-
that is, of the new award-
it did provide for seniority. Elders IXL did not comply with that clause. The union complained to the Commission, which said it could do nothing.

I accused Elders IXL of failing to comply with an industrial award. In contrast to the reaction to the very mild statement I made in my speech about the use to which the Medicare scheme had been put, which brought forth the company's rage, and the address by Senator Alston at lunchtime, there has been no reaction to the statement I made about the breach of the award. Is it fair to conclude that Elders IXL has no compunction about breaching awards, that it is quite happy to breach awards, but it is not happy to be accused-if that is the word-of using the Medicare scheme? In fact, as I read the transcript of my speech, it is not even accused of that. Is it concerned about a mild rebuke in respect of Medicare, but not concerned about the accusation that it has failed to comply with an award. If that is so it is a matter of great concern to the people of this nation that a company such as Elders IXL should not be troubled-and I judge this from its reaction to my speech-about breaching an award. It has not responded to the rebuke that it failed to comply with the law-awards having the force of law. It has absolutely no concern about that. I would have thought that the major protest would be about the accusation that it had failed to comply with an award. That it has not made one should be contrasted to the excessive reaction to the other statement I made. This says a lot about this whole dispute.

It would seem to follow-this inference can be fairly drawn from what has happened-that Borthwicks, controlled as it is by Elders IXL, has absolutely no compunction about breaching awards. It is disastrous that a company of its size and repute should approach industrial relations in this way. Whether or not we accept the industrial relations system, the fact is that it is the law of the land. Simply to disregard the law of the land and reject it out of hand because it does not suit one, simply to ignore it, is to take up a worrying stand.

What I am concerned about, arising from the reaction of Elders IXL to my speech of 5 September 1989, is the awful silence in respect of what I would have thought was the most serious of any of the accusations I made in it, namely, that the company has failed to obey the law, that it has failed to comply with the direction of the Industrial Relations Commission, and that it has failed to follow an award. It has said nothing about those things. Senator Alston has brought forward matters, as he is entitled to do, and he has done that with propriety. It says a lot about this company that it has reacted in the way it has to the statement I made regarding its use of the Medicare scheme-a scheme which is not intended to be used for the purpose to which it has been put in this case. That statement has been met with rage, while the proposition that the law has been breached has been met with silence. I did not say that the use by the company of the Medicare scheme had breached the law governing its operation. I simply said that it was of concern that people applying for jobs with this company had to use their Medicare entitlements in order to get a job. I said that the Medicare scheme was not intended for the purpose to which it was put in this case.

It is of concern that people who have been out of work for months, who have been crushed by the burdens of industrial trouble, who have had to wait for a long period while the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, now the Industrial Relations Commission, decided their case-that took about six months-would feel depressed. Those people were asked to visit the doctor used by the company, who then reported back to the company on their physical condition. They were unable to see the doctor's reports, even though, as I said, the doctor was paid by Medicare. That, in my view, is a matter of singular concern, particularly when one is dealing with a company which, according to its reaction to my speech, apparently has no regard for the force of awards and no regard for the law of the land.

If one reads the speech I made-it took me only five minutes to make it; it has taken me 15 minutes to describe it-one sees that it refers to the tragedy that was occurring while the dispute was before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It took too long to resolve. In my speech, I talked about the misfortune of those people caught in a situation in which the Commission took a long time to decide the issue. They were out of work for a long period. No matter what one says about the dispute, it was tragic that these people should be thrown into the situation they were. In the speech I referred to how these people had been caught up in the system and the distress that they had suffered. Yet Borthwicks, run by Elders, did not acknowledge the concern that I expressed about the situation of the people who were put through the grinder of the system. Borthwicks' concern was apparently about this one sentence, where I said:
This caused concern because the Medicare scheme is not intended for the purpose to which it was put.

That was seen by Elders as criticism and it raised a furore. It ignored completely the thrust of the speech, namely, a concern for these people so tragically dealt with by the circumstances that pertained in Portland earlier this year and late last year. It is a strange order of values, a strange arrangement of priorities, that all the elements in this speech dealing with people in these tragic circumstances should be ignored. There was not one word of sympathy in anything that was subsequently said-either by Senator Alston today or in any of the comments made by Borthwicks and Elders IXL published in the newspapers. Since I made this speech there has not been one word of sympathy for these people.

The company could have said, `Look, Senator Cooney, you were a bit rough in what you said there, but we do concede that the people had been tragically affected'. Although it could have said that it was not the fault of the company, it could have at least acknowledged the position of the people who had worked for the company, or who are now potential workers. These are not union leaders but ordinary men and women. One would have hoped that there would be some expression of sympathy for them. The company could have said that it was sympathetic but that nevertheless that is how the system works, that is how the cookie crumbles, or whatever other expression it wanted to use. However, it said absolutely nothing about the essential thrust of the speech and gave not one word of sympathy to the people involved. It simply extracted one sentence from the total text of the speech and caused a furore. This led to Senator Alston giving a speech about the matter today as a matter of public importance. This all seems to be a most extraordinary evaluation of what human life is all about.
I shall conclude by reading what I said in the last paragraph about the present situation. The course that this matter has taken since I made this speech confirms what I said there:

Much has been said about the need to free up the labour market. The call has been for workers and management to negotiate enterprise agreements. Unions have been allotted a minor role in the scheme of things. But for the unions conditions provided by Elders IXL at Portland would be the poorer.
I think the reaction of Elders to this speech is evidence of that. It is quite clear from the reaction of the company to this speech that more than ever there is a need for good, strong unions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.06 p.m.
